Nipper
Audit Report
Friday, September 30, 2022
 

Summary

Nipper performed an audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the network device described in the audit scope. The report consists of the following:

  • a best practice security audit section which details any identified security-related issues. Each security issue identified includes details of what was found together with the impact of the issue, how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit and a recommendation. The recommendations may include alternatives and, where relevant, the commands to resolve the issue;
  • a Defence Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) report section that provides compliance information against specific STIG benchmarks. The report includes a summary of the findings, detailed findings and recommendations on remedial action together with references and severity information.

S.1 Audit Scope

The scope of this audit was limited to the device described in Table 1.

Table 1: Audit scope
Device Name OS
Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org IOS 15.0(1)M

S.2 Security Audit

Nipper performed a best practice security audit of the one device detailed in the scope and identified 81 security-related findings. Although significant findings were identified that Nipper recommends should be reviewed as soon as is practical, most of the security findings were rated as low or informational. Each of the findings identified is described in greater detail in the main body of this report.

Nipper identified a number of clear-text protocol related findings. It is important that all clear-text protocol services should be replaced with cryptographically secure alternatives in order to help prevent unauthorized eavesdropping of potentially sensitive data. Furthermore, the clear-text services are often used for administration purposes and a malicious user, or attacker, who is able to monitor the communications may also gain access to authentication credentials that could then lead them to gain administrative access to the system.

Nipper can draw the following statistics from the results of this security assessment (percentages have been rounded). 1 finding (1%) was rated as critical, 14 findings (17%) were rated as high, 24 findings (30%) were rated as medium, 24 findings (30%) were rated as low and 18 findings (22%) were rated as informational.

Severity Classification
[No canvas support]
Issue Classification
[No canvas support]

Table 2: Summary of findings for each device

1

Your Report

This report was produced by Nipper on Friday, September 30, 2022. The body of this report contains the following reports:

  • Best Practice Security;
  • DISA STIG Compliance;
  • Appendix.

During this report various text styles, icons, ratings and so on are used to describe and reflect various aspects of the analysis and configuration. This section describes those conventions, ratings and icons etc.

1.1 Report Conventions

This report will make use of the text conventions described in Table 6.

Table 6: Report conventions
Convention Description
command This text style represents a device command that should be entered literally.
<user data> This style of text represents a part of a device command that you should substitute with a relevant value. For example, a command that sets a device's IP address would use this text style in a position where the address should be entered.
[optional] These are used to enclose a part of a command that should be treated as optional.
{required} These are used to enclose a part of a command that is required.
| This is used to divide options which could be enclosed in either required or optional braces.

1.2 Compliance Status

Each compliance audit check is given a status that indicates the outcome of the analysis for that audit check. Table 7 describes each possible status.

Table 7: Compliance Status
Status Description
The check has passed all of its required elements. For example, if the check states that the Telnet service should be disabled and it was, then it will be marked as passed.
The check has failed to meet some or all of the requirements. For example, the check may specify that support for only SSH protocol version 2 must be configured and version 1 was found to be configured. Therefore the result would be marked as a fail.
The check requires further investigation in order to determine if it is a pass or fail. For example, if the test states that port security should be enabled on a network switch port or it needs to be physically secured. If the devices configuration does not show that the network port has port security enabled, then an investigation of the physical security would have to be performed in order to determine this checks status. Therefore this check would be reported as needing further investigation.

1.3 DISA STIG Ratings

Severity Category Codes (referred to as CAT) are a measure of vulnerabilities used to assess a facility or system security posture. The DISA STIG category codes are specified against each guidance check based on guidelines outlined in Table 8.

Table 8: STIG Vulnerability Severity Category Code Definitions
Rating DISA Category Code Guidelines
CAT I Any vulnerability, the exploitation of which will directly and immediately result in loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.
CAT II Any vulnerability, the exploitation of which has a potential to result in loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.
CAT III Any vulnerability, the existence of which degrades measures to protect against loss of Confidentiality, Availability, or Integrity.

1.4 Nipper Ratings

Each finding identified and scored using the Nipper rating system is rated against both the impact of the finding and how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit. The fix rating provides a guide to the effort required to resolve the finding. The overall rating for the finding is calculated based on the finding's impact and ease ratings.

1.4.1 Impact Rating

A finding's impact rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 9.

Table 9: The impact rating
Rating Description
Critical These findings can pose a very significant security risk. The findings that have a critical impact are typically those that would allow an attacker to gain full administrative access to the device. For a firewall device, allowing all traffic to pass through the device unfiltered would receive this rating as filtering traffic to protect other devices is the primary purpose of a firewall.
High These findings pose a significant risk to security, but have some limitations on the extent to which they can be abused. User level access to a device and a DoS vulnerability in a critical service would fall into this category. A firewall device that allowed significant unfiltered access, such as allowing entire subnets through or not filtering in all directions, would fall into this category. A router that allows significant modification of its routing configuration would also fall into this category.
Medium These findings have significant limitations on the direct impact they can cause. Typically, these findings would include significant information leakage findings, less significant DoS findings or those that provide significantly limited access. An SNMP service that is secured with a default or a dictionary-based community string would typically fall into this rating, as would a firewall that allows unfiltered access to a range of services on a device.
Low These findings represent a low level security risk. A typical finding would involve information leakage that could be useful to an attacker, such as a list of users or version details. A non-firewall device that was configured with weak network filtering would fall into this category.
Informational These findings represent a very low level of security risk. These findings include minor information leakage, unnecessary services or legacy protocols that present no real risk to security.

1.4.2 Ease Rating

A finding's ease rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 10.

Table 10: The ease rating
Rating Description
Trivial The finding requires little-to-no knowledge on behalf of an attacker and can be exploited using standard operating system tools. A firewall device which had a network filtering configuration that enables traffic to pass through would fall into this category.
Easy The finding requires some knowledge for an attacker to exploit, which could be performed using standard operating system tools or tools downloaded from the Internet. An administrative service without or with a default password would fall into this category, as would a simple software vulnerability exploit.
Moderate The finding requires specific knowledge on behalf of an attacker. The finding could be exploited using a combination of operating system tools or publicly available tools downloaded from the Internet.
Challenging A security finding that falls into this category would require significant effort and knowledge on behalf of the attacker. The attacker may require specific physical access to resources or to the network infrastructure in order to successfully exploit the vulnerability. Furthermore, a combination of attacks may be required.

1.4.3 Fix Rating

A finding's fix rating is determined using the criteria outlined in Table 11.

Table 11: The fix rating
Rating Description
Involved The resolution of the finding will require significant resources to resolve and is likely to include disruption to network services, and possibly the modification of other network device configurations. The finding could involve upgrading a device's OS and possible modifications to the hardware.
Planned The finding resolution involves planning, testing and could cause some disruption to services. This finding could involve changes to routing protocols and changes to network filtering.
Quick The finding is quick to resolve. Typically this would just involve changing a small number of settings and would have little-to-no effect on network services.

1.4.4 Notes

It is worth noting that Nipper is unable to provide an accurate risk assessment due to a lack of contextual information. For example, in the case where highly sensitive information is processed, a Denial of Service (DoS) vulnerability poses less of a risk than the integrity of the data or an attacker gaining access to it. Similarly, for a situation where up-time is critical, a DoS vulnerability could be more important than the leakage of sensitive information. Therefore the ratings provided by Nipper are only intended to be a guide to an finding's significance.

1.5 Network Filtering Actions

This report includes a number of network filter rules. Table 12 describes the filter rule actions used within the report.

Table 12: Network filtering actions
Action Description
Allow the network traffic, enabling it to pass through to its destination.
Drop the network traffic, preventing it from reaching its destination and not informing the sender that it has been dropped.

1.6 Network Filter Objects

This report details the type of network objects used within the filter rules. Table 13 describes the object types used within the report.

Table 13: Network filtering actions
Object Description
This represents anything and everything. Any address, user, application etc.
Describes a single IPv4 or IPv6 address.
Specific IPv4 or IPv6 network address.
A network interface, such as eth0 or fastEthernet0/1.

2

Best Practice Security

Notes

beans

2.1 Introduction

Nipper performed a best practice security audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the device detailed in Table 14.

Table 14: Best practice security audit device list
Device Name OS
Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org IOS 15.0(1)M

2.1.1 Security Issue Findings

Each security issue identified by Nipper is described with a finding, the impact of the issue, how easy it would be for an attacker to exploit the issue and a recommendation.

2.1.1.1 Issue Finding

The issue finding describes what Nipper identified during the best practice security audit. Typically, the finding will include background information on what particular configuration settings are prior to describing what was found.

2.1.1.2 Issue Impact

The issue impact describes what an attacker could achieve from exploiting the finding. However, it is worth noting that the impact of an issue can often be influenced by other configuration settings, which could heighten or partially mitigate the issue. For example, a weak password could be partially mitigated if the access gained from using it is restricted in some way.

2.1.1.3 Issue Ease

The issue ease describes the knowledge, skill, level of access and time scales that would be required by an attacker in order to exploit an issue. The issue ease will describe, where relevant, if any Open Source or commercially available tools could be used to exploit an issue.

2.1.1.4 Issue Recommendation

Each issue includes a recommendation section which describes the steps that Nipper recommends should be taken in order to mitigate the issue. The recommendation includes, where relevant, the commands that can be used to resolve the issue.

2.2 Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Critical
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.2.1 Finding

Access to restricted network user and administration services are typically secured using username and password authentication credentials. The strength of the authentication credentials is even more important if the service allows for devices to be reconfigured or it allows access to potentially sensitive information.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if any enabled user accounts had a dictionary-based authentication password.

2.2.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

The following table contains user accounts configured with a dictionary-based password on router03.nipper.org and includes administrative access to the device.

Table 15: Users on router03.nipper.org with a dictionary-based password
User Password Strength Policy
enable (password) cisco Dictionary-based  
temp password Dictionary-based PASSWORD_POLICY
testuser password Dictionary-based  
localuser password Dictionary-based  
Console Line password Dictionary-based  
Auxiliary password Dictionary-based  
VTY 0 - 4 Line password Dictionary-based  

2.2.2 Impact

A malicious user, or remote attacker, who is able to connect to an administrative service will be able to perform a dictionary-based attack in order to identify valid authentication credentials and logon to the device. The attacker will then be able to perform administrative and user level tasks. This could include re-configuring the device, extracting potentially sensitive information and disabling the device. Once an attacker has obtained the configuration from the device they may be able to identify authentication credentials that could then be used to gain access to other network devices.

2.2.3 Ease

Dictionary-based password guessing attacks have been widely documented on the Internet and published media, enabling an attacker with very little knowledge or experience to perform the attack. There are a number of different dictionary-based password guessing tools and password dictionaries available on the Internet. Additionally an experienced attacker is likely to have a collection of personal password dictionaries which they have built up over time. However, there are a number of factors that may discourage an attacker from performing a dictionary-based attack.

  1. Account lockout facilities can quickly prevent access to the account.
  2. Device protection mechanisms may slow or disconnect connections where multiple authentication attempts are made in a short period of time.
  3. Brute-forcing can be very time consuming, especially if the password is long or made up of various character types.
  4. Network administrators may be alerted to locked out accounts or authentication attempts.

2.2.4 Recommendation

Nipper strongly recommends that all user accounts should have strong passwords. If the user accounts are not being used then Nipper recommends that they should be either removed or disabled.

Nipper recommends that:

  • user passwords should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the user password should not be repeated more than three times;
  • user passwords should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • user passwords should include numbers;
  • user passwords should include punctuation characters;
  • user passwords should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • user passwords should not be based on dictionary words.

2.2.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following commands can be used on Cisco IOS devices to set the enable password, create a local user with a password and to delete a local user:

enable secret <password>
username <user> secret <password>
no username <user>

2.2.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0005
  • Classification: Authentication

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Enable Password Configured (see section 2.5);
  • Users Configured With Cisco Type 7 Password Hashing Algorithm (see section 2.32).

2.3 Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.3.1 Finding

Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. Access to the SNMP Management Information Base (MIB) with protocol versions 1 and 2 is restricted using a community string to help prevent unauthorized access.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if usable default SNMP community strings were configured.

2.3.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified two default SNMP community strings configured on router03.nipper.org. These default SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 16: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version View ACL IPv6 ACL
public Read Only 1   20  
private Read/Write 1      

2.3.2 Impact

With read access to the SNMP MIB an attacker would be able to enumerate a large quantity of information about the device, its configuration, network details and more. The attacker could then use this information as part of a targeted attack.

2.3.3 Ease

Default SNMP community strings are usually documented in the manufacturers manuals, on third-party Internet web sites and in the password dictionaries of testing tools. Furthermore, SNMP query tools are installed by default on some operating systems and other SNMP tools can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.3.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. If SNMP is required then Nipper recommends that only SNMP version 3 should be configured. If access using SNMP community strings is required, Nipper recommends that only strong community strings should be chosen that are also not used for any other authentication.

Nipper recommends that:

  • SNMP community strings should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the SNMP community string should not be repeated more than three times;
  • SNMP community strings should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • SNMP community strings should include numbers;
  • SNMP community strings should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • SNMP community strings should not be based on dictionary words.

2.3.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

SNMP can be disabled with the following command:

no snmp-server

A SNMP community string can be configured with the following command:

snmp-server community <community-string> [view <view-name>] [ro | rw] [<acl-number>]

2.3.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

There are 2 options to mitigate this issue on router03.nipper.org, you only need to choose one. The remediation options are described in the recommended order of preference, so the first option is the recommended option.

Option 1: The following will disable the clear-text SNMP V1/2c service on the device. (Risk Level - Low)

no snmp-server

Option 2: The following will set new SNMP V1/2c community strings. This will replace any configured default or weak community strings. (Risk Level - Low)

no snmp-server community public
snmp-server community 9qIl3ck4KfpqmAvR ro 20
no snmp-server community private
snmp-server community kkQwdjmQmLUWjkPh rw

2.3.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0002
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.4 Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.4.1 Finding

The Telnet protocol (described in RFC 15 and RFC 854) is a clear-text protocol that is widely used to provide command-based access to systems and applications. Telnet is a simple protocol that was one of the first TCP/IP protocols to be developed, before security features were given a greater importance. Many modern network devices still provide a Telnet service for remote administrative purposes alongside the more secure Secure Shell (SSH) service.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the Telnet service had been disabled.

2.4.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the Telnet service was enabled on router03.nipper.org. The Telnet service is configured on administrative lines on Cisco Router 1841 devices. The following Table describes those lines.

Table 17: Telnet administrative line on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Level Password Telnet SSH Filter In Filter Out
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password Yes Yes 40  

2.4.2 Impact

Due to the lack of encryption provided by the Telnet protocol, an attacker who is able to monitor a Telnet session would be able to view all of the authentication credentials and data passed in the session. The attacker could then attempt to gain access to the device using the authentication credentials extracted from the session and potentially gain access under the context of that user. Since Telnet is commonly used for network device administration this could gain the attacker an administrative level of access.

2.4.3 Ease

To exploit the fact that the Telnet protocol does not provide any encryption, the attacker would need to be able to monitor the Telnet session between a Telnet server and client. In some situations the attacker may not need to perform any further action other than launching a network monitoring tool. However, in a switched network the attacker may need to perform additional actions such as an Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) attack and in a routed environment the attacker may have to compromise the network routing.

Tools that are capable of both monitoring and displaying network traffic in an easy to read form can be downloaded from the Internet. There are also tools that automatically detect where authentication credentials or files are being transferred and display or save the data. Tools are also available that enable an attacker to easily perform a variety of network attacks in order to be able to monitor and intercept sessions between two network devices.

2.4.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the Telnet service should be disabled. If remote administrative access is required then Nipper recommends that a cryptographically secure alternative, such as SSH, should be used instead. If Telnet has to be used then Nipper recommends that network filtering should be employed to restrict access to the service from only those specific devices that need the access.

2.4.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Telnet must be disabled on Cisco IOS devices for each transport line that the service is enabled. If supported, the SSH protocol can also be enabled using the same command. This can be configured using the following command:

transport input [none | ssh]

2.4.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the clear-text Telnet administrative service. It is worth noting that this can prevent remote command-based access to the device if Telnet is your only access service. (Risk Level - Moderate)

line vty 0 4
transport input ssh
exit

2.4.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0036
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 15, RFC 854
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telnet

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Administration Line With Weak Inbound ACL Host Restrictions (see section 2.42).

2.5 Enable Password Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.5.1 Finding

Cisco Internet Operating System (IOS)-based devices enable passwords can be stored using MD5 hashes or using the Cisco Type 7 password encoding algorithm. A strong password stored using an MD5 hash can take a significant period of time to brute-force. However, the same password stored in Cisco Type 7 form can be reversed in a fraction of a second. The MD5 enable user password hash can be created using the secret keyword, whilst the Cisco Type 7 hash is created using the password keyword.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the enable (password) user was configured.

2.5.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper idenfied the user enable (password) configured on router03.nipper.org. The enable (password) user account is described in the following table:

Table 18: enable (password) user
User Password Privilege Filter Logon Attempt Limit Policy
enable (password) cisco 15   None  

2.5.2 Impact

An attacker could use an enable password from a Cisco device to gain administrative level access to the device and modify its configuration. It is important to note, that Nipper found that the "enable secret" method had also been used within the configuration, which would override the "enable password" setting.

2.5.3 Ease

An attacker who had access to the Cisco configuration file would easily be able to retrieve passwords that are stored in clear-text or using the Cisco type-7 encryption. However, an attacker who had access to a Cisco configuration file could attempt a brute-force attack against the stronger MD5 hashes. Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are capable of reversing Cisco Type 7 passwords. However, an attacker would need to obtain a copy of the configuration file and would need to be able to gain initial access to the device before they could make use of an enable password.

Notes

cheese

2.5.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all enable passwords should be stored using the MD5 hash. The following command can be used to remove the Cisco Type 7 enable password:

no enable password

Because Nipper found that the "enable secret" method was in use, the password provided using "enable password" would not be used. However, it is still recommended to remove Cisco Type 7 enable passwords from the device.

MD5 enable passwords can be configured using the following command:

enable secret [level <password>] <password>

2.5.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0006
  • Classification: Authentication

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (see section 2.2);
  • Users Configured With Cisco Type 7 Password Hashing Algorithm (see section 2.32).

2.6 No Inbound TCP Connection Keep-Alives

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.6.1 Finding

The keep-alive messages are used to determine if a connection is active or has become orphaned and is no longer used. Depending on the result, the device can reclaim resources allocated to inbound connections that have become orphaned. Connections to a device could become orphaned if a connection becomes disrupted or if the client has not properly terminated a connection.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if inbound TCP keep alive messages were enabled.

2.6.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that inbound TCP keep alive messages were disabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.6.2 Impact

An attacker could attempt a DoS attack against a device by exhausting the number of possible connections. To perform this attack, the attacker could keep requesting new connections to the device and spoof the source IP addresses. This would then prevent any new legitimate connections to the device from being made as the device awaits the completion of the connection attempts that have already been initiated. This attack would prevent both users and administrators from connecting to the device.

2.6.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are capable of opening a large number of TCP connections without correctly terminating them.

2.6.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that TCP keep alive messages should be sent to detect and drop orphaned connections from remote systems.

2.6.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Keep-alive messages can be sent for inbound TCP connections to Cisco IOS devices with the following command:

service tcp-keepalives-in

2.6.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0006
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keepalive

2.7 BGP Neighbors With No Authentication

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.7.1 Finding

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes to the network topology. Routing neighbors are configured to define which BGP hosts the routing updates will be sent to. MD5 authentication can be configured for each neighbor to ensure that BGP routing updates are sent from a trusted source.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all BGP neighbors were configured to authenticate.

2.7.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following BGP neighbors on router03.nipper.org that were not configured to authenticate.

Table 19: BGP ASN 1 Neighbor ASN 12345
Description Value
Description Site to Site Connection
Address 192.168.0.11
ASN 12345
Version 4
Authentication None
Route Weight Default
Route Map In  
Route Map Out  
Prefix List In  
Prefix List Out FILTER_CORE_PREFIXES
Maximum Prefixes No Limit
Maximum Hops (TTL Security) 12
Update Source Loopback0

2.7.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a BGP routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.7.3 Ease

There are multiple methods an attacker could use to identify potentially vulnerable BGP routers, such as by monitoring network traffic to identify routers and examine their routing updates. With no authentication configured, an attacker would not have to determine the authentication key prior to sending malicious BGP route updates

An attacker would have to be able to create their own malicious routing updates to exploit this issue. To do this they could configure their own router, using either Open Source routing software or their use their own physical router. The following are examples of the Open Source software that could be used by the attacker to interact with the routing protocol:

  • Quagga (www.nongnu.org/quagga);
  • Bird (bird.network.cz).

2.7.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that strong encrypted authentication passwords should be configured for all BGP routing updates. Although it could be possible for an attacker to extract the encrypted password authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the password, it would take the significantly more time and effort.

Nipper recommends that:

  • BGP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the BGP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • BGP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • BGP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • BGP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • BGP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • BGP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.7.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

BGP neighbor authentication passwords can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following router command:

neighbor {<address> | <group>} password <password>

2.7.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0003
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1105, RFC 1654, RFC 2283, RFC 4271
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Border_Gateway_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.8 No RIP Authentication

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.8.1 Finding

Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. There are three main versions of RIP; version 1, 2 and NG. Version 2 of RIP supports authentication using either clear-text or MD5 authentication methods. This ensures that routing updates were sent from a trusted source.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all RIP routing interfaces were configured to provide authentication.

2.8.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following RIP routing configuration, applied to network interfaces, on router03.nipper.org:

Table 20: RIP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active Passive Send Receive Auth Key ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes No V1 V1 and V2 Clear Text routing-chain
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes No V2 V1 and V2 None N/A

2.8.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.8.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that could be used to send malicious RIP routing updates. With no authentication configured, an attacker would not have to determine the authentication key prior to sending malicious RIP route updates.

2.8.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that strong authentication keys should be configured for all RIP routing updates with RIP version 2 MD5 authentication.

Nipper recommends that:

  • RIP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the RIP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • RIP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • RIP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • RIP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • RIP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • RIP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.8.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

RIP update authentication is configured on Cisco IOS devices by configuring a key chain with a strong authentication key, then applying it to individual interfaces. A key chain and key can be created using the following commands:

key chain <chain-name>
 key <key-number>
 key-string <authentication-string>

The authentication keys can be applied to individual interfaces with the following commands:

ip rip authentication key-chain <chain-name>
ip rip authentication mode md5

2.8.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0036
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.23);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.39);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.9 Low GLBP Group Priorities

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.9.1 Finding

Gateway Load Balancing Protocol (GLBP) is a Cisco proprietary protocol which is used for router load balancing and redundancy. A priority is configured to determine which GLBP enabled router will become the Active Virtual Gateway (AVG) and respond to ARP requests on behalf of the Active Virtual Forwarders (AVFs). The router with the highest priority will become the AVG.

Nipper examined the device configuration GLBP routing to determine that the priority had been set to 255.

2.9.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following GLBP routing configuration on router03.nipper.org with a priority not equal to 255:

Table 21: GLBP with a weak priority
Interface Active Group Name Address Priority Weighting Auth Key Chain/ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 44   192.168.8.42 100 100 Clear Text 1
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes 40   192.168.7.42 100 100 None N/A

2.9.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure GLBP with the relevant authentication configuration, could configure a higher priority in order to become the AVG. If an attacker is able to become the GLBP AVG, they would be able to control network routing in order to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.9.3 Ease

There are multiple methods an attacker could use to identify potentially vulnerable GLBP routers, such as by monitoring network traffic to identify routers and their priority. The attacker could extract the authentication key hashes from the monitored network traffic and then use password cracking tools to determine the unencrypted authentication key. Weak authentication keys will take far less time to break than strong authentication keys.

An attacker would have to be able to create their own malicious routing updates to exploit this issue. To do this they could configure their own router, using either Open Source routing software or their use their own physical router. They would configure their router with a higher GLBP priority to become the AVG. The following are examples of the Open Source software that could be used by the attacker to interact with the routing protocol:

  • Quagga (www.nongnu.org/quagga);
  • Bird (bird.network.cz).

2.9.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the GLBP group priority of 255 should be configured. If two or more routers are present, Nipper recommends that each of the routers should be configured with high numbered priorities.

2.9.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

GLBP priorities can be configured with the following Cisco IOS interface command:

glbp <group> priority <priority>

2.9.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0013
  • Classification: Routing
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_Load_Balancing_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.10);
  • Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.24);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.10 Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.10.1 Finding

GLBP is a Cisco proprietary protocol used to provide router load balancing and redundancy against a single point of failure. GLBP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication is configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all GLBP routing interfaces were configured to provide authentication.

2.10.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following GLBP routing configuration, applied to network interfaces, on router03.nipper.org:

Table 22: GLBP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active Group Name Address Priority Weighting Auth Key Chain/ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 44   192.168.8.42 100 100 Clear Text 1
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes 40   192.168.7.42 100 100 None N/A

2.10.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure their router with the relevant GLBP group configuration would be able to participate in network routing in order to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.10.3 Ease

An attacker could use a GLBP capable device in order to perform the attack. The attacker could then configure their GLBP capable router to be in the same group and with a higher priority in order to become the AVG.

2.10.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all GLBP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if no authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • GLBP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the GLBP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • GLBP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • GLBP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.10.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 GLBP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

glbp [<group>] authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.10.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0011
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_Load_Balancing_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low GLBP Group Priorities (see section 2.9);
  • Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.24);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.11 Low HSRP Group Priorities

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.11.1 Finding

Hot Standby Routing Protocol (HSRP) is a Cisco proprietary protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. Multiple routers can be configured in a HSRP group in a master and backup router configuration. The master router is determined by an election where the router with the highest priority will become the master. Router priorities can be between 1 and 255.

Nipper examined the device configuration HSRP routing to determine that the priority had been set to 255.

2.11.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following HSRP routing configuration on router03.nipper.org with a priority not equal to 255:

Table 23: HSRP with a weak priority
Interface Active Name Number Version Address MAC Priority Auth Key Chain/ID SSO
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes   0 2 192.168.5.10   100 Clear Text 1 Yes
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes   20 1 192.168.5.20   100 None N/A Yes

2.11.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure HSRP with the relevant authentication configuration, could configure a higher priority and force a router election in order to become the master router. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.11.3 Ease

To perform this attack, the attacker would first have to determine the existing HSRP configuration. If authentication credentials are used, the attacker could extract them from the captured network packets. With MD5-based authentication, the attacker would have use a dictionary/brute-force attack in order to determine the authentication key. Additionally, the attacker would require access to a network segment where they could participate in HSRP routing. The attacker could then configure their router with a higher priority in order to perform the attack. All of the software required to complete each of these components can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.11.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the HSRP priority of 255 should be configured. If two or more routers are present, Nipper recommends that each of the routers should be configured with high numbered priorities.

2.11.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

HSRP priorities can be configured with the following Cisco IOS interface command:

standby <group> priority <priority>

2.11.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0019
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2281
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_Standby_Router_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.12);
  • Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.25);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.12 Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.12.1 Finding

HSRP is a Cisco proprietary protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. HSRP version 1 is described in RFC 2281.

HSRP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication can be configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all HSRP routing interfaces were configured to provide authentication.

2.12.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following HSRP routing configuration, applied to network interfaces, on router03.nipper.org:

Table 24: HSRP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active Name Number Version Address MAC Priority Auth Key Chain/ID SSO
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes   0 2 192.168.5.10   100 Clear Text 1 Yes
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes   20 1 192.168.5.20   100 None N/A Yes

2.12.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to join a HSRP routing group and become the master router. If an attacker is able to become a router, they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.12.3 Ease

An attacker could use a HSRP capable device, or download HSRP software from the Internet. The attacker could then configure their HSRP to be in the same group and with a higher priority in order to become the master during an election.

2.12.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all HSRP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if no authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • HSRP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the HSRP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • HSRP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • HSRP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.12.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 HSRP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

standby [<group>] authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.12.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0017
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2281
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_Standby_Router_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low HSRP Group Priorities (see section 2.11);
  • Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.25);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.13 Low VRRP Priorities

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.13.1 Finding

Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) is an industry standard protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. Multiple routers can be configured in a VRRP group in a master and backup router configuration. The master router is determined by an election where the router with the highest priority will become the master. Router priorities can be between 1 and 254. VRRP is described in more detail in RFC 5798.

Nipper examined the device configuration VRRP routing to determine that the priority had been set to 255.

2.13.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following VRRP routing configuration on router03.nipper.org with a priority not equal to 255:

Table 25: VRRP with a weak priority
Interface Active VRRP Address Description Priority Auth Key Chain/ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 2 192.168.4.2   100 Clear Text 1
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes 3 192.168.3.2   100 None N/A

2.13.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure VRRP with the relevant authentication configuration, could configure a higher priority and force a router election in order to become the master router. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.13.3 Ease

To perform this attack, the attacker would first have to determine the existing VRRP configuration. If authentication credentials are used, the attacker could extract them from the captured network packets. With MD5-based authentication, the attacker would have use a dictionary/brute-force attack in order to determine the authentication key. Additionally, the attacker would require access to a network segment where they could participate in VRRP routing. The attacker could then configure their router with a higher priority in order to perform the attack. All of the software required to complete each of these components can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.13.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the VRRP priority of 254 should be configured. If two or more routers are present, Nipper recommends that each of the routers should be configured with high numbered priorities.

2.13.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

VRRP priorities can be configured with the following Cisco IOS interface command:

vrrp <group> priority <priority>

2.13.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0046
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 5798
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Router_Redundancy_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (see section 2.14);
  • Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (see section 2.26);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.14 Not All VRRP Were Authenticated

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.14.1 Finding

ABBREV*VRRP*-ABBREV* is an industry standard protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. VRRP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication is configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router. VRRP is described in more detail in RFC 5798.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all VRRP routing interfaces were configured to provide authentication.

2.14.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following VRRP routing configuration, applied to network interfaces, on router03.nipper.org:

Table 26: VRRP authentication on interfaces
Interface Active VRRP Address Description Priority Auth Key Chain/ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 2 192.168.4.2   100 Clear Text 1
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes 3 192.168.3.2   100 None N/A

2.14.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to join a VRRP routing group and become the master router. If an attacker is able to become a router, they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.14.3 Ease

An attacker could use a VRRP capable device, or download VRRP software from the Internet. The attacker could then configure their VRRP to be in the same group and with a higher priority in order to become the master during an election.

2.14.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all VRRP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if no authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • VRRP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the VRRP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • VRRP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • VRRP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.14.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 VRRP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

vrrp <group> authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.14.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0044
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 5798
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Router_Redundancy_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low VRRP Priorities (see section 2.13);
  • Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (see section 2.26);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.15 Clear-Text SNMP In Use

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.15.1 Finding

SNMP is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. With write access to SNMP, it is possible to re-configure networking, system properties and even shutdown a device.

There are multiple versions of SNMP and versions prior to version 3 offer no encryption of either the authentication or data network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if clear-text SNMP was configured on the device. This includes sending and receiving data for both SNMP versions 1 and 2c.

2.15.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified two SNMP community strings on router03.nipper.org. Those SNMP community string are described in the following table:

Table 27: SNMP Community Strings
Community Access Version View ACL IPv6 ACL
public Read Only 1   20  
private Read/Write 1      

Nipper determined that no SNMP hosts were configured on router03.nipper.org.

2.15.2 Impact

An attacker or malicious user who can monitor the unencrypted SNMP network traffic would capture the SNMP community string used to authenticate access to the SNMP agent service. Additionally, they would capture all the information transferred using the unencrypted connection.

Nipper determined that SNMP write access was configured. With write access to SNMP an attacker could modify a device's settings and potentially cause a network-wide DoS condition.

2.15.3 Ease

Network packet capture tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can allow an attacker to monitor the network traffic. In a modern network environment, switches are typically deployed to connect the network infrastructure devices rather than hubs. With network switch devices, the attacker should only be able to see broadcast network traffic or traffic sent directly to or from the attacker's host. However, a skilled attacker could bypass this restriction by performing an attack such as ARP spoofing or exploiting a vulnerability with the network routing. Tools for bypassing a network switching environment's restrictions can be downloaded from the Internet.

It is worth noting that with no SNMP view configured, the attacker would not be restricted to a specified subset of the SNMP MIB.

2.15.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. However, if SNMP access is required, Nipper recommends that only SNMP version 3 should be configured with strong authentication and privacy passwords.

2.15.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

SNMP can be disabled with the following command:

no snmp-server

SNMP version 3 is configured by creating a group and then by adding users to the group. The following commands can be used to create a group and add a user to it:

snmp-server group <group-name> v3 {noauth | auth | priv} [read <read-view>] [write <write-view>] [notify <notify-view>] [access <acl>]
snmp-server user <username> <group-name> v3 [auth {md5 | sha} <auth-password>] [access <acl>]

2.15.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the clear-text SNMP V1/2c service on the device. (Risk Level - Low)

no snmp-server

2.15.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0001
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.16 SNMP Write Access Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: High
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.16.1 Finding

SNMP is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. With write access to SNMP it can be possible to re-configure networking, system properties and even shutdown a device.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if usable SNMP community strings were configured.

2.16.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one SNMP community string with read/write access on router03.nipper.org. This SNMP community string is described in the following table:

Table 28: SNMP Community Write Access Strings
Community Access Version View ACL IPv6 ACL
private Read/Write 1      

2.16.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with a write access SNMP community string could modify the configuration of the device and in some circumstances cause the device to reboot. It is also worth noting that SNMP write access could enable an attacker to extract the full configuration from the device.

2.16.3 Ease

An attacker who wanted to modify a device's configuration using SNMP would require a tool that could write to the SNMP MIB and a community string with write access. SNMP tools that can write to a SNMP MIB can be downloaded from the Internet and some Operating System (OS) install them by default.

2.16.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. If SNMP is required, then Nipper recommends that, if write access is not required, then read-only access should be configured instead of allowing write access.

2.16.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Read only SNMP community strings can be configured with the following command:

snmp-server community <community-string> [view <view-name>] ro [<acl-number>]

2.16.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0024
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

It is worth noting that this issue could be mitigated by fixing the following:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15).

2.17 SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.17.1 Finding

SSH is typically used as a cryptographically secure alternative to Telnet and other clear-text protocols. In addition to command-based access, SSH services can enable the forwarding of network ports (such as X forwarding) or the transfer of files (such as Secure Copy (SCP) or Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP)).

There are two main versions of the SSH protocol, version 1 and 2. Version 2 was developed to both extend the functionality of the protocol and to enhance security. It is common for SSH servers that support both versions of the protocol to be capable of being configured to support connections from clients using different versions of the protocol in order to maintain backward compatibility.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the SSH service had been configured to only accept connections using version 2 of the protocol.

2.17.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on router03.nipper.org.

2.17.2 Impact

Although flaws have been identified with SSH protocol version 2, fundamental flaws exist in protocol version 1. Table 29 details some of the vulnerabilities identified in SSH protocol version 1.

Table 29: Known SSH protocol version 1 vulnerabilities
Description CVE CERT
CBC or CFB vulnerability allowing a remote attacker to insert data (and commands) in to an existing SSH session. CVE-1999-1085 VU#13877
A CRC overflow error could enable remote attackers to write to arbitrary locations in a device's memory. CVE-2001-0144 VU#945216
A client authentication forwarding flaw in the protocol could enable a remote attacker to perform a man in the middle attack.   VU#684820
It is possible for an attacker to modify the last block of an SSH connection that is using the IDEA cipher.   VU#315308

2.17.3 Ease

Although a number of vulnerabilities in SSH protocol version 1 are widely known they can be difficult to exploit and some require very specific configurations to also exist. It is more likely that unless the attacker highly motivated and experienced they will seek an alternative weakness to exploit rather than attempting to exploit vulnerabilities with the SSH protocol.

2.17.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the SSH service should be reconfigured to only support version 2 of the protocol.

2.17.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Depending on your device model and IOS version you may have to perform an upgrade for your device to support SSH protocol version 2. When you configure support for SSH protocol version 2, support for version 1 will be disabled. This can be configured using the following command:

ip ssh version 2

2.17.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will configure the SSH service to support only V2 of the protocol, removing access using the weaker SSH V1 protocol. (Risk Level - Low)

ip ssh version 2

2.17.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0033
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 4250, RFC 4251, RFC 4252, RFC 4253, RFC 4254, RFC 4255, RFC 4256
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_(Secure_Shell)

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Administration Line With Weak Inbound ACL Host Restrictions (see section 2.42).

2.18 RADIUS Servers With No Shared Secret

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.18.1 Finding

A Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) server provides Authentication, Authorization and Accounting (AAA) services for network connected devices such as switches and routers. Authentication requests are sent to the RADIUS server and a access response is returned to the device. A RADIUS shared secret can be configured to encrypt the traffic between the service and requesting device. RADIUS is detailed in RFC 2138.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all the RADIUS servers were configured with a shared secret.

2.18.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 30: RADIUS server with no shared secret
Server Group Address Port Secret
  1.2.3.4 1645  

2.18.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to monitor the network traffic between the RADIUS server and the device could potentially extract authentication credentials from the traffic. The attacker could then use the authentication credentials in order to gain a level of access to a number of network devices.

2.18.3 Ease

A skilled attacker could make use of open source code in order to help decrypt any captured network traffic.

2.18.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a strong RADIUS shared secret should be configured to encrypt the network packets between the RADIUS server and client devices. The shared secret will have to be configured on the RADIUS server and client(s).

Nipper recommends that:

  • RADIUS shared secrets should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the RADIUS shared secret should not be repeated more than three times;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include numbers;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include punctuation characters;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should not be based on dictionary words.

2.18.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0015
  • Classification: Authentication, Clear Text
  • RFCs: RFC 2865, RFC 2866
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RADIUS

The following findings are related to this one:

  • RADIUS Servers With A Dictionary-Based Shared Secret (see section 2.33).

2.19 Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.19.1 Finding

The Host and Service Black List specifies traffic that should not be allowed through the network device. Entries in this black list might typically be internal resources containing highly sensitive or confidential information or external resources that may pose a threat to the network.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following blacklist host services:

  • Service http on host 212.241.243.218.

2.19.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 3.

The filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 31: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rules 1 and 2.

The filter list "named-acl-2" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 32: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 6.

The filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 33: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
