35 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
36 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
37 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
38 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
39 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
40 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
41 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rule 1.

The filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 34: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper determined that filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to blacklist service http (TCP port 80) on host 212.241.243.218 in filter rules 1 and 2.

The filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 35: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
4 192.168.20.10 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
5 192.168.20.12 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
6 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
8 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

2.19.2 Impact

Violating the Host and Service Black List could provide an attacker with a range of vulnerabilities to exploit. If the blacklisted resource is internal and sensitive, an attacker may have access to confidential and private information. If it is an external resource, an attacker may be able to introduce some other vulnerabilities into the network.

2.19.3 Ease

Access to the hosts and services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.19.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that firewall Access control lists are configured in a manner that does not violate specified Host and Service Black Lists.

2.19.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an Access Control Entry (ACE) the Access Control List (ACL) would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.19.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0008
  • Classification: Filtering

2.20 Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.20.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow from any address.

2.20.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 36: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 37: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified four rules in filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from any address. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 38: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
6 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from any address. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 39: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.20.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.20.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.20.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.20.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.20.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0018
  • Classification: Filtering

2.21 Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.21.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to any address.

2.21.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 40: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "named-acl-2" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 41: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 42: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
15 10.1.23.1 Any IPv4 UDP from port 67 to port 67 Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 43: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified three rules in filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 44: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 45: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No

2.21.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.21.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.21.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.21.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.21.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0021
  • Classification: Filtering

2.22 DTP Was Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.22.1 Finding

Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP) is a proprietary protocol developed by Cisco for the purpose of negotiating Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN) trunking between switches. When enabled the switch can dynamically negotiate trunking with an attached switch without requiring any manual configuration. Once the negotiation is successful, any Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) configured to trunk will then be transferred between the devices. If specific VLANs have not been specified then all VLANs will be transferred.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that DTP was not configured to automatically negotiate VLAN trunks on all network interfaces.

2.22.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to permit DTP auto-negotiation of VLAN trunks.

2.22.2 Impact

An attacker could attempt to negotiate a trunk with the device in order to gain access to all the VLANs configured for the trunk. This will enable an attacker to bypass any network filtering provided to restrict access between VLANs. For example, if a management network were to be available then the attacker will be able to connect to all the devices and services offered on that network as if they were attached to it directly.

2.22.3 Ease

Software to enable an attacker to negotiate a trunk is available on the Internet. Alternatively an attacker could make use of their own DTP capable network device.

2.22.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, DTP should be disabled. Nipper recommends that switch ports should be configured to either trunk or not and those ports where trunking is required should only be configured to trunk the required VLANs.

2.22.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Switch ports can be configured to either trunk or not and DTP negotiation disabled using the following interface commands:

switchport mode {access | trunk}
switchport nonegotiate

2.22.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0003
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Trunking_Protocol

2.23 RIP Version 1 Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.23.1 Finding

RIP is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. There are three main versions of RIP:

  • version 1 of the protocol, outlined in RFC 1058, supports simple routing updates with support only for classful routing and broadcast updates;
  • version 2 of the protocol, outlined in RFC 2453, added support for CIDR, authentication (both in clear-text and MD5 forms) and multicast updates;
  • NG, outlined in RFC 2080, adds support for IPv6 but does not include support for authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that sending or receiving RIP version 1 was not configured.

2.23.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that sending or receiving RIP version 1 was configured on router03.nipper.org.

Table 46: RIP network interface configurations allowing version 1
Interface Active Passive Send Receive Auth Key ID
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes No V1 V1 and V2 Clear Text routing-chain
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes No V2 V1 and V2 None N/A

2.23.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

Another issue with RIP version 1, though not necessarily a security one, is that broadcast updates can wake up computers that are shutdown on the Local Area Network (LAN).

2.23.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to send malicious RIP routing updates. With RIP version 1 supported, the attacker would not need to provide authentication information.

2.23.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if RIP is required, only support for version 2 should be configured. However, this may require a firmware update if the device does not support version 2.

2.23.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Support for only RIP version 2 updates can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following router configuration command:

version 2

Additionally, RIP version 2 support can be configured on individual interfaces with the following interface commands:

ip rip send version 2
ip rip receive version 2

2.23.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0040
  • Classification: Authentication, Clear-Text, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.8);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.39);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.24 Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.24.1 Finding

GLBP is a Cisco proprietary protocol used to provide router load balancing and redundancy against a single point of failure. GLBP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication is configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that GLBP was configured to not use weak authentication keys.

2.24.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one weak GLBP authentication key configured on router03.nipper.org. This authentication key is detailed in the table below.

Table 47: GLBP weak authentication keys
Key ID Authentication Key Key Strength
1 Passw0rd Too short

2.24.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure their router with the relevant GLBP group configuration would be able to participate in network routing in order to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.24.3 Ease

For a clear-text GLBP group authentication, the attacker could monitor the network traffic in order to gain the GLBP group authentication key. For MD5 authentication, an attacker could perform a brute-force attack. This can be achieved using software downloaded from the Internet.

An attacker could use a GLBP capable device in the attack. The attacker could then configure their GLBP capable router, with the authentication key, in order to become a network router.

2.24.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all GLBP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if clear-text authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • GLBP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the GLBP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • GLBP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • GLBP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • GLBP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.24.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 GLBP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

glbp [<group>] authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.24.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0012
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_Load_Balancing_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low GLBP Group Priorities (see section 2.9);
  • Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.10);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.25 Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.25.1 Finding

HSRP is a Cisco proprietary protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. HSRP version 1 is described in RFC 2281.

HSRP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication can be configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that HSRP was configured to not use weak authentication keys.

2.25.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one weak HSRP authentication key configured on router03.nipper.org. This authentication key is detailed in the table below.

Table 48: HSRP weak authentication keys
Key ID Authentication Key Key Strength
1 Passw0rd Too short

2.25.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to join a HSRP routing group and become the master router. If an attacker is able to become a router, they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.25.3 Ease

For a clear-text HSRP group authentication, the attacker could monitor the network traffic in order to gain the HSRP group authentication key. For MD5 authentication, an attacker could perform a brute force attack. This can be achieved using software downloaded from the Internet.

An attacker could use a HSRP capable device, or download HSRP software from the Internet. The attacker could then configure their HSRP to be in the same group and with a higher priority in order to become the master during an election. The authentication key (or shared secret) can be configured using the HSRP group authentication key.

2.25.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all HSRP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if clear-text authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • HSRP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the HSRP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • HSRP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • HSRP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • HSRP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.25.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 HSRP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

standby [<group>] authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.25.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0018
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2281
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_Standby_Router_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low HSRP Group Priorities (see section 2.11);
  • Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.12);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.26 Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.26.1 Finding

ABBREV*VRRP*-ABBREV* is an industry standard protocol used to provide router redundancy against a single point of failure. VRRP routers are configured in a group which can be authenticated using either clear-text or MD5 authentication. Authentication is configured to ensure that routing will not be performed by an untrusted router. VRRP is described in more detail in RFC 5798.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that VRRP was configured to not use dictionary-based authentication keys.

2.26.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one dictionary-based VRRP authentication key configured on router03.nipper.org. This authentication key is detailed in the table below.

Table 49: VRRP dictionary-based authentication keys
Key ID Authentication Key Key Strength
1 password Dictionary-based

2.26.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to join a VRRP routing group and become the master router. If an attacker is able to become a router, they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.26.3 Ease

For a clear-text VRRP group authentication, the attacker could monitor the network traffic in order to gain the VRRP group authentication key. For MD5 authentication, an attacker could perform a dictionary-based attack. This can be achieved using software downloaded from the Internet.

An attacker could use a VRRP capable device, or download VRRP software from the Internet. The attacker could then configure their VRRP to be in the same group and with a higher priority in order to become the master during an election. The authentication key (or shared secret) can be configured using the VRRP group authentication key.

2.26.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that MD5 authentication with a strong key should be configured for all VRRP groups. Although it may be possible for an attacker to extract the MD5 authentication hash from a network packet and brute-force the authentication key, it would take significantly more effort than would be required if clear-text authentication were to be configured.

Nipper recommends that:

  • VRRP authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the VRRP authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include numbers;
  • VRRP authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • VRRP authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • VRRP authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.26.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

MD5 VRRP group authentication can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

vrrp <group> authentication md5 {key-string <key> | key-chain <key-chain>}

2.26.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0043
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 5798
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Router_Redundancy_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Low VRRP Priorities (see section 2.13);
  • Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (see section 2.14);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.27 Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.27.1 Finding

Routers and routing devices can be configured to send route updates to each other. This enables devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network topology and enables router devices to make informed decisions when routing network traffic between networks. Authentication keys, sometimes referred to as shared secrets, can be configured for routing protocols. The routing protocol authentication keys are configured to ensure that any routing updates sent to the device that will update the device's routing information were only sent from trusted sources.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all routing keychain keys were not dictionary-based.

2.27.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified two dictionary-based routing keychain keys configured on router03.nipper.org. Those routing keychain keys are detailed in the table below.

Table 50: Dictionary-based routing keychain keys
Keychain Key ID Key Algo Accept Life Send Life Key Strength
testchain 1 password None     Dictionary-based
routing-chain 1 cisco None     Dictionary-based

2.27.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.27.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to send malicious routing updates. With a simple dictionary-based authentication key configured, it would not be time consuming for an attacker to determine the authentication key. The attacker could then send routing updates that appear to be authentic and the source address can be spoofed.

2.27.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that strong routing protocol authentication keys should be configured for all routing updates.

Nipper recommends that:

  • Routing authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the Routing authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • Routing authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • Routing authentication keys should include numbers;
  • Routing authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • Routing authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • Routing authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.27.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Authentication key chains and keys can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following commands:

key chain <chain-name>
 key <key-number>
 key-string <authentication-string>

2.27.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0022
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing

The following findings are related to this one:

  • BGP Neighbors With No Authentication (see section 2.7);
  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.8);
  • Low GLBP Group Priorities (see section 2.9);
  • Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.10);
  • Low HSRP Group Priorities (see section 2.11);
  • Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.12);
  • Low VRRP Priorities (see section 2.13);
  • Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (see section 2.14);
  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.23);
  • Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.24);
  • Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.25);
  • Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (see section 2.26);
  • Low OSPF Priorities (see section 2.38);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.39);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40);
  • No OSPF LSA Thresholds (see section 2.46).

2.28 SNMP System Shutdown Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.28.1 Finding

A SNMP system shutdown facility can be configured for some SNMP agents so that network administrators can remotely reset the devices using SNMP.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the option to allow a device to be shutdown via SNMP was disabled.

2.28.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the option to enable the system to be shutdown via SNMP was enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.28.2 Impact

An attacker who had SNMP write access could cause a DoS condition by causing the device to shutdown.

2.28.3 Ease

For an attacker to exploit this issue they would require SNMP query tools and a community string with write access to the SNMP MIB. SNMP query tools can be downloaded from the Internet and some OS install them by default. If the attacker does not know the community string it may be possible to determine it by monitoring the network traffic or by brute-forcing the community string.

2.28.4 Recommendation

Generally the SNMP system shutdown facility is not saved to the configuration file and should not persist following a system shutdown. Nipper recommends that the SNMP system shutdown facility should be disabled.

2.28.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following Cisco IOS device command can be used to disable the SNMP shutdown facility:

no snmp-server system-shutdown

2.28.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0009
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.29 AUX Port Not Disabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.29.1 Finding

The Auxilary (AUX) port's primary purpose is to provide a remote administration capability. With a modem connected to the AUX port, a remote administrator could dial into the device in order to perform remote administration. As an extra layer of security, some devices can be configured with a callback facility. The callback facility, if configured, drops any incoming calls and dials the network administrator back.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the AUX port had been disabled. However, it is worth noting that not all device models have an AUX port, therefore its status can be falsely determined.

2.29.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

On Cisco Router 1841 devices the AUX port is configured using administrative lines. Nipper determined that the AUX port was configured as follows on router03.nipper.org.

Table 51: AUX port administration lines on
Line Access Login Exec Timeout Absolute Timeout Session Timeout Login Timeout Session Limit Filter In Filter Out Callback
Auxiliary Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 10 minutes None 25 minutes 30 seconds None N/A N/A No

2.29.2 Impact

If an attacker is able to dial in and connect to the device remotely using the AUX port, the attacker could perform a brute-force attack against the authentication mechanism in order to gain remote administrative access. If a malicious user was able to gain physical access to a device where the AUX port had not been disabled, they could attach a modem in order to perform an attack from a remote location. If a callback facility has not been configured, then the device would not drop incoming calls and attempt to dial the network administrators phone number.

2.29.3 Ease

In order to successfully exploit this issue, the attacker would require a modem to be attached to the AUX port. If a modem is already attached, an attacker could discover the modem's telephone number during a war-dial. However, even though a number of war dial tools are available on the Internet, a war dial is more likely to be discovered due to the number of telephones which would be called in an office.

2.29.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, the AUX port should be disabled. If the AUX port is required and the device supports callback then Nipper suggests that the callback facility should be configured as an additional level of protection.

2.29.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The auxiliary port can be disabled with the following IOS auxiliary line commands:

transport input none
login local
no exec

2.29.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will re-configure the AUX 0 port to prevent logins and command access from the devices auxilliary port. (Risk Level - Low)

line aux 0
transport input none
login local
no exec
exit

2.29.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0001
  • Classification: Administration

2.30 Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.30.1 Finding

HTTPS (RFC 2818) provides a cryptographically secure connection for web-based services, such as network device administration and other sensitive services. HTTPS is essentially HTTP (RFC 2616) over an Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)/Transport Layer Security (TLS) (RFC 2546) encrypted connection.

Depending on the implementation, HTTPS can support SSL protocol versions 2, 3, and TLS cryptographic protocols. However, SSL protocol version 2 is now considered to be obsolete and has since been replaced by more secure cryptographic protocols. SSL protocol version 3 has been revealed to contain a number of vulnerabilities, as has TLS v1.0. Additionally, encryption ciphers with key lengths of less than 128 bits are not considered to be as strong as those with higher key lengths.

For example, the significant flaws in the design of SSL version 2 that lead to the improvements in version 3 and TLS included:

  • message authentication and encryption keys were identical;
  • message authentication codes (MAC) relies on the flawed MD5 hashing algorithm;
  • lack of handshake protection;
  • sole reliance on TCP for session termination.

Vulnerabilities with SSL version 3 and TLS version 1.0 making them insecure include:

  • Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encryption (POODLE) - CVE-2014-3566;
  • Browser Exploit Against SSL/TLS (BEAST) - CVE-2011-3389.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the HTTPS encryption ciphers were SSLv1, SSLv2, SSLv3 and TLSv1 with a key length less than 128 bits.

2.30.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 52: Encryption ciphersuites
IANA Name Protocols Key Exchange Authentication Encryption Hash RFC
TLS_RSA_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA TLS v1
TLS v1.1		 RSA RSA DES 56bit CBC mode SHA-1 RFC 5469

2.30.2 Impact

Although HTTPS provides a significant security enhancement over using a clear-text connection, significant flaws have been identified in SSL versions 2, 3, as well as TLS version 1.0, and the shorter the cipher key length the less time is required to break the encryption. If an attacker is able to monitor or intercept a HTTPS connection that is using one of the weaker protocols or encryption ciphers they could potentially:

  • gain access to the decrypted data and authentication credentials;
  • perform a Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) attack by downgrading the connection;
  • perform a connection truncation attack;
  • perform a POODLE attack.

2.30.3 Ease

Although the vulnerabilities with weak ciphers and encryption protocols are widely known, exploiting the vulnerabilities can be both difficult and time consuming. An attacker who was able to monitor a connection, may require a significant amount of time before even one of the weaker encryption ciphers is broken.

2.30.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that only strong encryption ciphers and protocols should be configured. Nipper recommends that SSL and TLS1.0 should not be used, instead Nipper recommends that you use TLS1.2 instead. Furthermore, Nipper recommends that only encryption ciphers with a key length of at least 128 bits should be used.

2.30.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The most secure cipher suite supported by Cisco IOS devices can be configured with the following command:

ip http secure-ciphersuite 3des-ede-cbc-sha

2.30.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0019
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 2616, RFC 2818, RFC 2546
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (see section 2.31).

2.31 No HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.31.1 Finding

HTTPS (RFC 2818) provides a cryptographically secure connection for web-based services, such as network device administration and other sensitive services. HTTPS is a essentially HTTP (RFC 2616) over a SSL/TLS (RFC 2546) encrypted connection.

Network access to the HTTPS service can be restricted by specifying those hosts that are allowed to access the service and thereby denying access to all other network host addresses.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if HTTPS service specific access restrictions had been configured to limit network access.

2.31.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that there was no configured list of hosts to restrict access to the HTTPS service on router03.nipper.org.

2.31.2 Impact

Without management host address restrictions an attacker, or malicious user, with authentication credentials would be able to connect to the HTTPS service, logon and access the functionality and information provided for that user. If an attacker does not have authentication credentials they could attempt a brute-force attack in order to identify valid credentials. Additionally, if there is a vulnerability with the service then allowing anyone to connect to the service could enable an attacker to exploit the vulnerability.

2.31.3 Ease

With no HTTPS network host access restrictions an attacker would not be prevented from connecting to the service. Furthermore, web browsers and other web-based client tools are included as standard with most operating systems. Alternative web service tools are available on the Internet, together with vulnerability exploit code, enumeration and brute-force tools.

2.31.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that access to the HTTPS service should be restricted to only those network hosts that require access.

2.31.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0016
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 2616, RFC 2818, RFC 2546
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (see section 2.30).

2.32 Users Configured With Cisco Type 7 Password Hashing Algorithm

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.32.1 Finding

User passwords on Cisco IOS-based devices can be configured to store user passwords using either a variety of hashing algorithms, including the Cisco Type 7 password encoding algorithm. Whilst the Cisco Type-7 password encoding can be easily reversed to reveal the original password. Instead if the original password needs to be determined from a hash, the passwords must be guessed and then put through the hashing process. The resulting hashes can then be compared in order to determine if the passwords match.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all user passwords used Cisco Type-7 encryption. User accounts that were not usable (i.e. disabled or expired) are excluded from the check.

2.32.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 53: Identified local users
User Password Privilege Filter Logon Attempt Limit Policy
temp password 15   None PASSWORD_POLICY
testuser password 15   None  
localuser password 15   None  
Console Line password 1   None  
Auxiliary password 1   None  
VTY 0 - 4 Line password 1   None  

2.32.2 Impact

A strong password stored using a modern hashing algorithm can take a significant period of time to brute-force. However, the same password stored in the Cisco Type 7 encoded form can be reversed in a fraction of a second. An attacker could use decoded passwords from a Cisco device in order to gain a level of access to the device and potentially modify its configuration.

2.32.3 Ease

An attacker who had access to the Cisco configuration file would easily be able to retrieve and decode passwords that are stored using the Cisco Type-7 encoding scheme. However, an attacker who had access to a Cisco configuration file could attempt a brute-force attack against the stronger modern hashing algorithm. Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are capable of reversing Cisco Type 7 passwords. However, an attacker would need to obtain a copy of the configuration file and would need to be able to gain initial access to the device before they could make use of an enable password.

2.32.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all user passwords should be stored using newer hashing algorithms, such as Cisco Type-8 (PBKDF2) or Type-9 (SCRYPT). The following command can be used to remove users using the Cisco Type 5 password: 

no username

Users can configure the device to store passwords using newer hashing algorithms by using the following command: 

username <user-name> secret <8-9> <password>

2.32.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0003
  • Classification: Authentication

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (see section 2.2);
  • Enable Password Configured (see section 2.5).

2.33 RADIUS Servers With A Dictionary-Based Shared Secret

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Critical
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.33.1 Finding

A RADIUS server provides AAA services for network connected devices such as switches and routers. Authentication requests are sent to the RADIUS server and a access response is returned to the device. A RADIUS shared secret can be configured to encrypt the traffic between the service and requesting device. RADIUS is detailed in RFC 2138.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all the RADIUS servers were not configured with a dictionary-based shared secret.

2.33.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 54: RADIUS servers with a dictionary-based shared secret
Server Group Address Secret Strength
  10.10.10.10 password Dictionary-based

2.33.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to monitor the network traffic between the RADIUS server and the device could potentially extract authentication credentials from the traffic. The attacker could then use the authentication credentials in order to gain a level of access to a number of network devices.

2.33.3 Ease

A skilled attacker could make use of open source code in order to help decrypt any captured network traffic.

2.33.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a strong RADIUS shared secret should be configured to encrypt the network packets between the RADIUS server and client devices. The shared secret will have to be configured on the RADIUS server and client(s).

Nipper recommends that:

  • RADIUS shared secrets should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the RADIUS shared secret should not be repeated more than three times;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include numbers;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should include punctuation characters;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • RADIUS shared secrets should not be based on dictionary words.

2.33.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0014
  • Classification: Authentication
  • RFCs: RFC 2865, RFC 2866
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RADIUS

The following findings are related to this one:

  • RADIUS Servers With No Shared Secret (see section 2.18).

2.34 Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.34.1 Finding

Administrative network services are essential to enable network administrators to remotely configure, update, modify and monitor the systems. Typically these services fall in to two groups:

  • remote command, graphical or web-based environments that enable administrators to quickly configure and manage devices;
  • informational services which either provide alerts, notifications and may also enable the modification of settings using specialist software.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following administrative services:

  • ssh (tcp/22);
  • telnet (tcp/23);
  • tacacs (tcp/49);
  • snmp (udp/161);
  • snmptrap (udp/162);
  • syslog (udp/514).

2.34.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 3.

The filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 55: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.

The filter list "named-acl-2" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 56: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32.

The filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org did not deny access to all the administrative services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that router03.nipper.org would automatically deny access to those administrative services by default if no matching filter rule is found. snmp (UDP port 161), snmptrap (UDP port 162) and syslog (UDP port 514) were the administrative services not specifically denied.

The filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 58: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper determined that filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 1.

The filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 59: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
4 192.168.20.10 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
5 192.168.20.12 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No

7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper determined that filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to administrative services. These were as follows:

  • access to administrative service ssh (TCP port 22) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to administrative service syslog (UDP port 514) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to administrative service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to administrative service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to administrative service snmptrap (UDP port 162) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to administrative service snmp (UDP port 161) was allowed in rule 4.

The filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 60: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.34.2 Impact

The administrative services by their nature enable the remote configuration of a device and access to a wealth of sensitive configuration information. These services are likely to be a prime target for an attacker who may attempt to gain access by exploiting a vulnerability or attacking the authentication systems.

2.34.3 Ease

Access to the administrative network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.34.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that network filter rules should only be configured to allow access to administrative network services from those who are authorized.

2.34.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.34.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0004
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.35 Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.35.1 Finding

Clear-text protocol services are those network services that provide no encryption of the network traffic between the service and a connected client. Whilst some clear-text protocol services are relatively simple and be of little of interest to an attacker, others may be used for the remote administration of the device and transfer their authentication credentials with no encryption.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following clear-text services:

  • ftp-data (tcp/20);
  • ftp (tcp/21);
  • telnet (tcp/23);
  • smtp (tcp/25);
  • tacacs (tcp/49);
  • tftp (tcp/69);
  • http (tcp/80);
  • rtelnet (tcp/107);
  • pop2 (tcp/109);
  • pop3 (tcp/110);
  • nntp (tcp/119);
  • ldap (tcp/389);
  • exec (tcp/512);
  • login (tcp/513);
  • shell (tcp/514);
  • rsync (tcp/873).

2.35.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 3.

The filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 61: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.

The filter list "named-acl-2" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 62: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32.

The filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 1.

Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper determined that filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.
