Nipper determined that filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to clear-text services. These were as follows:

  • access to clear-text service rtelnet (TCP port 107) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service ftp-data (TCP port 20) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service tftp (TCP port 69) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service tacacs (TCP port 49) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service rsync (TCP port 873) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service ftp (TCP port 21) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service smtp (TCP port 25) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service pop2 (TCP port 109) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service shell (TCP port 514) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service http (TCP port 80) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service ldap (TCP port 389) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service exec (TCP port 512) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service telnet (TCP port 23) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service pop3 (TCP port 110) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service nntp (TCP port 119) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to clear-text service login (TCP port 513) was allowed in rule 4.

The filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 66: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.35.2 Impact

Due to a lack of encryption, an attacker who is able to monitor clear-text protocol service network communications would gain access to the information transmitted. The information could include the authentication credentials used to access the service or any other information transferred. Furthermore, some of the services could be used for remote administration and once accessed could be used to attack other devices on the network, bypassing any configured network filtering. Additionally, clear-text protocol services are vulnerable to man in the middle style attacks.

2.35.3 Ease

Access to the network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

Network monitoring tools are available on the Internet and, depending on the operating system, may be installed by default. It is worth noting that an attacker may have to perform additional actions in order to be in a position where the network traffic can be monitored. This could mean that an attacker would have to perform a layer-2 attack or exploit a weakness in a routing protocol.

2.35.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should not allow access to clear-text protocol services.

2.35.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.35.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0007
  • Classification: Clear-Text, Filtering

2.36 Filter Rules Allow To Any Port

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.36.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to any port.

2.36.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 67: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "named-acl-2" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 68: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified twelve rules in filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 69: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
6 212.241.243.217 212.241.243.218 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
8 192.168.224.154 192.168.224.153 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
10 192.168.224.150 192.168.224.149 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
12 192.168.224.162 192.168.224.161 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
18 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: Any No
19 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: ESTABLISHED No
22 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 80 to any port Fragments
Connection State: Any		 No
23 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: Any No
26 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
27 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
31 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
32 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 70: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 71: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to any port. Those rules are detailed in the following table.

Table 72: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.36.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.36.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.36.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.36.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.36.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0024
  • Classification: Filtering

2.37 Syslog Logging Not Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.37.1 Finding

Syslog logging provides an industry standard system (detailed in RFC 5424) for logging messages, enabling the collection, storage and administration of logs from a variety of devices to a single location. The sending of logs to other systems, not only provides extra storage space for logs which could be size restricted on the originating network device, but it also provides an extra level of protection for the logs in a scenario where an attacker has compromised the security of the message source.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if logging to a WebTrends logging server had been configured.

2.37.2 Impact

If logging of system messages is not configured, a network administrator may not be made aware of significant events happening on the device. These events could include security issues such as intrusion attempts, network scans, authentication failures or diagnostic and management information such as potential hardware issues. Without logging system messages, the information would not be available to either a forensic investigation or for diagnostic purposes.

2.37.3 Ease

System messages will not be sent to a Syslog logging server.

2.37.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that Syslog logging should be configured to enable system messages to be logged to a central logging server.

2.37.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The logging of system messages to a remote Syslog host can be configured using the following command:

logging host <ip-address>

2.37.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-LOG-0005
  • RFCs: RFC 3164, RFC 5424
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syslog

2.38 Low OSPF Priorities

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.38.1 Finding

Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is a routing protocol that can be configured to dynamically update the routing table with changes to the network topology. Multiple routers can be configured on a network for fault tolerance, in that situation the router with the highest priority will take precedence. Router priorities can be between 0 and 255, if set to 0 the router will not become the designated or backup router. If two routers have the same priority, the router with the highest router Identifier (ID) will then take precedence.

Nipper examined the device configuration OSPF routing to determine that the priority had been set to 255.

2.38.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following OSPF routing configuration on router03.nipper.org with a priority not equal to 255:

Table 73: OSPF with a weak priority
Interface Active Passive Area Priority Type Auth Mode SPI Key Route Cost Hello Interval Dead Interval
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes No   1 Point to MultiPoint Key Chain N/A 1 Default 10 seconds 40 seconds
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes No   1 Point to MultiPoint Key Chain N/A OSPF_KEY_CHAIN Default 10 seconds 40 seconds

2.38.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to configure OSPF with the relevant authentication configuration, could configure a higher priority in order to take precedence over the existing router. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.38.3 Ease

To perform this attack, the attacker would first have to determine the existing OSPF configuration. If authentication credentials are used, the attacker could extract them from the captured network packets. With MD5-based authentication, the attacker would have use a dictionary/brute-force attack in order to determine the authentication key. Additionally, the attacker would require access to a network segment where they could participate in OSPF routing. The attacker could then configure their router with a higher priority in order to perform the attack. All of the software required to complete each of these components can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.38.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the OSPF priority of 255 should be configured. If two or more routers are present, Nipper recommends that each of the routers should be configured with high numbered priorities.

2.38.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

A high OSPF priority can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following interface command:

ip ospf priority <priority-no>

2.38.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0030
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2328, RFC 5340
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Shortest_Path_First

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40);
  • No OSPF LSA Thresholds (see section 2.46).

2.39 No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.39.1 Finding

RIP is a routing protocol that allows network devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network infrastructure. The routing devices can be configured to send RIP routing updates to specified RIP neighbors. If not specified, RIP routing updates will be sent to all LAN hosts.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all RIP routing instances were configured with neighbors.

2.39.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that there was one RIP routing instance with no neighbors on router03.nipper.org.

Table 74: RIP routing instances with no neighbors
Router Enabled Send Version Receive Version Update Interval
  Enabled 1 1 and 2 0

2.39.2 Impact

With no RIP routing update neighbors configured, route updates will be sent to all LAN hosts. If an attacker is able to monitor a network segment to which the device is attached, they would be able to monitor the routing traffic. This would give the attacker:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.39.3 Ease

RIP routing updates will be sent to all hosts on the LAN. Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to monitor, extract and exploit the information contained in the RIP route update packets.

2.39.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that RIP routing update neighbors should be configured to send RIP updates to specific addresses.

2.39.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

RIP neighbors can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following router command:

neighbor <ip-address>

2.39.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0037
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 1058, RFC 1388, RFC 1723, RFC 2453, RFC 4822
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.8);
  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.23);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.40 Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Medium
  • Impact: High
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Involved
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.40.1 Finding

Routers and routing devices can be configured to send route updates to each other. This enables devices to dynamically adapt to changes in the network topology and enables router devices to make informed decisions when routing network traffic between networks. Authentication keys, sometimes referred to as shared secrets, can be configured for routing protocols. The routing protocol authentication keys are configured to ensure that any routing updates sent to the device that will update the device's routing information were only sent from trusted sources.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that no routing keychains were configured with weak authentication keys.

2.40.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified three weak routing keychain authentication keys configured on router03.nipper.org. Those routing keychain authentication keys are detailed in the table below.

Table 75: Routing keychains with weak authentication keys
Keychain Key ID Key Algo Accept Life Send Life Key Strength
OSPF_KEY_CHAIN 1 xxxxxxx SHA256 Wed Jan 31 00:00:00 2018 to Sun Apr 1 01:05:00 2018 Mon Jan 1 00:00:00 2018 to Fri Mar 2 23:59:59 2018 Too short
OSPF_KEY_CHAIN 2 yyyyyyy SHA256 Sat Mar 31 23:55:00 2018 to Sun Jul 1 01:05:00 2018 Sun Apr 1 00:00:00 2018 to Sat Jun 30 23:59:59 2018 Too short
1   bakedbeans MD5     No upper case characters

2.40.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to modify the routing table of a routing device in an attempt to route network traffic through a device that they control. If an attacker is able to control a routing device they would be able to:

  • monitor network traffic sent between network segments;
  • gain a list of network addresses the router knows about;
  • perform a man in the middle attack;
  • capture clear-text protocol authentication credentials;
  • capture encrypted authentication hashes which could be subjected to a brute-force attack;
  • perform a network wide DoS;
  • route updates could be redistributed by the device to other routing devices and possibly using other routing protocols and authentication.

2.40.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to send malicious routing updates. With a weak authentication key configured, the attacker may have to perform a brute-force attack in order to determine the authentication key. The attacker could then send routing updates that appear to be authentic and the source address can be spoofed.

2.40.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that strong routing protocol authentication keys should be configured for all routing updates.

Nipper recommends that:

  • Routing authentication keys should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the Routing authentication key should not be repeated more than three times;
  • Routing authentication keys should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • Routing authentication keys should include numbers;
  • Routing authentication keys should include punctuation characters;
  • Routing authentication keys should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • Routing authentication keys should not be based on dictionary words.

2.40.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Authentication key chains and keys can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following commands:

key chain <chain-name>
 key <key-number>
 key-string <authentication-string>

2.40.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0024
  • Classification: Authentication, Routing

The following findings are related to this one:

  • BGP Neighbors With No Authentication (see section 2.7);
  • No RIP Authentication (see section 2.8);
  • Low GLBP Group Priorities (see section 2.9);
  • Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.10);
  • Low HSRP Group Priorities (see section 2.11);
  • Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (see section 2.12);
  • Low VRRP Priorities (see section 2.13);
  • Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (see section 2.14);
  • RIP Version 1 Configured (see section 2.23);
  • Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.24);
  • Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (see section 2.25);
  • Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (see section 2.26);
  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Low OSPF Priorities (see section 2.38);
  • No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (see section 2.39);
  • No OSPF LSA Thresholds (see section 2.46).

2.41 The Finger Service Was Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.41.1 Finding

The Finger protocol (defined in RFC 749 and RFC 1288) enables the enumeration of status and user information from a system running a Finger service. The Finger protocol is simple and does not encrypt the data or provide any authentication. The default TCP port for the Finger service is 79.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the Finger service was disabled.

2.41.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the Finger service was enabled on router03.nipper.org

2.41.2 Impact

An attacker could use the Finger service to enumerate users and user information. The attacker could then use this information as part of a targeted attack such as password guessing or a brute-force attack. The Finger user information may also be used by an attacker for a targeted attack where user identity information would be useful.

2.41.3 Ease

The Finger query tool is installed by default on some platforms by default and is relatively easy to use. Additionally, tools that an attacker can use to attack a system using the information obtained using Finger are available to download from the Internet.

2.41.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the Finger service should be disabled to help prevent an attacker from enumerating user information.

2.41.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Finger can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

no ip finger

2.41.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the legacy Finger service. (Risk Level - Safe)

no ip finger

2.41.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0005
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 749, RFC 1288
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finger_protocol

2.42 Administration Line With Weak Inbound ACL Host Restrictions

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.42.1 Finding

Some devices use administrative line configurations to configure which administrative services, such as Telnet and SSH command line services, should be offered by the device. Additionally administrative lines can be configured to specify additional options such as authentication methods, access restrictions, timeouts and more.

To prevent access to the administrative services from unauthorized hosts, the administrative lines can be configred with an inbound ACL to restrict access from only those systems that are permitted.

Nipper examined the all the administative VTY line inbound ACL to determine if they had been configured to allow access from only specific hosts, rather than entire subnets or address ranges.

2.42.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

The configuration of the administrative lines with inbound ACL on router03.nipper.org are detailed in Table 76.

Table 76: Administrative line settings on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Level Password Telnet SSH Filter In Filter Out
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password Yes Yes 40  

Nipper determined that the administrative line Virtual Teletype (VTY) 0 - 4 restricted access to specific administrative addresses on router03.nipper.org. The filter list assigned for restricting acceess to administrative line Virtual Teletype (VTY) 0 - 4 was "40".

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "40" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from anything other than a single address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 77: Standard IPv4 ACL: 40
Rule Action Source Log
5 20.0.0.0/24 No

2.42.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with valid authentication credentials and access to the service would be able to logon and execute commands within the context of that user. If the attacker does not have authentication credentials they could attempt a brute-force attack in order to identify valid credentials. Additionally, if there is a vulnerability with the service then allowing anyone to connect to the service could enable an attacker to exploit the vulnerability.

2.42.3 Ease

Since the inbound administrative line ACL was configured to allow access from entire network subnets it would be easier for an unauthorized user, or attacker, to access the service than if they had been restricted to only those specific network addresses that require access. If the attackers address is not within the permitted range they would have to either spoof the address or compromise a system that is within the configured range of network addresses in order to access the services delivered via the administrative lines.

2.42.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that an ACL should be restricted to only those network hosts that require access.

2.42.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices an inbound ACL can be created and assigned to an administrative line using the following commands:

ip access-list standard <access-list-number>
    remark <description>
    permit <ip-address> <wildcard> [log]
    exit
line <line-type> <line-number(s)>
    access-class <access-list-number> in

2.42.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0047
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (see section 2.4);
  • SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (see section 2.17).

2.43 Weak User Account Lockout Policy Setting

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.43.1 Finding

When configured, the user account lockout policy setting will prevent a user account from authenticating if the user has failed to logon the number of times defined by the threshold.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the maximum number of failed login attempts was set to three or less.

2.43.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 78: Identified users
User Password Privilege Filter Logon Attempt Limit Policy
enable (password) cisco 15   None  
temp password 15   None PASSWORD_POLICY
testuser password 15   None  
localuser password 15   None  
Console Line password 1   None  
Auxiliary password 1   None  
VTY 0 - 4 Line password 1   None  

2.43.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, may attempt to determine a password for a specific user account by repeatedly attempting to logon using a different password each time. If no user account lockout policy setting has been configured then an attacker could brute-force a password by going through each character combination until a valid password is found. However, if a user account lockout policy setting has been defined, the attacker will be limited to a far smaller number of guesses before the account becomes unusable.

2.43.3 Ease

Brute-force and dictionary-based password guessing attacks have been widely documented on the Internet and published media, enabling an attacker with very little knowledge or experience to perform the attack. However, it is also worth noting that there are a number of factors that may discourage an attacker from performing a password guessing attack.

  • If a user account lockout policy setting has been configured the user account could quickly become disabled.
  • Device protection mechanisms may slow or disconnect connections where multiple authentication attempts are made in a short period of time.
  • Brute-forcing can be very time consuming, especially if the password is long or made up of various character types.
  • Network administrators may be alerted to locked out accounts or authentication attempts.

2.43.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a user account lockout threshold of three should be configured in order to help prevent unauthorized access to user accounts.

2.43.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ATH-0010
  • Classification: Authentication

2.44 Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.44.1 Finding

Whilst not strictly administrative services, a number of network services can be classified as potentially sensitive due to their nature. These network services could be database services that enable applications to connect to and query data, authentication services or Microsoft Windows file sharing services.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following potentially sensitive services:

  • netbios-ns (tcp/137);
  • netbios-ns (udp/137);
  • netbios-dgm (tcp/138);
  • netbios-dgm (udp/138);
  • netbios-ssn (tcp/139);
  • netbios-ssn (udp/139);
  • microsoft-ds (tcp/445);
  • nessus (tcp/1241);
  • ms-sql-s (tcp/1433);
  • ms-sql-s (udp/1433);
  • ms-sql-m (tcp/1434);
  • ms-sql-m (udp/1434);
  • wins (tcp/1512);
  • radius (tcp/1812);
  • mysql (tcp/3306);
  • tns-server (tcp/3308);
  • http-alt (tcp/8080).

2.44.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (UDP port 139) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service mysql (TCP port 3306) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (UDP port 137) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (UDP port 138) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rule 3.

The filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 79: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (UDP port 139) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;

  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;

  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service mysql (TCP port 3306) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org did not deny access to all the potentially sensitive services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that router03.nipper.org would automatically deny access to those potentially sensitive services by default if no matching filter rule is found. netbios-ns (UDP port 137), netbios-dgm (UDP port 138), netbios-ssn (UDP port 139), ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) and ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434) were the potentially sensitive services not specifically denied.

The filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 82: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper determined that filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (UDP port 139) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (UDP port 138) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service mysql (TCP port 3306) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (UDP port 137) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.

Nipper determined that filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially sensitive services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (UDP port 139) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service wins (TCP port 1512) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service mysql (TCP port 3306) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (TCP port 137) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (UDP port 1434) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service http-alt (TCP port 8080) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ssn (TCP port 139) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service nessus (TCP port 1241) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-ns (UDP port 137) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (UDP port 138) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (TCP port 1433) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-m (TCP port 1434) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service tns-server (TCP port 3308) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service ms-sql-s (UDP port 1433) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service radius (TCP port 1812) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service microsoft-ds (TCP port 445) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially sensitive service netbios-dgm (TCP port 138) was allowed in rule 4.

The filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 84: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.44.2 Impact

Although there may be a business requirement for access to be permitted to these services, such as access to Windows file shares, these services also offer a tempting target for an attacker. At worst an attacker may be able to exploit configuration or software vulnerabilities in these services in order to gain access to the service host and data. It is also typical for these services to provide an attacker with a wealth of information about the systems, such as enumerating users from a Windows hosts or obtaining software version details from database services.

2.44.3 Ease

Access to the potentially sensitive network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.44.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that access to potentially sensitive services should be restricted to only those who are authorized.

2.44.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.44.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0005
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.45 Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.45.1 Finding

A number of different network services provide little to no functionality and are installed by default on some operating systems. Examples of these services are:

  • echo - a network service that responds with a copy of the data sent to it;
  • qotd - a network service that responds a random quote;
  • discard - a network service that simply ignores anything that is sent to it;
  • chargen - a network service that returns with a repeating character sequence;
  • daytime - a network service that returns the current system time and date.

Nipper examined the network filtering to determine if any filter rules allow access to the following potentially unnecessary services:

  • echo (tcp/7);
  • echo (udp/7);
  • discard (tcp/9);
  • discard (udp/9);
  • daytime (tcp/13);
  • daytime (udp/13);
  • qotd (tcp/17);
  • qotd (udp/17);
  • chargen (tcp/19);
  • chargen (udp/19);
  • whoispp (tcp/63);
  • whoispp (udp/63);
  • gopher (tcp/70);
  • finger (tcp/79);
  • finger (udp/79).

2.45.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 3;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 3.

The filter list "named-acl-1" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rules 1 and 2.

Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rules 6, 8, 10, 12, 18, 19, 22, 23, 26, 27, 31 and 32.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 1.

Nipper determined that filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org did not deny access to all the potentially unnecessary services before the end of the filter rule list. However, it is worth noting that router03.nipper.org would automatically deny access to those potentially unnecessary services by default if no matching filter rule is found. echo (UDP port 7), discard (UDP port 9), daytime (UDP port 13), qotd (UDP port 17), chargen (UDP port 19), whoispp (UDP port 63) and finger (UDP port 79) were the potentially unnecessary services not specifically denied.

The filter list "110" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;

  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;

  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;

  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 1;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rules 1 and 2;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 1.
