Nipper determined that filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org allowed access to potentially unnecessary services. These were as follows:

  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (TCP port 19) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service chargen (UDP port 19) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (TCP port 63) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (UDP port 13) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service daytime (TCP port 13) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (TCP port 7) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (TCP port 79) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service echo (UDP port 7) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (UDP port 9) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (UDP port 17) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service gopher (TCP port 70) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service finger (UDP port 79) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service discard (TCP port 9) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service qotd (TCP port 17) was allowed in rule 4;
  • access to potentially unnecessary service whoispp (UDP port 63) was allowed in rule 4.

The filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org is described in the following table.

Table 90: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.45.2 Impact

Although a number of these services may appear to be relatively harmless, serious issues may exist with their use and running unnecessary services also places a burden on the host system. Furthermore, an attacker may be able to use a combination of some network services such as chargen and echo to perform a DoS attack.

2.45.3 Ease

Access to the potentially unnecessary network services detailed in the finding would not be prevented by the network filter rules if any network traffic were to match the rule.

2.45.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should be configured to prevent access to potentially unnecessary services. Additionally, if the potentially unnecessary network services are not required, Nipper suggests that they should be disabled.

2.45.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.45.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0006
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.46 No OSPF LSA Thresholds

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.46.1 Finding

OSPF is a routing protocol that can be configured to dynamically update the routing table with changes to the network topology. OSPF uses Link State Advertisement (LSA) to communicate changes to other routers and update the routers own Link State Database (LSDB). Devices can be configured with a LSA message threshold in order to limit the number of LSA messages being processed by the device.

Nipper examined the device configuration OSPF routing to determine that a maximum LSA limit had been configured.

2.46.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one OSPF configuration with no maximum LSA configured on router03.nipper.org. This is listed in the table below.

Table 91: OSPF maximum LSA limit
Process Name Router ID IPv6 Maximum LSA
6   No 0

2.46.2 Impact

An attacker may be able to perform an OSPF DoS by flooding the device with LSA messages.

2.46.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can be used to perform a DoS by flooding the device with LSA messages.

2.46.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that the number of OSPF LSA messages accepted by the device should be limited.

2.46.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The number of OSPF LSA messages can be limited on Cisco IOS devices with the following router command:

max-lsa <threshold>

2.46.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0031
  • Classification: Routing
  • RFCs: RFC 2328, RFC 5340
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Shortest_Path_First

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.27);
  • Low OSPF Priorities (see section 2.38);
  • Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (see section 2.40).

2.47 No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.47.1 Finding

Using SNMP, some network devices can be instructed to send its configuration to a file on a specified Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) server. This feature enables network administrators and management software to quickly obtain a copy of a device's configuration. A network access list can be configured on those devices to help secure access to this functionality (supported on Cisco IOS devices from version 10.2).

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if a TFTP server ACL had been configured to restrict the SNMP servers TFTP access to specific hosts.

2.47.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that there was no TFTP server ACL configured on router03.nipper.org to restrict the SNMP service access.

2.47.2 Impact

An attacker who had SNMP write access could remotely obtain a copy of a device's configuration. The configuration would include any passwords for the device and include the configuration of the administrative services.

2.47.3 Ease

For an attacker to exploit this issue they would require SNMP query tools, a TFTP server and a community string with write access to the SNMP MIB. SNMP query tools and TFTP server software can be downloaded from the Internet and some OS install them by default. If the attacker does not know the community string it may be possible to determine it by monitoring the network traffic or by brute-forcing the community string.

2.47.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a SNMP TFTP server list ACL should be configured to ensure that configurations are only saved to specific hosts.

2.47.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following example configures ACL number 20 for use as a SNMP TFTP server list and gives access to a single host with logging.

access-list 20 permit 192.168.0.50 255.255.255.255 log
access-list 20 deny any log

The ACL can then be assigned as the SNMP TFTP server list with the following command:

snmp-server tftp-server-list 20

2.47.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0011
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416, RFC 1350
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trivial_File_Transfer_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.48 SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.48.1 Finding

SNMPv3, like prior versions, provides remote access for the monitoring and administration of a device. Version 3 adds various levels of security and privacy. This enables a SNMPv3 user to have:

  • communication without authentication and privacy encryption (NoAuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and without privacy encryption (AuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and privacy encryption (AuthPriv).

SNMPv3 allows for a variety of different authentication hashing algorithms and privacy encryption algorithms to protect the authentication and data in transit.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all SNMP users were configured to use privacy encryption algorithms.

2.48.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following two SNMP users on router03.nipper.org that were not configured to use a privacy encryption algorithm.

Table 92: SNMP users with no privacy encryption
User Host Port Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password ACL IPv6 ACL
Test   N/A 3 Auth MD5 (NO PASSWORD) N/A N/A    
Test3   N/A 3 Auth SHA (NO PASSWORD) N/A N/A    

2.48.2 Impact

An attacker or malicious user who can monitor the unencrypted SNMP network traffic would capture all the information transferred using the unencrypted connection. Furthermore, the attacker could attempt to determine the authentication password by brute-forcing the authentication hash. Once determined, the attacker would then gain the level access provided to the user, which could include the ability to modify the device.

2.48.3 Ease

Network packet capture tools can be downloaded from the Internet that can allow an attacker to monitor the network traffic. In a modern network environment, switches are typically deployed to connect the network infrastructure devices rather than hubs. With network switch devices, the attacker should only be able to see broadcast network traffic or traffic sent directly to or from the attacker's host. However, a skilled attacker could bypass this restriction by performing an attack such as ARP spoofing or exploiting a vulnerability with the network routing. Tools for bypassing a network switching environment's restrictions can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.48.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) privacy encryption algorithm should be configured for all SNMPv3 users.

2.48.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

SNMP version 3 is configured by creating a group and then by adding users to the group. The following commands can be used to create a group and add a user to it:

snmp-server group <group-name> v3 {noauth | auth | priv} [read <read-view>] [write <write-view>] [notify <notify-view>] [access <acl>]
snmp-server user <username> <group-name> v3 [auth {md5 | sha} <auth-password>] [access <acl>]

2.48.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0015
  • Classification: Administration, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.49 NTP Authentication Was Disabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.49.1 Finding

Time synchronization for network devices is inherently important, not just for the various services that make use of time, but also for the accurate logging of events. Therefore network devices can be configured to synchronize their time against a network time source in order to ensure that the time is synchronized.

Network Time Protocol (NTP) (described in RFC 5905) is a complex time synchronization protocol with a number of different features and options such as time update authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if NTP authentication was enabled.

2.49.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the NTP client authentication was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.49.2 Impact

If an attacker is able to modify a device's time with an inaccurate time update then it would be more difficult during an examination to correlate the system logs. Furthermore, any systems that depend on accurate time, such as some authentication systems, could be disrupted and potentially cause a DoS.

2.49.3 Ease

With NTP time authentication disabled, an attacker could attempt to update the time by sending malicious time updates. An attacker could do this using open source code or by sending customized network packets and spoofing the source address.

2.49.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that NTP time authentication should be enabled.

2.49.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Authenticated NTP time updates can be configured on Cisco IOS devices with the following commands:

ntp authenticate
ntp authentication-key <key-num> md5 <key-string>
ntp server <ip-address> key <key-num> [prefer]

If access restrictions are in place, you will need to ensure that you allow time synchronization with the following command 

ntp access-group peer <acl>

2.49.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-TME-0002
  • Classification: Authentication
  • RFCs: RFC 1305, RFC 5905
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Time_Protocol

2.50 The BOOTP Service Was Not Disabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.50.1 Finding

BOOTstrap Protocol (BOOTP) (described in RFC 951) is a datagram protocol that enables compatible hosts to load their operating system over the network from a BOOTP server. However, these days BOOTP services are rarely used.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the BOOTP service had been disabled. However, it is worth noting that not all device models will support the BOOTP service and therefore this can be falsely determined.

2.50.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the BOOTP service was enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.50.2 Impact

An attacker could use a device that offers a BOOTP service to download a copy of the device's OS software.

2.50.3 Ease

Tools that can interact with BOOTP services can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.50.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, the BOOTP service should be disabled.

2.50.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The BOOTP service can be disabled using one of the following commands:

ip dhcp bootp ignore
no ip bootp server

2.50.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the BOOTP service on the device. (Risk Level - Low)

ip dhcp bootp ignore

2.50.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0002
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 951
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrap_Protocol

2.51 No Warning In Pre-Logon Banner Message

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.51.1 Finding

Logon banner messages are an important, but often overlooked, part of a secure configuration. Logon banner messages can provide connecting users with important information and warn against unauthorized access.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if there was a pre-login banner message that contained any of the following words:

  • warning;
  • authorised;
  • authorized;
  • prosecute;
  • permission;
  • prohibited.

2.51.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

The Login banner message on router03.nipper.org was:


This is a test banner. This also has a really long banner text line to see what happens when the banner text is wider than the report content display.

2.51.2 Impact

A carefully worded warning message could deter a casual attacker or malicious user, but not a determined attacker. However, it would be more difficult to prove any intent without a message warning against unauthorized access if any legal action were to be taken against an attacker.

2.51.3 Ease

An attacker would not be presented with a carefully worded legal warning prior to attempting to logon.

2.51.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all pre-logon banner messages should be configured to warn against unauthorized access.

2.51.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The Login banner message is shown to all connections to Cisco IOS devices prior to logon. The Login banner message can be configured on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

banner login <delimiter> <banner-message> <delimiter>

2.51.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-BAN-0003
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication

2.52 Service Password Encryption Disabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.52.1 Finding

Some device passwords, such as user authentication passwords, do not need to be known by the device which can make authentication checks based on the encrypted hash. Other passwords need to be known by the device in order that it can perform specific operations using the clear-text version of the password. The service password encryption option instructs a device to store passwords using Cisco type-7 encryption where it is possible as these can be reversed to their original clear-text form. By default the passwords are otherwise stored in the configuration file in their clear-text form.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the device was configured to store passwords in an encrypted form.

2.52.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the storage of encrypted passwords was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.52.2 Impact

A malicious user or an attacker with access to the device's configuration could quickly extract clear-text passwords without having to decode or brute-force them. Alternatively, a malicious user could gain a clear-text password if they were closely watching a network administrator. The attacker could then make use of the stolen credentials to gain a level of access to the device.

2.52.3 Ease

An attacker would require access to the device configuration or would have to be closely watching a network administrator. This issue may require the attacker to have access to the device or a backup copy of the configuration for the device.

2.52.4 Recommendation

Although Cisco type-7 passwords are easily reversed, and there are a number of programs that reverse them, they do provide an effective barrier against a casual observer. Therefore, Nipper recommends that service password encryption should be enabled.

2.52.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Service password encryption can be enabled on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

service password-encryption

2.52.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will enable the password encryption server. This provides a more secure configuration by storing important passwords using non-trivial encryption algorithms. (Risk Level - Safe)

service password-encryption

2.52.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-CON-0002
  • Classification: Authentication

2.53 Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.53.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow from a subnet address.

2.53.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "120" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed from a subnet address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 93: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No

2.53.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.53.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.53.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.53.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.53.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0019
  • Classification: Filtering

2.54 Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.54.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to a subnet address.

2.54.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to a subnet address. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 94: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.54.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.54.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.54.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.54.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.54.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0022
  • Classification: Filtering

2.55 Filter Rules Allow To Port Range

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.55.1 Finding

Filtering rules are typically deployed between networks of different security levels, service type, location, organizational unit or organization. The filtering rules assist the network administrator with restricting access to systems and services from only those that have been allowed to access them. Filtering rules are typically processed by a device sequentially, with the first rule that matches the network traffic traversing the filtering device being applied. If no filtering rules match the traffic passing through the default action will be applied, which on most devices is to block the network traffic.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any network filtering rules that allow to a range port.

2.55.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "cp-critical-in" configured on router03.nipper.org that allowed to a range port. That rule is detailed in the following table.

Table 95: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
30 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to ports 56-62 Connection State: Any No

2.55.2 Impact

It would be possible for a potentially unauthorized user, or malicious actor, to access to the hosts and services described in the finding. For a network edge device, this could lead to a remote attacker gaining access to a service. For an internal filtering this could lead a malicious user gaining unauthorized access to a service.

2.55.3 Ease

The network filtering would not prevent a malicious user or an attacker from accessing the network services covered by the rules detailed in this issues finding.

2.55.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, all network filtering rules should be configured to restrict access to network hosts and services from only those hosts that require access. However, it is worth noting that it may not be possible to achieve this in all circumstances. For example, a public web service may anyone to access the service itself from any location.

2.55.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. ACL can be either named or numbered. If numbered a standard ACL will be numbered between 1-99 and 1300-1999, all others will be extended ACL. The following commands show how to create both named and numbered standard and extended ACL and filter rules:

ip access-list standard <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <source-address> [log]
ip access-list extended <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit
access-list <number> [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address> [<source-port>] <dest-address> [<dest-port>] [log]

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

On Cisco IOS devices IPv6 network filter rules are added to ACL which can then be used when configuring interfaces, services and other options. The following commands show how to create add an ACE to a named IPv6 ACL:

ipv6 access-list <list-name>
  [permit | deny] <protocol> <source-address/prefix> [<source-port>] <dest-address/prefix> [<dest-port>] [log]
  exit

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.55.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0025
  • Classification: Filtering

2.56 IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.56.1 Finding

Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo requests can be addressed to an entire network or subnet as well as to individual hosts. Disabling directed broadcasts on each individual network interface will help prevent network ping requests.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if IP directed broadcasts had been disabled.

2.56.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that IP Directed Broadcasts were configured on the router03.nipper.org network interfaces as follows:

Table 96: Interfaces with IP Directed Broadcasts
Interface Active Address Proxy-ARP Directed ACL In ACL Out
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 10.0.0.1
 		 Off On    

It is worth noting that IP Directed Broadcasts is not applicable on those interfaces without an Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) address.

The scope of the network interfaces examined was limited to IPv4 layer-3 network interfaces and have support for IP Directed Broadcasts. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/1 was the only network interface included in the scope of this check. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/2 was the only network interface excluded from the scope of this check.

2.56.2 Impact

A DoS attack known as a Smurf attack makes use of network ICMP echo requests to perform the attack. An attacker would send an ICMP echo request with the victim hosts IP address spoofed as the source address. The hosts on the network would then reply to the echo request, flooding the victim host.

2.56.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are capable of performing the smurf attack outlined above.

2.56.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that directed broadcasts should be disabled on all network interfaces.

2.56.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Directed broadcasts can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices with the following command:

no ip directed broadcast

2.56.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0002

The following findings are related to this one:

  • ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.57);
  • ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.58);
  • Filter Rules Allow ICMP (see section 2.67);
  • ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.71).

2.57 ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.57.1 Finding

ICMP address mask reply messages inform network hosts of the TCP / IP network mask for a network segment. This protocol can now be regarded as legacy as hosts will typically either make use of protocols such as Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or be configured fixed address information.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if ICMP IP Mask Reply had been disabled.

2.57.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 97: Interfaces with ICMP IP Mask Reply
Interface Active Address Unreachables Redirects Mask Reply Info Reply
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 10.0.0.1 On On On Off

It is worth noting that ICMP IP Mask Reply is not applicable on those interfaces without an IPv4 address.

The scope of the network interfaces examined was limited to IPv4 layer-3 network interfaces and have support for ICMP IP Mask Reply. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/1 was the only network interface included in the scope of this check. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/2 was the only network interface excluded from the scope of this check.

2.57.2 Impact

An attacker could use the ICMP address mask reply feature to gain additional information about the network configuration.

2.57.3 Ease

ICMP scanning tools, that are capably of sending various types of ICMP messages, can be downloaded from the Internet. Furthermore, some OS include ICMP tools as standard.

2.57.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, ICMP address mask reply messages should be disabled on all network interfaces.

2.57.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

ICMP mask reply message sending can be disabled on network interfaces with the following command:

no ip mask-reply

2.57.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0009
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled (see section 2.56);
  • ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.58);
  • Filter Rules Allow ICMP (see section 2.67);
  • ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.71).

2.58 ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.58.1 Finding

When a network packet is sent to a destination host or service that is unreachable, a ICMP unreachable message can be sent from a network gateway or the destination host to inform the requester that it was unreachable. If it is a host that is unreachable the message will be in the form of an ICMP host unreachable message. ICMP unreachable messages are described in more detail in RFC 792.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if IP Unreachables had been disabled.

2.58.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 98: Interfaces with ICMP IP Unreachables
Interface Active Address Unreachables Redirects Mask Reply Info Reply
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 10.0.0.1 On On On Off

It is worth noting that ICMP IP Unreachables is not applicable on those interfaces without an IPv4 address.

The scope of the network interfaces examined was limited to IPv4 layer-3 network interfaces and have support for ICMP IP Unreachables. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/1 was the only network interface included in the scope of this check. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/2 was the only network interface excluded from the scope of this check.

2.58.2 Impact

An attacker who was performing network scans to determine what services were available would be able to scan a device more quickly. If the device being scanned sends ICMP unreachable messages, informing the attacker that a network or protocol is not supported, the attacker will not have to wait for a connection time-out.

2.58.3 Ease

The ICMP messages are automatically returned by a device with the ICMP unreachable feature enabled. Network scanning tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are able to perform a wide variety of scan types and take into account ICMP unreachable messages.

2.58.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, ICMP unreachable messages should be disabled. However, it is important to note that whilst disabling of ICMP unreachable messages will not stop a network scan, it will make the scan more time consuming for the attacker to perform.

2.58.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

ICMP unreachable message sending can be disabled on network interfaces with the following command:

no ip unreachables

2.58.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0020
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled (see section 2.56);
  • ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.57);
  • Filter Rules Allow ICMP (see section 2.67);
  • ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.71).

2.59 CDP Was Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.59.1 Finding

Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) is a proprietary protocol that was developed and is primarily used by Cisco. A CDP enabled device can be configured to broadcast CDP packets on the network enabling network management applications and CDP aware devices to identify each other. CDP packets include the following information about the sending device:

  • The OS version details of the device.
  • IP address details of the device.
  • The devices name.
  • Details of the devices hardware platform, model and capabilities.
  • Information about the network interface and VLAN used to send the CDP message.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if CDP was disabled.

2.59.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that CDP was enabled on router03.nipper.org. The following table shows the CDP status on individual network interfaces.

Table 99: CDP interface status on router03.nipper.org
Interface Active Description CDP
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes First interface on switch On
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes Second interface on switch On

2.59.2 Impact

CDP packets contain information about the sender, such as hardware model information, operating system version and IP address details. This information would give an attacker valuable information about the device. The attacker could then use this information as part of a targeted attack.

The following is an example capture of CDP information using the "tcpdump" tool. It shows the types of information an attacker would gain by capturing CDP packets.

tcpdump: listening on bond0, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 1500 bytes
08:50:11.768298 CDPv2, ttl: 180s, checksum: 0xb08a (unverified), length 271
    Device-ID (0x01), value length: 40 bytes: ‘test1-demo-sw28b.test.com(FDO2116225P)’
    Address (0x02), value length: 13 bytes: IPv4 (1) test1-demo-sw28b.test.com
    Port-ID (0x03), value length: 11 bytes: ‘Ethernet1/1’
    Capability (0x04), value length: 4 bytes: (0x00000229): Router, L2 Switch, IGMP snooping
    Version String (0x05), value length: 66 bytes: 
      Cisco Nexus Operating System (NX-OS) Software, Version 7.0(3)I6(1)
    Platform (0x06), value length: 15 bytes: ‘N9K-C9xx3180YC-EX’
    Native VLAN ID (0x0a), value length: 2 bytes: 985
    Duplex (0x0b), value length: 1 byte: full
    MTU (0x11), value length: 4 bytes: 1500 bytes
    System Name (0x14), value length: 17 bytes: ‘test1-demo-sw28b’
    System Object ID (not decoded) (0x15), value length: 14 bytes:
       0x0000:  060c 2b06 0104 0109 0c03 0103 8e14
    Management Addresses (0x16), value length: 13 bytes: IPv4 (1) test1-demo-sw28b.test.com
    Physical Location (0x17), value length: 15 bytes: 0x00/test1

The example CDP information above, includes the platform and software version details. Using that information an attacker could then search vulnerability databases, such as National Vulnerability Database (NVD) to identify any vulnerabilities that could be exploited. If the attacker identifies a vulnerability, they could then follow the information described to exploit the issue or search the Internet for exploit code.

2.59.3 Ease

CDP packets are broadcast to an entire network segment. The attacker or malicious user would require access to a network segment on which the CDP packets are broadcast and network monitoring software. A wide variety of network monitoring, packet capture and analysis tools can be downloaded from the Internet. Tools like:

  • Wireshark, which is a graphical packet capture tool used by networking specialists (https://www.wireshark.org/)
  • TCPDump, which is a command line packet capture tool (https://www.tcpdump.org/)

2.59.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, CDP should be disabled. However, in some configurations with IP phones, deployed using either Auto Discovery or DHCP, the CDP service may need to be enabled. However, if the device supports disabling CDP on individual interfaces, then Nipper recommends that it should be disabled on all the interfaces where it is not required.

2.59.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following commands can be used to disable CDP on Cisco IOS devices. The first command disables CDP for the entire device, whilst the second can be used to disable CDP on individual interfaces.

no cdp run
no cdp enable

2.59.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0001
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cisco_Discovery_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • LLDP Was Enabled (see section 2.60).

2.60 LLDP Was Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.60.1 Finding

Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) is an industry standard protocol specified in Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.1AB. A LLDP enabled device can be configured to broadcast and receive LLDP packets on the network enabling network management applications and LLDP aware devices to identify each other. LLDP packets may include the following sender information:

  • System name and description.
  • Network interface name, description and VLAN details.
  • IP management address.
  • System capabilities.
  • MAC address information.
  • Power over ethernet details.
  • Link aggregation information.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if LLDP was disabled.

2.60.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to send and receive LLDP. The following table shows the LLDP status on individual network interfaces.

Table 100: LLDP interface status on router03.nipper.org
Interface Active LLDP Send LLDP Receive Description
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes On On First interface on switch
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes On On Second interface on switch

2.60.2 Impact

LLDP packets contain information about the sender and the network that an attacker would find useful as part of a targeted attack. The following is an example capture using the "tcpdump" tool. It provides a good example of some of the information an attacker could obtain from LLDP.

16:42:20.305995 LLDP, length 523
    Chassis ID TLV (1), length 7
      Subtype MAC address (4): cc:d5:39:33:46:00 (oui Unknown)
    Port ID TLV (2), length 9
      Subtype Interface Name (5): Gi2/0/40
    Time to Live TLV (3), length 2: TTL 120s
    System Name TLV (5), length 19: switch-01.mg-it.net
    System Description TLV (6), length 248
      Cisco IOS Software, C2960S Software (C2960S-UNIVERSALK9-M), Version 12.2(58)SE2, RELEASE SOFTWARE (fc1)
      Technical Support: http://www.cisco.com/techsupport
      Copyright (c) 1986-2011 by Cisco Systems, Inc.
      Compiled Thu 21-Jul-11 02:22 by prod_rel_team
    Port Description TLV (4), length 21: GigabitEthernet2/0/40
    System Capabilities TLV (7), length 4
      System  Capabilities [Bridge, Router] (0x0014)
      Enabled Capabilities [Bridge] (0x0004)
    Management Address TLV (8), length 12
      Management Address length 5, AFI IPv4 (1): 172.42.24.10
      System Port Number Interface Numbering (3): 0
    Organization specific TLV (127), length 7: OUI ANSI/TIA (0x0012bb)
      LLDP-MED Capabilities Subtype (1)
        Media capabilities [LLDP-MED capabilities, network policy, location identification, extended power via MDI-PSE, Inventory] (0x002f)
        Device type [network connectivity] (0x04)

The example LLDP information above, includes the platform and software version details. Using that information an attacker could then search vulnerability databases, such as NVD to identify any vulnerabilities that could be exploited. If the attacker identifies a vulnerability, they could then follow the information described to exploit the issue or search the Internet for exploit code.

2.60.3 Ease

LLDP packets are broadcast to an entire network segment. The attacker or malicious user would require access to a network segment on which the LLDP packets are broadcast and network monitoring software. A wide variety of network monitoring, packet capture and analysis tools can be downloaded from the Internet. Tools like:

  • Wireshark, which is a graphical packet capture tool used by networking specialists (https://www.wireshark.org/)
  • TCPDump, which is a command line packet capture tool (https://www.tcpdump.org/)

2.60.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, LLDP should be disabled.

2.60.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

LLDP can be disabled globally or on individual interfaces using the following Cisco IOS device commands:

no lldp run
interface <interface>
    no lldp transmit
    no lldp receive

2.60.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0008
  • IEEE: IEEE 802.1ab
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_Layer_Discovery_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • CDP Was Enabled (see section 2.59).

2.61 IP Source Routing Was Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.61.1 Finding

TCP/IP packets can contain source route information, this can enable a packet to define its own route through a network rather than using a route defined by static routes or routing protocols. The source route option functionality was defined in RFC 791.

Some network routers, and multipurpose devices, include facilities that enable them to ignore the source route defined in a packet or block the packets entirely.

2.61.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that IP source routing was enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.61.2 Impact

IP source routing can allow an attacker to specify a route for a network packet to follow, possibly to bypass a Firewall device or an Intrusion Detection System (IDS). An attacker could also use source routing to capture network traffic by routing it through a system controlled by the attacker.

2.61.3 Ease

An attacker would have to control either a routing device or an end point device in order to modify a packets route through the network. However, tools can be downloaded from the Internet that would allow an attacker to specify source routes. Tools are also available to modify network routing using vulnerabilities in some routing protocols.

2.61.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that IP source routing information contained in network packets should be ignored.

2.61.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

IP source routing can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

no ip source-route

2.61.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable IP source routing on the device. (Risk Level - Low)

no ip source-route

2.61.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0020
  • Classification: Routing
  • Wikipedia: Disable *ABBREV*IP*-ABBREV* source routing

2.62 SNMP Access With No View

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.62.1 Finding

SNMP is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. Views are used to restrict access to specific sections of the SNMP MIB. This enables an administrator to restrict SNMP access to only the information that the caller requires.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all usable SNMP community strings were configured with a view to limit their access.

2.62.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 101: SNMP Community Strings With No View
Community Access Version View ACL IPv6 ACL
public Read Only 1   20  
private Read/Write 1      

2.62.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, who has SNMP access using a community string for which no view had been configured would have unrestricted access to the SNMP MIB.

2.62.3 Ease

With no SNMP view configured, an attacker would not be restricted to specific sections of the SNMP MIB.

2.62.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. If SNMP is required then Nipper recommends that a view is configured for every community string in order to limit the access to only those sections of the MIB that are required.

2.62.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

A SNMP view can be configured and then assigned to a community string with the following commands:

snmp-server view <view-name> <oid> {included | excluded}
snmp-server community <community-string> [view <view-name>] [ro | rw] [<acl-number>]

2.62.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0007
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

It is worth noting that this issue could be mitigated by fixing the following:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15).

2.63 SNMP Access Without Network Filtering

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Easy
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.63.1 Finding

SNMP is an industry standard protocol for monitoring and managing a variety of devices. SNMP services typically offer detailed information that includes a device's operating system, network interfaces, memory, system counters and system users. Access to the SNMP service can be restricted to specific Network Management System (NMS), or SNMP management hosts, using a filter list.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all usable SNMP community strings were configured with filtering to restrict access from specific network hosts.

2.63.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one SNMP community strings on router03.nipper.org that did not have an assigned filter list. Those community strings are described in the following table.

Table 102: SNMP Community Strings With No Filter
Community Access Version View ACL IPv6 ACL
private Read/Write 1      

2.63.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with a community string for the SNMP agent, could gain access to the data offered by the service. With no network filtering the attacker would not be restricted by the device from connecting to the service. Additionally, if a software vulnerability existed in the service, then the attacker may be able to exploit the vulnerability without requiring knowledge of a community string.

2.63.3 Ease

An attacker would not be prevented from connecting to the SNMP agent. SNMP query tools are included by default with some operating systems and further query tools can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.63.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. If SNMP is required then Nipper recommends that only SNMP version 3 should be configured. If access using community strings is required, Nipper recommends that network filtering should be configured to restrict access to the service.

2.63.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following commands can be used to configure an ACL and assign it to a community string:

access-list <acl-number> permit <ip-address> <network-mask> log
access-list <acl-number> deny any log
snmp-server community <community-string> [view <view-name>] [ro | rw] [<acl-number>]

2.63.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0006
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

It is worth noting that this issue could be mitigated by fixing the following:

  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15).

2.64 Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Low
  • Impact: Medium
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.64.1 Finding

SNMPv3, like prior versions, provides remote access for the monitoring and administration of a device. Version 3 adds various levels of security and privacy. This enables a SNMPv3 user to have:

  • communication without authentication and privacy encryption (NoAuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and without privacy encryption (AuthNoPriv);
  • communication with authentication hashing and privacy encryption (AuthPriv).

SNMPv3 allows for a variety of different authentication hashing algorithms and privacy encryption algorithms to protect the authentication and data in transit.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if SNMP users were configured to use only FIPS 140-2 authentication hashes.

2.64.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following two SNMP users on router03.nipper.org that were not configured with FIPS 140-2 compliant authentication hashing.

Table 103: Non FIPS 140-2 compliant SNMP user authentication
User Host Port Version Security Auth Auth Password Priv Priv Password ACL IPv6 ACL
Test   N/A 3 Auth MD5 (NO PASSWORD) N/A N/A    
test   N/A 3 Auth+Priv MD5 (NO PASSWORD) AES-192 (NO PASSWORD)    

2.64.2 Impact

An attacker who was able to gain access to the authentication hash, possibly by monitoring the network traffic, could attempt to gain access to the password from the hash. With read access to the SNMP MIB an attacker would be able to enumerate a large quantity of information about the device, its configuration, network details and more. With write access to the SNMP MIB an attacker could reconfigure the device, potentially causing a DoS. Additionally, write access to SNMP on some devices would enable an attacker to download a copy of a device's configuration, including password hashes.

2.64.3 Ease

Packet capture tools, password brute force and SNMP management tools can all be downloaded from the Internet. Some OS may install some of those tools by default.

2.64.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a FIPS authentication hashing algorithm should be configured for all SNMPv3 users.

2.64.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

SNMP version 3 is configured by creating a group and then by adding users to the group. The following commands can be used to create a group and add a user to it:

snmp-server group <group-name> v3 {noauth | auth | priv} [read <read-view>] [write <write-view>] [notify <notify-view>] [access <acl>]
snmp-server user <username> <group-name> v3 [auth {md5 | sha} <auth-password>] [access <acl>]

2.64.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0021
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (see section 2.73).

2.65 DNS Lookups Were Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.65.1 Finding

Some network devices can be configured to make use of Domain Name System (DNS) to perform lookups of addresses that have been specified using a DNS name. In addition to being used for connecting to other devices, the DNS lookup functionality could be used for auditing purposes.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if DNS Lookups were disabled.

2.65.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the DNS lookup feature was enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.65.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to monitor DNS queries from the device that could then potentially be used as part of a targeted attack. Some devices include functionality to automatically connect to a device if an administrator simply types in a device's DNS name. Unfortunately this also means that if an administrator mistypes an administrative command the device will automatically perform a lookup for the device and attempt to connect to it. Cisco IOS-based devices perform this action, but it could enable an attacker to perform a MITM attack if the attacker were to immediately respond to the DNS query, allow the incoming connection to attackers system and then connect straight back to the sender.

2.65.3 Ease

Tools that can monitor DNS queries can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.65.4 Recommendation

Nipper suggests that, if not required, DNS lookups should be disabled.

2.65.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Domain lookups can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices with the following commands (the latter command is for Cisco IOS 12.1 and older):

no ip domain lookup
no ip domain-lookup

2.65.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-DNS-0001
  • RFCs: RFC 1033, RFC 1034, RFC 1035
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System

2.66 Filter Rules Allow Any IP

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.66.1 Finding

Network filtering rules are typically configured to enable hosts to access a specific network service or services. Therefore a network filter rule which enables access to a secure web service could be configured to access a specific destination host on TCP port 443. However, it is possible to configure the filter rule to allow access using all IP protocols which, for the previous example, would enable access to port 443 using TCP and UDP.

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any filter rules that allow all IP protocols.

2.66.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in named-acl-1 on router03.nipper.org that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 104: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1 allowing Any IP
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified two filter rules configured in named-acl-2 on router03.nipper.org that allowed Any IP. Those filter rules are shown in the table below.

Table 105: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2 allowing Any IP
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in 120 on router03.nipper.org that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 106: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120 allowing Any IP
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in FILTER_IPV6 on router03.nipper.org that allowed Any IP. That filter rule is shown in the table below. All access to Any IP was denied in 5.

Table 107: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6 allowing Any IP
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No

2.66.2 Impact

If a network protocol is not specified then it an attacker would not be prevented from accessing hosts and services detailed in the finding using protocols other than those which the services are listening on. This could enable an attacker to gain unauthorized access to a network service or leave unfiltered network ports which an attacker could utilize in a targeted attack.

2.66.3 Ease

With no specific network protocol configured on the network filtering rules identified, access attempts using a network protocol other than the one that was intended would not be prevented by the filtering.

2.66.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network filter rules should be configured to use only the specific protocols required.

2.66.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

2.66.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0017
  • Classification: Filtering

2.67 Filter Rules Allow ICMP

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.67.1 Finding

ICMP is an IP protocol that is commonly used by network administrators for network diagnostic purposes. However, ICMP can be used to send a number of different control messages between networked systems, such as destination unreachable, time exceeded, echo request and echo reply (used by the ping utility).

Nipper examined the device configuration to identify any filter rules that allow ICMP.

2.67.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in named-acl-1 on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 108: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified two filter rules configured in named-acl-2 on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. Those filter rules are shown in the table below.

Table 109: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified eight filter rules configured in cp-critical-in on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. Those filter rules are shown in the table below. All access to ICMP packets was denied in rule 41 for IPv4.

Table 110: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in allowing ICMP packets
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
33 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
34 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
35 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
36 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
37 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
38 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
39 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
40 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No

Nipper did not identify any filter rule in 110 on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. The configuration of 110 is shown the table below.

Table 111: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified one filter rule configured in 120 on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. That filter rule is shown in the table below.

Table 112: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified two filter rules configured in FILTER_IPV6 on router03.nipper.org that allowed ICMP packets. Those filter rules are shown in the table below. All access to ICMP packets was denied in rule 5 for IPv6.

Table 113: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6 allowing ICMP packets
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.67.2 Impact

Although ICMP is useful for network administrators who wish to determine if a network device is reachable or is responding, an attacker could also use ICMP to enumerate potential targets. Furthermore, a number of ICMP message types can be used to enumerate basic host and network information. Even the most minor information may be useful to an attacker who may then use that information as part of a targeted attack.

It is worth noting that issues with a host incorrectly processing ICMP messages has been known to lead to a DoS condition.

2.67.3 Ease

Many platforms include a basic set of ICMP tools, such as ping which uses ICMP echo messages. Additionally, a number of more sophisticated ICMP tools can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.67.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, where possible, network filter rules should be configured to drop all ICMP traffic.

2.67.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.67.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0009
  • Classification: Filtering
  • RFCs: RFC 792, RFC 4443
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol_for_IPv6

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled (see section 2.56);
  • ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.57);
  • ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.58);
  • ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.71).

2.68 Filter Rules Deny Without Logging

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.68.1 Finding

Network filter rules can be configured to log an access attempt when network traffic matches a specific filter rule. The network filter rule logging facility helps network administrators to diagnose issues, determine a rules usage and provide an audit trail for network traffic accessing specific hosts and services.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all deny filter rules were configured to log.

2.68.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org that did not log blocked traffic. Those rules are detailed below.

Table 114: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org that did not log blocked traffic. This rule is detailed below.

Table 115: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
41 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org that did not log blocked traffic. This rule is detailed below.

Table 116: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
8 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org that did not log blocked traffic. This rule is detailed below.

Table 117: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No

2.68.2 Impact

It is common for an attacker to perform network reconnaissance in order to identify potential target hosts and services. An attackers reconnaissance phase can vary greatly in intensity and covertness, but any network scans that match network filter rules that are not configured to log will not be record the activity.

Logging access attempts to network hosts and services that are filtered using drop rules provides useful information about an attackers activities, and could be useful as evidence in any legal action taken. With no logging of drop filter rules the information would not be recorded for use by network administrators, auditors or a network forensic team. Furthermore log monitoring software, if configured, would not alert network administrators of a potential attack in progress.

2.68.3 Ease

An attackers attempts to access network services which are protected by the drop filter rules detailed in the finding would not be logged.

2.68.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network filter rules that drop network traffic should be configured to log the access attempt.

2.68.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

2.68.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0014
  • Classification: Filtering

2.69 Filter Rules Allow Without Logging

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.69.1 Finding

Network filter rules can be configured to log an access attempt when network traffic matches a specific filter rule. The network filter rule logging facility helps network administrators to diagnose issues, determine a rules usage and provide an audit trail for network traffic accessing specific hosts and services.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if all filter rules that allow were configured to log.

2.69.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. This allow rule is detailed below.

Table 118: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified two rules in filter list "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. Those allow rules are detailed below.

Table 119: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified 34 rules in filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. Those allow rules are detailed below.

Table 120: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
5 212.241.243.217 212.241.243.218 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
6 212.241.243.217 212.241.243.218 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
7 192.168.224.154 192.168.224.153 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
8 192.168.224.154 192.168.224.153 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
9 192.168.224.150 192.168.224.149 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
10 192.168.224.150 192.168.224.149 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
11 192.168.224.162 192.168.224.161 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No

13 192.168.123.123 192.192.192.192 TCP from any port to port 21 Connection State: Any No
14 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 UDP from any port to port 67 Connection State: Any No
15 10.1.23.1 Any IPv4 UDP from port 67 to port 67 Connection State: Any No
