Connection State: Any		 No
23 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: Any No
24 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any No
26 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
27 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
29 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any No
30 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to ports 56-62 Connection State: Any No
31 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
32 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
33 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
34 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
35 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
36 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
37 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
38 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
39 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
40 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "110" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. This allow rule is detailed below.

Table 121: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper identified six rules in filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. Those allow rules are detailed below.

Table 122: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
4 192.168.20.10 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
5 192.168.20.12 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
6 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org that did not log allowed traffic. This allow rule is detailed below.

Table 123: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No

2.69.2 Impact

It is common for an attacker to perform network reconnaissance in order to identify potential target hosts and services. An attackers reconnaissance phase can vary greatly in intensity and covertness, but any network scans that match network filter rules that are not configured to log will not be recorded.

Logging access attempts to network hosts and services that are filtered using allow rules provides useful information about an attackers activities, enabling a network administrators to determine which hosts and services were accessed. The information collected would also be useful as evidence in case any legal action were to be taken against the attacker. With no logging of allow filter rules the information would not be recorded for use by network administrators, auditors or a network forensic team. Additionally, with no logging of allow filter rules network administrators may not be able to determine which hosts were accessed by an attacker and log monitoring software, if configured, would not alert network administrators of a potential attack in progress.

2.69.3 Ease

An attacker's attempts to access network services covered by the allow filter rules detailed in the finding would not be logged.

2.69.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network filter rules that allow network traffic should be configured to log the access attempt.

2.69.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On IOS versions prior to 12.2 to modify an ACE the ACL would have to be removed and then re-created. For newer IOS versions you can modify ACE by deleting the ACE using its rule number and then adding a new ACE. To remove an ACE and add a new one to a named ACL using the rule numbers you can use the following commands:

ip access-list [standard | extended] <acl-name>
    no <rule-number>
    <rule-number> <ace-rule>

2.69.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0015
  • Classification: Filtering

2.70 Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.70.1 Finding

Network filtering is used to restrict access to network services and devices from only those systems that are authorized to access them. For public facing services this could be allowing all remote hosts to connect to a specific service. For remote administrative services this could be to allow only a specific address access to a range of administrative services.

Whilst many devices define filter rules in a single list for the entire device, or network. Some network devices define filter rule lists that are then assigned to specific network interfaces, applying filtering to only the traffic entering or leaving those interfaces.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if inbound or outbound filtering had been configured on all network interfaces.

2.70.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 124: Network interfaces with inadequate filtering assigned
Interface Class Active Address Filtering Description
GigabitEthernet1/1 Internal Yes 10.0.0.1   First interface on switch

2.70.2 Impact

The network traffic from an attacker attached to one of the network interfaces detailed in the finding would not be subjected to filtering, potentially providing unrestricted access to network services.

2.70.3 Ease

The network traffic would not be subjected to filtering.

2.70.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all network interfaces should be configured with filtering to help prevent unauthorized access to network services and hosts.

2.70.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Cisco IOS device filtering can be configured on interfaces with the following command:

ip access-group <ACL> [in | out]

2.70.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-INTR-0001
  • Classification: Filtering

2.71 ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.71.1 Finding

When sending network traffic through a router, ICMP redirect messages could be sent to the router in order to indicate a specific route that the sending host would like the network traffic to take. On a router that accepts ICMP redirect message the network traffic will be forwarded using the specified route. Furthermore, some routers will cache the new routing information for use with future network packets.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if ICMP IP Redirects had been disabled.

2.71.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Table 125: Interfaces with ICMP IP Redirects
Interface Active Address Unreachables Redirects Mask Reply Info Reply
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 10.0.0.1 On On On Off

It is worth noting that ICMP IP Redirects is not applicable on those interfaces without an IPv4 address.

The scope of the network interfaces examined was limited to IPv4 layer-3 network interfaces and have support for ICMP IP Redirects. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/1 was the only network interface included in the scope of this check. The network interface GigabitEthernet1/2 was the only network interface excluded from the scope of this check.

2.71.2 Impact

An attacker could use ICMP redirects to modify the route that a packet takes through a network. However, it is worth noting that on networks with functional network routing, disabling ICMP redirects will have little to no effect.

2.71.3 Ease

ICMP redirect messages will be accepted, but not necessarily acted upon. An attacker could download software from the Internet in order to perform this attack.

2.71.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, the processing of ICMP redirect messages on devices should be disabled.

2.71.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

ICMP redirect message sending can be disabled on network interfaces with the following command:

no ip redirects

2.71.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0013
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Control_Message_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled (see section 2.56);
  • ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.57);
  • ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (see section 2.58);
  • Filter Rules Allow ICMP (see section 2.67).

2.72 PAD Service Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.72.1 Finding

The Packet Assembler / Disassembler (PAD) service enables X.25 commands and connections between PAD devices and access servers, converting the character stream data into network packets and network packets into character stream data. The PAD service is enabled by default on some devices but it is only required if support for X.25 links are necessary.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the PAD service was disabled.

2.72.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the PAD service was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.72.2 Impact

In addition to the extra overhead, running unused services increases the chances of an attacker finding a security hole or fingerprinting a device.

2.72.3 Ease

The PAD service was enabled.

2.72.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, the PAD service should be disabled.

2.72.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The following command can be used to disable the PAD service on Cisco IOS devices:

no service pad

2.72.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the PAcket Assembler/Disassembler service that is used to support X.25 links. (Risk Level - Low)

no service pad

2.72.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0011
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_assembler/disassembler

2.73 Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Low
  • Ease: Moderate
  • Fix: Planned
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.73.1 Finding

SNMP traps and informs can be configured to send notifications to a SNMP NMS host. Trap notifications are sent without any confirmation of receipt from the receiving host, whilst with inform notifications the receiving host sends a confirmation of receipt. Community strings can be configured for traps and inform notifications to provide a method of authentication.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that no dictionary-based SNMP Traps community strings are configured.

2.73.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified two dictionary-based SNMP Traps community strings on router03.nipper.org. These are detailed in the table below.

Table 126: Dictionary-based SNMP Traps community strings
Host Type Version Security Community Notifications Port Key Strength
192.168.20.30 Trap 1 Community private snmp 162 Dictionary-based
192.168.20.40 Trap 1 Community private snmp 162 Dictionary-based

2.73.2 Impact

An attacker who had identified a dictionary-based community string could flood the SNMP NMS host with false notification messages. The false notification messages could be used by an attacker to hide an attack within a flood of false notifications or as part of a DoS attack.

2.73.3 Ease

SNMP management tools can be downloaded from the Internet and some OS install SNMP management tools by default. Although the sending of notification messages is not usually the primary purpose of most of these tools, the configuration of these tools for sending notification messages is usually detailed in the tools documentation.

2.73.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, SNMP should be disabled. However, if the sending of traps is required, Nipper recommends that a strong community string should be configured to authenticate all notification messages with a SNMP NMS host.

Nipper recommends that:

  • SNMP community strings should be at least ten characters in length;
  • characters in the SNMP community string should not be repeated more than three times;
  • SNMP community strings should include both upper case and lower case characters;
  • SNMP community strings should include numbers;
  • SNMP community strings should not include a device's name, make or model;
  • SNMP community strings should not be based on dictionary words.

2.73.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

A SNMP trap can be configured with the following command:

snmp-server host <ip-address> traps [version {1 | 2c | 3 [noauth | auth | priv]}] <community-string>

2.73.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-SNMP-0005
  • Classification: Administration, Authentication, Clear-Text
  • RFCs: RFC 1157, RFC 3416
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Management_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (see section 2.3);
  • Clear-Text SNMP In Use (see section 2.15);
  • SNMP Write Access Enabled (see section 2.16);
  • SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (see section 2.28);
  • No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (see section 2.48);
  • SNMP Access With No View (see section 2.62);
  • SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (see section 2.63);
  • Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (see section 2.64).

2.74 Unrestricted Outbound Administrative Access

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Challenging
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.74.1 Finding

Many network devices, such as switches and routers, contain network client tools that enable a network administrator to connect to administrative services offered by other devices. Outbound access from these devices to others can be restricted to specific host addresses in order to limit the access to only those that are required.

Nipper examined all usable administative VTY lines to determine that they had been configured with an outbound ACL.

2.74.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

The configuration of the administrative lines on router03.nipper.org are detailed in Table 127.

Table 127: Administrative line settings on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Level Password Telnet SSH Filter In Filter Out
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password Yes Yes 40  

2.74.2 Impact

A malicious user, or attacker, with a basic level of access to the device could use it to attack other devices on the network. An attacker may prefer to use this facility as a way of masking their trail or because the target device may not be contactable directly. If an outbound ACL had been configured then the potential list of targets would be restricted to only those network addresses.

2.74.3 Ease

The attacker must have a level of access to the device in order to be able to use the administrative service client tools to access another system. However, once a level of access has been gained on the device the attacker would then be able to use the available client tools to access services offered by other devices.

2.74.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, unless required, an outbound ACL should be configured and assigned in order to restrict administrative access to other systems.

2.74.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices an outbound ACL can be created and assigned to an administrative line using the following commands:

ip access-list standard <access-list-number>
    remark <description>
    permit <ip-address> <wildcard> [log]
    exit
line <line-type> <line-number(s)>
    access-class <access-list-number> out

2.74.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0024
  • Classification: Administration, Filtering

2.75 TCP Small Services Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.75.1 Finding

Some devices and platforms provide a collection of simple TCP network services, which are also sometimes referred to as small services. These services provide little functionality and are rarely used and they typically include:

  • Echo (defined in RFC 862) returns any data sent to it back to the connecting client
  • Discard (defined in RFC 863) ignores any data sent to it by a connecting client
  • Chargen (defined in RFC 864) generates printable characters which are returned to the connecting client
  • Daytime (defined in RFC 867) returns the current time to a connecting client

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the TCP Small Servers service was disabled.

2.75.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that TCP Small Servers were enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.75.2 Impact

Each running service increases the chances of an attacker being able to identify the device and successfully compromise it. Although not significant, some of the services may provide an attacker with simple information that could then be used as part of a targeted attack against the system.

2.75.3 Ease

Tools such as Telnet can be used to connect to these services and are often installed by default.

2.75.4 Recommendation

It is generally considered good security practice to disable all unused services and not running the services will free system resources for other use. Therefore Nipper suggests that the TCP small servers should be disabled.

2.75.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

TCP small servers can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices with the following command:

no service tcp-small-servers

2.75.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the TCP Small Servers service on the device. TCP small services are of little use and are commonly considered non-production or legacy services. (Risk Level - Safe)

no tcp-small-servers

2.75.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0035
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 862, RFC 863, RFC 864, RFC 867
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discard_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character_Generator_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • UDP Small Services Enabled (see section 2.76).

2.76 UDP Small Services Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.76.1 Finding

Some devices and platforms provide a collection of simple UDP network services, which are also sometimes referred to as small services. These services provide little functionality and are rarely used and they typically include:

  • Echo (defined in RFC 862) returns any data sent to it back to the connecting client
  • Discard (defined in RFC 863) ignores any data sent to it by a connecting client
  • Chargen (defined in RFC 864) generates printable characters which are returned to the connecting client

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the UDP Small Servers service was disabled.

2.76.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that UDP Small Servers were enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.76.2 Impact

An attacker could use the UDP small servers as part of a DoS attack. UDP is a connection-less protocol and an experienced attacker could forge network packets to use the echo and chargen services to increase the network traffic and system utilization of devices offering the services. Additionally, each running service increases the chances of an attacker being able to identify the device and successfully compromise it. Although not as significant, some of the services may provide an attacker with simple information that could then be used as part of a targeted attack against the system.

2.76.3 Ease

Tools that can be used to connect to these services are installed by default on some systems or can be downloaded from the Internet.

2.76.4 Recommendation

It is generally considered good security practice to disable all unused services and not running the services will free system resources for other use. Therefore Nipper suggests that the UDP small servers should be disabled.

2.76.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

UDP small servers can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices with the following command:

no service udp-small-servers

2.76.4.2 router03.nipper.org Remediation

The following will disable the UDP Small Servers service on the device. UDP small services are of little use and are commonly considered non-production or legacy services. (Risk Level - Safe)

no udp-small-servers

2.76.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ADM-0044
  • Classification: Administration
  • RFCs: RFC 862, RFC 863, RFC 864
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discard_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character_Generator_Protocol

The following findings are related to this one:

  • TCP Small Services Enabled (see section 2.75).

2.77 No Post Logon Banner Message

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.77.1 Finding

Post logon banner messages are ones that are shown to users after they have authenticated and prior to being given access to the device. It is one that is shown to users when they connect to a device and prior to the user logon.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the device had a post-login banner message configured.

2.77.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

There was no post-logon banner message configured on router03.nipper.org.

2.77.2 Impact

The post logon banner is useful for detailing the acceptable use policy and the change control procedures which should be followed prior to making any changes to a device's configuration. An acceptable use message detailing the change control procedures and waning against abuse of the policy could help to prevent ad-hoc changes being made to a device's configuration.

2.77.3 Ease

With no post logon banner configured, a user would not be given a reminder of the acceptable use and change control procedure policy details.

2.77.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a post logon banner message is configured that details both the acceptable use policy and change control procedures. Additionally, if the device does not support a pre-logon banner message then Nipper recommends that the post logon banner message should also include a carefully worded legal warning against unauthorized access.

2.77.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

The Exec banner message is shown after logon and before the command prompt is shown on Cisco IOS devices. The Exec banner message can be configured on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

banner exec <delimiter> <banner-message> <delimiter>

2.77.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-BAN-0002
  • Classification: Administration

2.78 Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.78.1 Finding

Network devices that are capable of performing network filtering will usually drop all network traffic when it does not match any of the configured network filter rules. However, this network traffic is also usually excluded from logging when a network filter rule does not apply.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine if the filter rule list contained an explicit deny all and log to prevent any further network access if a specific allow rule is not defined and log the denied traffic.

2.78.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that "named-acl-1" on router03.nipper.org was configured to allow all traffic in rule 3.

Table 128: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that "named-acl-2" on router03.nipper.org did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 129: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-2
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 192.168.76.4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 172.18.19.1 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org was configured to deny all traffic in rule 41, but without logging.

Table 130: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 10.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
2 100.64.0.0/10 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
3 127.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input

25 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any Yes
26 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
27 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
28 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any Yes
29 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any No
30 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to ports 56-62 Connection State: Any No
31 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
32 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
CSM Probes ICMP
33 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
34 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
35 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
36 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
37 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
38 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
39 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
40 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
41 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper determined that "110" on router03.nipper.org did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 131: Extended IPv4 ACL: 110
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to any port No

Nipper determined that "120" on router03.nipper.org did not contain a rule to specifically deny all traffic.

Table 132: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
4 192.168.20.10 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
5 192.168.20.12 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
6 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
8 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

2.78.2 Impact

It is common for an attacker to perform network reconnaissance in order to identify potential target hosts and services. An attackers reconnaissance phase can vary greatly in intensity and covertness, but any network scans which do not match the configured filter rules will not be logged.

The log information collected would be useful as evidence in case any legal action were to be taken against the attacker. Without any logging of the network traffic that does not match any of the filter rules, the information would not be recorded for use by network administrators, auditors or a network forensic team.

2.78.3 Ease

Any network traffic that does not match any network filter rules will not be logged.

2.78.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that a drop all and log filter rule should be added to filter rule lists to prevent further access and log those attempts.

2.78.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

A drop all and log ACE can be added to standard and extended ACL using the following ACL commands:

deny any log
deny ip any any log

A drop all and log IPv6 ACE can be added to an ACL using the following ACL command:

deny ipv6 any any log

2.78.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0026
  • Classification: Filtering

2.79 Unused Filter Rules

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.79.1 Finding

It is possible to configure active network filter rules that will never be used by a filtering device. Network filtering is performed by matching network traffic against a list of configured filter rules. These rules are processed sequentially and the configured action will be performed for the first filter rule that matches the traffic. If network filter rules exist after a filter rule that blocks all network traffic, then those rules will never be used.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all allow filter rules had time restrictions to limit when the traffic will be permitted.

2.79.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified one rule in filter list "cp-critical-in" on router03.nipper.org that was unused. Filter rule 15 would never be actioned because rule 1, which is defined earlier, will have already matched the traffic.

Table 133: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 10.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
2 100.64.0.0/10 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
3 127.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
4 169.254.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any Yes + Input
Control plane critical traffic - inbound
BGP
5 212.241.243.217 212.241.243.218 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
6 212.241.243.217 212.241.243.218 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
7 192.168.224.154 192.168.224.153 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
8 192.168.224.154 192.168.224.153 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
9 192.168.224.150 192.168.224.149 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
10 192.168.224.150 192.168.224.149 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
11 192.168.224.162 192.168.224.161 TCP from any port to port 179 Connection State: Any No
12 192.168.224.162 192.168.224.161 TCP from port 179 to any port Connection State: Any No
13 192.168.123.123 192.192.192.192 TCP from any port to port 21 Connection State: Any No
DHCP
14 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 UDP from any port to port 67 Connection State: Any No
15 10.1.23.1 Any IPv4 UDP from port 67 to port 67 Connection State: Any No
CSM Probes HTTP
16 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 80 Connection State: Any No
17 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 80 Connection State: Any No
18 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: Any No
19 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: ESTABLISHED No
20 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 80 Connection State: Any No
21 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 80 Connection State: Any No
22 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 80 to any port Fragments
Connection State: Any		 No
23 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 80 to any port Connection State: Any No
CSM Probes HTTPS
24 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any No
25 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any Yes
26 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
27 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
28 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any Yes
29 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to port 443 Connection State: Any No
30 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 TCP from any port to ports 56-62 Connection State: Any No
31 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
32 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 TCP from port 443 to any port Connection State: Any No
CSM Probes ICMP
33 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
34 192.168.224.10 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
35 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
36 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.10 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
37 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.51 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
38 192.168.224.11 192.168.224.52 ICMP Echo Connection State: Any No
39 192.168.224.51 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
40 192.168.224.52 192.168.224.11 ICMP Echo Reply Connection State: Any No
41 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No

Nipper identified four rules in filter list "120" on router03.nipper.org that were unused. Those rules were:

  • Filter rule 8 would never be actioned because rule 7, which is defined earlier, will have already matched the traffic;
  • Filter rule 8 would never be actioned because rule 6, which is defined earlier, will have already matched the traffic;
  • Filter rules 4 and 5 would never be actioned because rule 3, which is defined earlier, will have already matched the traffic;
  • Filter rules 4 and 5 would never be actioned because rule 3, which is defined earlier, will have already matched the traffic.
Table 134: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
1 50.60.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port No
2 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from port 21 to any port Yes + Input
3 Any IPv4 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
4 192.168.20.10 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
5 192.168.20.12 192.168.30.40 TCP from any port to port 161 No
6 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
7 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
8 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No

Nipper identified four rules in filter list "FILTER_IPV6" on router03.nipper.org that were unused. Those rules were:

  • Filter rule 2 would match all network packets. Therefore, rules 6, 5, 4 and 3, which are defined after, will never be matched.
Table 135: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
4 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Type 4 No
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No
6 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::/64 Any IP from any port to any port   Yes

2.79.2 Impact

Although unused network filter rules are not a direct threat to security, the rules could make interpreting a filter rule list more difficult. This could lead a network administrator to add additional, or more relaxed, filter rules that enable an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network services.

2.79.3 Ease

An attacker will only be able to exploit this issue if it leads to a network administrator adding additional, or more relaxed, filter rules by mistake. Enabling an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network hosts and services.

2.79.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all unused network filter rules should be removed.

2.79.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

On Cisco IOS devices network filter rules can be deleted by entering the appropriate configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

An IPv6 ACE can be deleted from an ACL by entering the ACL configuration context and then negating the rule. This can be done using the following command:

no <filter-rule-to-delete>

2.79.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0028
  • Classification: Filtering

2.80 Unassigned Filter Rule Lists

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.80.1 Finding

Network filter rule lists can be assigned to specific network interfaces, services or protocols on some types of devices. It can be possible on those devices to have network filter rule lists which have not been assigned to anything and are therefore redundant.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all filter rule lists had been assigned.

2.80.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that the following five filter lists on router03.nipper.org were potentially unused:

  • named-acl-1
  • named-acl-2
  • cp-critical-in
  • 110
  • 120

2.80.2 Impact

Although unused network filter rule lists are not a direct threat to security. However, unused filter rule lists can make interpreting the configured network filtering unclear and potentially lead to the addition of filter rules that enable an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network services.

2.80.3 Ease

An attacker will only be able to exploit this issue if it leads to a network administrator adding additional, or more relaxed, filter rules by mistake. Enabling an attacker to gain unauthorized access to network hosts and services.

2.80.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that all unassigned network filter rule lists should be removed.

2.80.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Numbered and named ACL can be deleted on Cisco IOS devices using the following commands:

no access-list <acl>
no ip access-list <acl>

IPv6 ACL can be deleted on Cisco IOS devices using the following command:

no ipv6 access-list <acl>

2.80.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-FLT-0029
  • Classification: Filtering

2.81 Switch Ports Allow Trunking All VLAN

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.81.1 Finding

VLAN network packets can be sent between networked devices, extending a VLAN across different physical devices. In order to extend a VLAN to a different physical device a trunk has to be created between the devices. In order to restrict VLAN access over different physical devices the VLAN trunk can be configured to only permit specific VLANs.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that all VLAN trunking network interfaces trunk only specific VLAN.

2.81.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper identified the following two interfaces on router03.nipper.org that were configured to trunk all VLAN.

Table 136: Network interfaces that trunk all VLAN on router03.nipper.org
Interface Active Address VLAN Trunk Trunk VLAN Description
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes 10.0.0.1   N/A   First interface on switch
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes 10.0.0.2
1e7f:4d:1::32/64		 1 Auto All Second interface on switch

2.81.2 Impact

An attacker who is able to create a trunk would gain direct access to all the VLANs extended over the trunk. This would allow an attacker to bypass any network filtering between the VLANs and capture potentially sensitive information. If a clear-text protocols network traffic is transferred over the trunk an attacker would gain immediate access to any authentication credentials transferred.

It is worth noting that some network devices default to allowing trunks to be negotiated on the network ports and by default will allow access to all VLANs.

2.81.3 Ease

Tools can be downloaded from the Internet that are capable of creating trunks, or the attacker could use a network switch. The attacker would require a little knowledge of network trunking.

2.81.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, VLAN trunking should be disabled. If trunking is required on a specific switch port, Nipper recommends that the switch port should be configured to trunk only the required VLANs.

2.81.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Switch ports can be configured to provide no trunking or only trunk specific VLANs on each interface using the following interface commands:

switchport mode access
switchport trunk allowed vlan <vlan-list>

2.81.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-INTR-0004
  • IEEE: IEEE 802.1Q, IEEE 802.1ad, IEEE 802.1ah
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VLAN

2.82 MOP Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.82.1 Finding

Maintenance Operations Protocol (MOP) is used with the DECnet protocol suite and was used to provide remote administration access. Although the use of MOP is not widespread, and is considered legacy, it is still enabled by default on a number of popular network infrastructure device products.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that MOP was disabled on all network interfaces.

2.82.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that MOP was enabled on router03.nipper.org. The following table shows the MOP status on individual network interfaces.

Table 137: MOP interface status on router03.nipper.org
Interface Active MOP ACL In ACL Out Description
GigabitEthernet1/1 Yes On     First interface on switch
GigabitEthernet1/2 Yes On     Second interface on switch

2.82.2 Impact

Running unused services increases the chances of an attacker finding a security hole or fingerprinting a device.

2.82.3 Ease

Few tools are available that make use of MOP.

2.82.4 Recommendation

Nipper recommends that, if not required, MOP should be disabled on all network interfaces.

2.82.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

It is worth noting that this issue may have been falsely determined on Cisco IOS switches as MOP functionality is no longer being supported on the most up-to-date devices. If MOP is supported on your device it can be disabled on individual network interfaces using the following command: 

no mop enable

And the following command can be used to determine whether your device is running MOP: 

show subsys | inc mop

2.82.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-PRO-0010
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maintenance_Operations_Protocol, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DECnet

2.83 Classless Routing Enabled

Nipper Rating
  • Overall: Informational
  • Impact: Informational
  • Ease: Trivial
  • Fix: Quick
Nipper Metrics Graph
[No canvas support]

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org

2.83.1 Finding

Classless routing enables the device to forward a network packet that is destined for a network subnet for which there is no route configured. Instead of failing to route the traffic, the device will forward the traffic to a configured supernet network route that best matches the intended destination.

Nipper examined the device configuration to determine that the classless routing feature had been disabled.

2.83.1.1 router03.nipper.org Findings

Nipper determined that classless routing was enabled on router03.nipper.org.

2.83.2 Impact

An attacker may attempt to abuse this functionality in order to route network packets which should otherwise fail.

2.83.3 Ease

With classless routing enabled, network packets received for an unknown subnet will be forwarded to the best matching supernet.

2.83.4 Recommendation

Nipper suggests that, where possible, classless routing should be disabled.

2.83.4.1 Cisco IOS Information

Classless routing can be disabled on Cisco IOS devices with the following command:

no ip classless

2.83.5 Additional Information

  • TID: TNA-ROUT-0006
  • Classification: Routing
  • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_Inter-Domain_Routing

2.84 Conclusions

Nipper performed a best practice security audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the device detailed in Table 138. Nipper identified 81 security-related findings. The most significant finding was rated as critical.

Table 138: Security audit device conclusions
Device Name Issues Highest Rating
Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org 81 Critical

One critical rated security finding was identified. Nipper determined that:

  • dictionary-based user authentication credentials were configured (one device, see section 2.2).

Nipper identified fourteen high rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • the default SNMP community strings were configured (one device, see section 2.3);
  • the Telnet service was enabled (one device, see section 2.4);
  • the enable password is not stored using an MD5 hash (one device, see section 2.5);
  • TCP keep-alive messages were not configured for inbound connections (one device, see section 2.6);
  • BGP neighbors were configured with no authentication key (one device, see section 2.7);
  • not all RIP configurations were authenticated (one device, see section 2.8);
  • low GLBP group priorities were configured (one device, see section 2.9);
  • not all GLBP groups were authenticated (one device, see section 2.10);
  • low HSRP group priorities were configured (one device, see section 2.11);
  • not all HSRP groups were authenticated (one device, see section 2.12);
  • low VRRP priorities were configured (one device, see section 2.13);
  • not all VRRP were authenticated (one device, see section 2.14);
  • the clear-text SNMP service was enabled (one device, see section 2.15);
  • SNMP write access was enabled (one device, see section 2.16).

Nipper identified 24 medium rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • support for SSH protocol version 1 was enabled (one device, see section 2.17);
  • RADIUS were configured with no shared secrets (one device, see section 2.18);
  • network filter rules allowed access to hosts and services defined on the blacklist (one device, see section 2.19);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access from any source address (one device, see section 2.20);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to any destination address (one device, see section 2.21);
  • DTP was enabled (one device, see section 2.22);
  • support for RIP version 1 routing updates was configured (one device, see section 2.23);
  • weak GLBP group authentication keys were configured (one device, see section 2.24);
  • weak HSRP group authentication keys were configured (one device, see section 2.25);
  • dictionary-based VRRP authentication keys were configured (one device, see section 2.26);
  • dictionary-based routing protocol authentication keys were configured (one device, see section 2.27);
  • the SNMP system shutdown facility was enabled (one device, see section 2.28);
  • the AUX port was not disabled (one device, see section 2.29);
  • weak encryption ciphers were configured (one device, see section 2.30);
  • no HTTPS network host access addresses were configured (one device, see section 2.31);
  • passwords stored using the Cisco Type 7 encoding algorithm were identified (one device, see section 2.32);
  • dictionary-based RADIUS shared secrets were configured (one device, see section 2.33);
  • network filter rules were configured that enable access to administrative services (one device, see section 2.34);
  • network filter rules were identified that allow access to clear-text protocol services (one device, see section 2.35);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to any port (one device, see section 2.36);
  • the logging of system messages to a Syslog logging server was not configured (one device, see section 2.37);
  • low OSPF priorities were configured (one device, see section 2.38);
  • no RIP routing update neighbors were configured (one device, see section 2.39);
  • weak routing protocol authentication keys were configured (one device, see section 2.40).

Nipper identified 24 low rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • the finger service was enabled (one device, see section 2.41);
  • weak inbound administrative line ACL restrictions configured (one device, see section 2.42);
  • a weak user account lockout policy setting was configured (one device, see section 2.43);
  • network filter rules allowed access to potentially sensitive network services (one device, see section 2.44);
  • network filter rules allowed access to potentially unnecessary network services (one device, see section 2.45);
  • no OSPF LSA message thresholds were configured (one device, see section 2.46);
  • a SNMP TFTP server access list was not configured (one device, see section 2.47);
  • SNMPv3 users were configured with no privacy encryption (one device, see section 2.48);
  • NTP authentication was disabled (one device, see section 2.49);
  • the BOOTP service was not disabled (one device, see section 2.50);
  • no unauthorized access warning in the pre-logon banner message (one device, see section 2.51);
  • service password encryption was disabled (one device, see section 2.52);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access from a subnet (one device, see section 2.53);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to a subnet (one device, see section 2.54);
  • network rules were identified that allowed access to a port range (one device, see section 2.55);
  • directed broadcasts were enabled (one device, see section 2.56);
  • ICMP address mask reply messages were enabled (one device, see section 2.57);
  • ICMP unreachable messages were enabled (one device, see section 2.58);
  • CDP was enabled (one device, see section 2.59);
  • LLDP was enabled (one device, see section 2.60);
  • IP source routing was enabled (one device, see section 2.61);
  • SNMP community strings were configured without a view (one device, see section 2.62);
  • network filtering was not configured to restrict SNMP access (one device, see section 2.63);
  • weak SNMPv3 users authentication hashing algorithms were configured (one device, see section 2.64).

Nipper identified 18 informational rated security findings. Nipper determined that:

  • DNS lookups were enabled (one device, see section 2.65);
  • network filter rules were configured to allow all IP protocols (one device, see section 2.66);
  • network filter rules were configured to allow ICMP traffic (one device, see section 2.67);
  • network filter rules were configured that do not log dropped network traffic (one device, see section 2.68);
  • network filter rules were configured that do not log allowed network traffic (one device, see section 2.69);
  • network interfaces were configured without filtering (one device, see section 2.70);
  • ICMP redirect message sending was enabled (one device, see section 2.71);
  • the PAD service was enabled (one device, see section 2.72);
  • dictionary-based SNMP trap community strings were configured (one device, see section 2.73);
  • no outbound administrative ACL has been configured (one device, see section 2.74);
  • the TCP small servers were enabled (one device, see section 2.75);
  • the UDP small servers were enabled (one device, see section 2.76);
  • not all filter rule lists were configured with a drop all and log rule (one device, see section 2.78);
  • unused network filter rules were configured (one device, see section 2.79);
  • unassigned network filter rule lists were configured (one device, see section 2.80);
  • trunking was enabled for all VLANs (one device, see section 2.81);
  • MOP was enabled (one device, see section 2.82);
  • classless routing was enabled (one device, see section 2.83).

Nipper can draw the following statistics from the results of this security assessment (percentages have been rounded). 1 finding (1%) was rated as critical, 14 findings (17%) were rated as high, 24 findings (30%) were rated as medium, 24 findings (30%) were rated as low and 18 findings (22%) were rated as informational.

Severity Classification
[No canvas support]
Issue Classification
[No canvas support]

2.85 Heatmap Analysis

Informational Low Medium High Critical
Complete 0 0 1 0 2
Partial 5 11 10 23 2
None 12 6 6 3 0

Nipper identified two findings that were rated as both "Critical" for Nipper "Impact" and "Complete" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Critical : Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (one device, see section 2.2);
  • Medium : SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (one device, see section 2.17).

Nipper determined that one finding was identified that was rated as both "Medium" for Nipper "Impact" and "Complete" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". This finding was:

  • Low : No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (one device, see section 2.47).

Nipper identified two findings that were rated as both "Critical" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Medium : RADIUS Servers With No Shared Secret (one device, see section 2.18);
  • Medium : RADIUS Servers With A Dictionary-Based Shared Secret (one device, see section 2.33).

Nipper identified 23 findings that were rated as both "High" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • High : Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (one device, see section 2.3);
  • High : Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (one device, see section 2.4);
  • High : Enable Password Configured (one device, see section 2.5);
  • High : BGP Neighbors With No Authentication (one device, see section 2.7);
  • High : No RIP Authentication (one device, see section 2.8);
  • High : Low GLBP Group Priorities (one device, see section 2.9);
  • High : Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.10);
  • High : Low HSRP Group Priorities (one device, see section 2.11);
  • High : Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.12);
  • High : Low VRRP Priorities (one device, see section 2.13);
  • High : Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.14);
  • High : Clear-Text SNMP In Use (one device, see section 2.15);
  • High : SNMP Write Access Enabled (one device, see section 2.16);
  • Medium : DTP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.22);
  • Medium : RIP Version 1 Configured (one device, see section 2.23);
  • Medium : Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (one device, see section 2.24);
  • Medium : Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (one device, see section 2.25);
  • Medium : Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (one device, see section 2.26);
  • Medium : Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (one device, see section 2.27);

  • Medium : Low OSPF Priorities (one device, see section 2.38);
  • Medium : Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (one device, see section 2.40).

  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service (one device, see section 2.19);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address (one device, see section 2.20);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address (one device, see section 2.21);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services (one device, see section 2.34);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services (one device, see section 2.35);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To Any Port (one device, see section 2.36);
  • Medium : No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (one device, see section 2.39);
  • Low : SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (one device, see section 2.48);
  • Low : Service Password Encryption Disabled (one device, see section 2.52);
  • Low : Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (one device, see section 2.64).

Nipper identified eleven findings that were rated as both "Low" for Nipper "Impact" and "Partial" for CVSS v2 "Confidentiality". Those findings were:

  • Low : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services (one device, see section 2.44);
  • Low : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services (one device, see section 2.45);
  • Low : The BOOTP Service Was Not Disabled (one device, see section 2.50);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet (one device, see section 2.53);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet (one device, see section 2.54);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To Port Range (one device, see section 2.55);
  • Low : ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.57);
  • Low : ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.58);
  • Low : CDP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.59);
  • Low : LLDP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.60).

  • Informational : Filter Rules Allow ICMP (one device, see section 2.67);
  • Informational : Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering (one device, see section 2.70);

  • Medium : SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (one device, see section 2.28);
  • Medium : AUX Port Not Disabled (one device, see section 2.29).

  • Low : No Warning In Pre-Logon Banner Message (one device, see section 2.51);

2.86 Recommendations

This section collates the issue recommendations into a single location in order to provide a guide to planning and mitigating the identified issues. The recommendations are listed in Table 140 together with the issue rating and a list of affected devices.

Table 140: Security audit recommendations list
Issue Rating Recommendation Affected Devices Section
Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords Critical Configure strong passwords for all user authentication credentials. router03.nipper.org 2.2
Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured High Configure strong SNMP community strings router03.nipper.org 2.3
Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled High Disable the Telnet service. router03.nipper.org 2.4
Enable Password Configured High Configure enable passwords to be stored only using the MD5 hash. router03.nipper.org 2.5
No Inbound TCP Connection Keep-Alives High Enable TCP keep-alive messages for inbound connections router03.nipper.org 2.6
BGP Neighbors With No Authentication High Configure strong BGP neighbor authentication keys for all routing updates. router03.nipper.org 2.7
No RIP Authentication High Configure strong authentication keys for all RIP routing updates router03.nipper.org 2.8
Low GLBP Group Priorities High Configure only high GLBP group priorities router03.nipper.org 2.9
Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated High Configure strong authentication keys for all GLBP groups router03.nipper.org 2.10
Low HSRP Group Priorities High Configure only high HSRP group priorities router03.nipper.org 2.11
Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated High Configure strong authentication keys for all HSRP groups router03.nipper.org 2.12
Low VRRP Priorities High Configure only high VRRP priorities router03.nipper.org 2.13
Not All VRRP Were Authenticated High Configure strong authentication keys for all VRRP router03.nipper.org 2.14
Clear-Text SNMP In Use High Disable access to the clear-text SNMP service.
Configure SNMP version 3 with authentication and privacy passwords instead of SNMP versions 1 or 2.		 router03.nipper.org 2.15
SNMP Write Access Enabled High Disable the SNMP service.
OR
Replace all write access community strings with read only SNMP community strings.		 router03.nipper.org 2.16
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported Medium Configure the SSH service to support only version 2 of the protocol. router03.nipper.org 2.17
RADIUS Servers With No Shared Secret Medium Configure strong RADIUS shared secrets for all connections. router03.nipper.org 2.18
Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service Medium Modify the filter rules to prevent access to blacklist host and services router03.nipper.org 2.19
Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.20
Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.21
DTP Was Enabled Medium Disable DTP router03.nipper.org 2.22
RIP Version 1 Configured Medium Configure support for RIP version 2 only.
Migrate to a device that has support for RIP version 2.		 router03.nipper.org 2.23
Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key Medium Configure strong GLBP authentication keys for all groups router03.nipper.org 2.24
Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key Medium Configure strong HSRP authentication keys for all groups router03.nipper.org 2.25
Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication Medium Configure strong VRRP authentication keys router03.nipper.org 2.26
Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys Medium Configure strong routing protocol authentication keys for all routing updates router03.nipper.org 2.27
SNMP System Shutdown Enabled Medium Disable SNMP system shutdown facility. router03.nipper.org 2.28
AUX Port Not Disabled Medium Disable the AUX port.
OR
Configure the callback facility.		 router03.nipper.org 2.29
Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported Medium Configure only strong encryption ciphers. router03.nipper.org 2.30
No HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions Medium Restrict the HTTPS service to only those hosts that require access. router03.nipper.org 2.31
Users Configured With Cisco Type 7 Password Hashing Algorithm Medium Configure all users to store passwords using an up-to-date hashing algorithm (e.g. Cisco Type-8 or Type-9). router03.nipper.org 2.32
RADIUS Servers With A Dictionary-Based Shared Secret Medium Configure strong RADIUS shared secrets for all connections. router03.nipper.org 2.33
Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services Medium Modify the filter rules to only permit access to administrative services where it is necessary router03.nipper.org 2.34
Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services Medium Modify the filter rules to prevent access to clear-text protocol services router03.nipper.org 2.35
Filter Rules Allow To Any Port Medium Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.36
Syslog Logging Not Enabled Medium Configure Syslog message logging router03.nipper.org 2.37
Low OSPF Priorities Medium Configure only high OSPF priorities router03.nipper.org 2.38
No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured Medium Configure RIP routing update neighbors router03.nipper.org 2.39
Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys Medium Configure strong routing protocol authentication keys for all routing updates router03.nipper.org 2.40
The Finger Service Was Enabled Low Disable the finger service. router03.nipper.org 2.41
Administration Line With Weak Inbound ACL Host Restrictions Low Configure the administrative line ACL to restrict access to only those specific hosts that require access. router03.nipper.org 2.42
Weak User Account Lockout Policy Setting Low Configure the user account lockout policy to disable access after 3 failed logon attempts for all users. router03.nipper.org 2.43
Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to potentially sensitive network services router03.nipper.org 2.44
Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services Low Modify the filter rules to prevent access to potentially unnecessary network services router03.nipper.org 2.45
No OSPF LSA Thresholds Low Configure OSPF LSA message thresholds for all OSPF routing processes router03.nipper.org 2.46
No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured Low Configure a SNMP TFTP server access list. router03.nipper.org 2.47
SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy Low Configure a FIPS privacy encryption algorithm for all SNMPv3 users router03.nipper.org 2.48
NTP Authentication Was Disabled Low Enable NTP authentication. router03.nipper.org 2.49
The BOOTP Service Was Not Disabled Low Disable the BOOTP service. router03.nipper.org 2.50
No Warning In Pre-Logon Banner Message Low Modify the pre-logon banner message to include a carefully worded legal warning. router03.nipper.org 2.51
Service Password Encryption Disabled Low Enable service password encryption. router03.nipper.org 2.52
Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.53
Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.54
Filter Rules Allow To Port Range Low Modify the filter rules to restrict access to network host services from only those hosts that require the access router03.nipper.org 2.55
IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled Low Disable directed broadcasts on all interfaces router03.nipper.org 2.56
ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled Low Disable the sending of ICMP address mask reply messages on all network interfaces router03.nipper.org 2.57
ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled Low Disable the sending of ICMP unreachable messages router03.nipper.org 2.58
CDP Was Enabled Low Disable CDP router03.nipper.org 2.59
LLDP Was Enabled Low Disable LLDP router03.nipper.org 2.60
IP Source Routing Was Enabled Low Disable IP source routing router03.nipper.org 2.61
SNMP Access With No View Low Configure a view to limit access to the SNMP MIB. router03.nipper.org 2.62
SNMP Access Without Network Filtering Low Configure SNMP network filtering to restrict network access. router03.nipper.org 2.63
Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured Low Configure a FIPS authentication hashing algorithm for all SNMPv3 users router03.nipper.org 2.64
DNS Lookups Were Enabled Informational Disable DNS lookups. router03.nipper.org 2.65
Filter Rules Allow Any IP Informational Modify the filter rules to use a specific protocol router03.nipper.org 2.66
Filter Rules Allow ICMP Informational Modify the filter rules to drop all ICMP network traffic router03.nipper.org 2.67
Filter Rules Deny Without Logging Informational Modify the filter rules to log all dropped network traffic router03.nipper.org 2.68
Filter Rules Allow Without Logging Informational Modify the filter rules to log all allowed network traffic router03.nipper.org 2.69
Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering Informational Assign network filtering rules to all network interfaces router03.nipper.org 2.70
ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled Informational Disable the sending of ICMP redirect messages router03.nipper.org 2.71
PAD Service Enabled Informational Disable the PAD service router03.nipper.org 2.72
Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings Informational Configure strong SNMP trap community strings router03.nipper.org 2.73
Unrestricted Outbound Administrative Access Informational Configure an ACL to restrict outbound administrative service access. router03.nipper.org 2.74
TCP Small Services Enabled Informational Disable the TCP small servers. router03.nipper.org 2.75
UDP Small Services Enabled Informational Disable the UDP small servers. router03.nipper.org 2.76
Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log Informational Add a drop all and log filter rule as the last filter rule router03.nipper.org 2.78
Unused Filter Rules Informational Remove all unused network filter rules router03.nipper.org 2.79
Unassigned Filter Rule Lists Informational Remove all unused network filter rule lists router03.nipper.org 2.80
Switch Ports Allow Trunking All VLAN Informational Disable VLAN trunking
Configure trunking for only the required VLANs		 router03.nipper.org 2.81
MOP Enabled Informational Disable MOP on all network interfaces router03.nipper.org 2.82
Classless Routing Enabled Informational Disable classless routing router03.nipper.org 2.83

2.87 Mitigation Classification

This section aims to provide a guide to the perceived complexity of resolving a particular finding by implementing the recommendation. An outline of how each mitigation classification has been determined is described in Table 141.

Table 141: The mitigation classification
Classification Description
Quick The finding is quick to resolve. Typically this would just involve changing a small number of settings and would have little-to-no effect on network services.
Planned The finding resolution involves planning, testing and could cause some disruption to services. This finding could involve changes to routing protocols and changes to network filtering.
Involved The resolution of the finding will require significant resources to resolve and is likely to include disruption to network services, and possibly the modification of other network device configurations. The finding could involve upgrading a device's OS and possible modifications to the hardware.

Nipper identified 45 security findings with mitigation recommendations that were classified as Quick. Those findings were:

  • Critical : Users With Dictionary-Based Passwords (one device, see section 2.2);
  • High : Default SNMP Community Strings Were Configured (one device, see section 2.3);
  • High : Clear Text Telnet Service Enabled (one device, see section 2.4);
  • High : Enable Password Configured (one device, see section 2.5);
  • High : No Inbound TCP Connection Keep-Alives (one device, see section 2.6);
  • High : SNMP Write Access Enabled (one device, see section 2.16);
  • Medium : SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported (one device, see section 2.17);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Blacklist Host and Service (one device, see section 2.19);
  • Medium : SNMP System Shutdown Enabled (one device, see section 2.28);
  • Medium : AUX Port Not Disabled (one device, see section 2.29);
  • Medium : Weak SSL/early TLS Ciphers Supported (one device, see section 2.30);
  • Medium : No HTTPS Service Network Access Restrictions (one device, see section 2.31);
  • Medium : Users Configured With Cisco Type 7 Password Hashing Algorithm (one device, see section 2.32);
  • Low : The Finger Service Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.41);
  • Low : Weak User Account Lockout Policy Setting (one device, see section 2.43);
  • Low : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Sensitive Services (one device, see section 2.44);
  • Low : Rules Allow Access To Potentially Unnecessary Services (one device, see section 2.45);
  • Low : No SNMP TFTP Server Access List Configured (one device, see section 2.47);
  • Low : SNMPv3 User Configured With No Privacy (one device, see section 2.48);
  • Low : The BOOTP Service Was Not Disabled (one device, see section 2.50);
  • Low : No Warning In Pre-Logon Banner Message (one device, see section 2.51);
  • Low : Service Password Encryption Disabled (one device, see section 2.52);
  • Low : IP Directed Broadcasts Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.56);
  • Low : ICMP Address Mask Reply Messages Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.57);
  • Low : ICMP Unreachable Messages Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.58);
  • Low : CDP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.59);
  • Low : LLDP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.60);
  • Low : IP Source Routing Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.61);
  • Low : SNMP Access With No View (one device, see section 2.62);
  • Low : SNMP Access Without Network Filtering (one device, see section 2.63);
  • Informational : DNS Lookups Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.65);
  • Informational : Filter Rules Deny Without Logging (one device, see section 2.68);
  • Informational : Filter Rules Allow Without Logging (one device, see section 2.69);
  • Informational : Interfaces Were Configured With No Filtering (one device, see section 2.70);
  • Informational : ICMP Redirect Messages Were Enabled (one device, see section 2.71);
  • Informational : PAD Service Enabled (one device, see section 2.72);
  • Informational : Unrestricted Outbound Administrative Access (one device, see section 2.74);
  • Informational : TCP Small Services Enabled (one device, see section 2.75);
  • Informational : UDP Small Services Enabled (one device, see section 2.76);
  • Informational : Filter Rule List Does Not End With Drop All And Log (one device, see section 2.78);
  • Informational : Unused Filter Rules (one device, see section 2.79);
  • Informational : Unassigned Filter Rule Lists (one device, see section 2.80);
  • Informational : Switch Ports Allow Trunking All VLAN (one device, see section 2.81);
  • Informational : MOP Enabled (one device, see section 2.82);
  • Informational : Classless Routing Enabled (one device, see section 2.83).

Nipper identified 25 security findings with mitigation recommendations that were classified as Planned. Those findings were:

  • High : Low GLBP Group Priorities (one device, see section 2.9);
  • High : Low HSRP Group Priorities (one device, see section 2.11);
  • High : Low VRRP Priorities (one device, see section 2.13);
  • High : Clear-Text SNMP In Use (one device, see section 2.15);
  • Medium : RADIUS Servers With No Shared Secret (one device, see section 2.18);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow From Any Source Address (one device, see section 2.20);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To Any Destination Address (one device, see section 2.21);
  • Medium : DTP Was Enabled (one device, see section 2.22);
  • Medium : RADIUS Servers With A Dictionary-Based Shared Secret (one device, see section 2.33);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Administrative Services (one device, see section 2.34);
  • Medium : Rules Allow Access To Clear-Text Services (one device, see section 2.35);
  • Medium : Filter Rules Allow To Any Port (one device, see section 2.36);
  • Medium : Syslog Logging Not Enabled (one device, see section 2.37);
  • Medium : Low OSPF Priorities (one device, see section 2.38);
  • Medium : No RIP Update Neighbors Were Configured (one device, see section 2.39);
  • Low : Administration Line With Weak Inbound ACL Host Restrictions (one device, see section 2.42);
  • Low : No OSPF LSA Thresholds (one device, see section 2.46);
  • Low : NTP Authentication Was Disabled (one device, see section 2.49);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow From A Subnet (one device, see section 2.53);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To A Subnet (one device, see section 2.54);
  • Low : Filter Rules Allow To Port Range (one device, see section 2.55);
  • Low : Weak SNMPv3 User Authentication Hashing Algorithm Configured (one device, see section 2.64);
  • Informational : Filter Rules Allow Any IP (one device, see section 2.66);
  • Informational : Filter Rules Allow ICMP (one device, see section 2.67);
  • Informational : Dictionary-Based SNMP Trap Community Strings (one device, see section 2.73).

Nipper identified 11 security findings with mitigation recommendations that were classified as Involved. Those findings were:

  • High : BGP Neighbors With No Authentication (one device, see section 2.7);
  • High : No RIP Authentication (one device, see section 2.8);
  • High : Not All GLBP Groups Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.10);
  • High : Not All HSRP Groups Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.12);
  • High : Not All VRRP Were Authenticated (one device, see section 2.14);
  • Medium : RIP Version 1 Configured (one device, see section 2.23);
  • Medium : Weak GLBP Group Authentication Key (one device, see section 2.24);
  • Medium : Weak HSRP Group Authentication Key (one device, see section 2.25);
  • Medium : Dictionary-Based VRRP Authentication (one device, see section 2.26);
  • Medium : Dictionary-Based Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (one device, see section 2.27);
  • Medium : Weak Routing Protocol Authentication Keys (one device, see section 2.40).

Nipper can draw the following additional conclusion from the best practice security audit based on the classification of the recommended finding mitigations. Most of the security finding recommendations are perceived to be quick to implement, enabling the majority of the findings to be quickly resolved without requiring a significant allocation of resources or system disruption. Of the 81 security findings identified, 45 (55%) recommendations were classified as having a quick mitigation, 25 (30%) recommendations were classified as having a planned mitigation and eleven (13%) recommendations were classified as having a involved mitigation.

Issue Mitigation Classification
[No canvas support]

3

DISA STIG Compliance

3.1 Introduction

Nipper performed a DoD STIG compliance audit on Friday, September 30, 2022 of the device and STIG benchmarks detailed in Table 142.

Table 142: Devices and STIG benchmark audit scope
Device STIG Benchmark
Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org Cisco IOS Router NDM Security Technical Implementation Guide

The benchmark profile used for the audit was "I - Mission Critical Classified". The benchmark versions used in this audit are described in the following table.

Table 143: Benchmark versions
Benchmark Version Release Status Date
Cisco IOS Router NDM Security Technical Implementation Guide 2 Release: 4 Benchmark Date: 27 Jul 2022 6/9/22
