3.2.2 SRG-APP-000142-NDM-000245

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215678
  • Rule ID : SV-215678r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000382
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000470
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.2.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to prohibit the use of all unnecessary and nonsecure functions and services.

3.2.2.2 Discussion

Network devices are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services provided by default may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations. Additionally, it is sometimes convenient to provide multiple services from a single component (e.g., email and web services); however, doing so increases risk over limiting the services provided by any one component.

To support the requirements and principles of least functionality, the network device must support the organizational requirements providing only essential capabilities and limiting the use of ports, protocols, and/or services to only those required, authorized, and approved. Some network devices have capabilities enabled by default; if these capabilities are not necessary, they must be disabled. If a particular capability is used, then it must be documented and approved.

3.2.2.3 Check

Verify that the router does not have any unnecessary or non-secure ports, protocols and services enabled. For example, the following commands should not be in the configuration:

boot network
ip boot server
ip bootp server
ip dns server
ip identd
ip finger
ip http server
ip rcmd rcp-enable
ip rcmd rsh-enable
service config
service finger
service tcp-small-servers
service udp-small-servers

If any unnecessary or non-secure ports, protocols, or services are enabled, this is a finding.

3.2.2.4 Findings

3.2.2.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[PASS]

Nipper determined that on router03.nipper.org there was no network boot configuration specified.

[PASS]

Nipper determined that the DNS server was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

[PASS]

Nipper determined that the Ident server was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

[PASS]

Nipper determined that on router03.nipper.org the service configuration was disabled.

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that the PAD service was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

[FAIL]

Nipper examined the remote administrative services configured on router03.nipper.org to determine their state and authorization. The status of each service is detailed in the following table:

Table 145: Authorization state of administrative services on router03.nipper.org
Service Authorized State Status
Telnet No Enabled Fail
Clear-Text Web Administration (HTTP) No Disabled Pass
RSH Unknown Disabled Pass

[FAIL]

Nipper examined the miscellaneous services configured on router03.nipper.org to determine their state and authorization. The status of each service is detailed in the following table:

Table 146: Authorization state of miscellaneous services on router03.nipper.org
Service Authorized State Status
Finger No Enabled Fail
TCP Small Servers No Enabled Fail
UDP Small Servers No Enabled Fail
BootP No Enabled Fail

3.2.2.5 Fix

Disable the following services if enabled as shown in the example below.

R2(config)#no boot network
R2(config)#no ip boot server
R2(config)#no ip bootp server
R2(config)#no ip dns server
R2(config)#no ip identd
R2(config)#no ip finger
R2(config)#no ip http server
R2(config)#no ip rcmd rcp-enable
R2(config)#no ip rcmd rsh-enable
R2(config)#no service config
R2(config)#no service finger
R2(config)#no service tcp-small-servers
R2(config)#no service udp-small-servers
R2(config)#no service pad
R2(config)#end

3.2.2.5.1 router03.nipper.org

The following will disable the PAcket Assembler/Disassembler service that is used to support X.25 links. (Risk Level - Low)

no service pad

The following will disable the clear-text Telnet administrative service. It is worth noting that this can prevent remote command-based access to the device if Telnet is your only access service. (Risk Level - Moderate)

line vty 0 4
transport input ssh
exit

The following will disable the legacy Finger service. (Risk Level - Safe)

no ip finger

The following will disable the TCP Small Servers service on the device. TCP small services are of little use and are commonly considered non-production or legacy services. (Risk Level - Safe)

no tcp-small-servers

The following will disable the UDP Small Servers service on the device. UDP small services are of little use and are commonly considered non-production or legacy services. (Risk Level - Safe)

no udp-small-servers

The following will disable the BOOTP service on the device. (Risk Level - Low)

ip dhcp bootp ignore

3.2.2.6 CCI References

The organization configures the information system to prohibit or restrict the use of organization-defined functions, ports, protocols, and/or services.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - CM-7;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - CM-7.1 (iii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - CM-7 b.

3.2.2.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000382
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96057, SV-105195
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96057, SV-105195
  • Fix ID : F-16870r285997_fix
  • Check ID : C-16872r285996_chk

3.2.3 SRG-APP-000171-NDM-000258

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215687
  • Rule ID : SV-215687r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000196
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000620
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.3.1 Summary

The Cisco router must only store cryptographic representations of passwords.

3.2.3.2 Discussion

Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised.

Network devices must enforce cryptographic representations of passwords when storing passwords in databases, configuration files, and log files. Passwords must be protected at all times; using a strong one-way hashing encryption algorithm with a salt is the standard method for providing a means to validate a password without having to store the actual password.

Performance and time required to access are factors that must be considered, and the one way hash is the most feasible means of securing the password and providing an acceptable measure of password security. If passwords are stored in clear text, they can be plainly read and easily compromised.

In many instances, verifying the user knows a password is performed using a password verifier. In its simplest form, a password verifier is a computational function that is capable of creating a hash of a password and determining if the value provided by the user matches the stored hash.

3.2.3.3 Check

Review the router configuration to determine if passwords are encrypted as shown in the example below.

service password-encryption

If the router is not configured to encrypt passwords, this is a finding.

3.2.3.4 Findings

3.2.3.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that the storage of encrypted passwords was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

3.2.3.5 Fix

Configure the router to encrypt all passwords.

R4(config)#service password-encryption 
R4(config)#end

3.2.3.5.1 router03.nipper.org

The following will enable the password encryption server. This provides a more secure configuration by storing important passwords using non-trivial encryption algorithms. (Risk Level - Safe)

service password-encryption

3.2.3.6 CCI References

The information system, for password-based authentication, stores only cryptographically-protected passwords.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - IA-5 (1) (c);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - IA-5 (1).1 (v);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - IA-5 (1) (c).

3.2.3.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000196
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96083, SV-105221
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96083, SV-105221
  • Fix ID : F-16879r286024_fix
  • Check ID : C-16881r286023_chk

3.2.4 SRG-APP-000190-NDM-000267

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215688
  • Rule ID : SV-215688r835043_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001133
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000720
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.4.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to terminate all network connections associated with device management after 10 minutes of inactivity.

3.2.4.2 Discussion

Terminating an idle session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of a management session enabled on the console or console port that has been left unattended. In addition, quickly terminating an idle session will also free up resources committed by the managed network element.

Terminating network connections associated with communications sessions includes, for example, de-allocating associated TCP/IP address/port pairs at the operating system level, or de-allocating networking assignments at the application level if multiple application sessions are using a single, operating system-level network connection. This does not mean that the device terminates all sessions or network access; it only ends the inactive session and releases the resources associated with that session.

3.2.4.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that all network connections associated with a device management have an idle timeout value set to 10 minutes or less as shown in the following example:

ip http secure-server
ip http timeout-policy idle 600 life nnnn requests nn
…
…
…
line con 0
 exec-timeout 10 0
line vty 0 1
 exec-timeout 10 0

If the Cisco router is not configured to terminate all network connections associated with a device management after 10 minutes of inactivity, this is a finding.

3.2.4.4 Findings

This check requires that all administrative connections have a session timeout of no more than 10 minutes. If an administrative service, such as HTTPS, is disabled then no administrative connections can be made using the service and the session timeout is extraneous. These checks will return a N/A finding status.

It is worth noting that the default Cisco line exec timeout is 10 minutes and 3 minutes for the HTTPS service.

Added information:

3.2.4.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[PASS]

The configuration of the administrative lines on router03.nipper.org are detailed in Table 147.

Table 147: Administrative line settings on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Exec Timeout Absolute Timeout Session Timeout Login Timeout Session Limit Filter In Filter Out Callback
Console Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 10 minutes None 25 minutes 30 seconds None N/A N/A N/A
Auxiliary Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 10 minutes None 25 minutes 30 seconds None N/A N/A No
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 10 minutes None None 30 seconds 2 40   N/A

[N/A]

Table 148: Web-based administration service settings
Description Value
Web Administration Service (HTTP) Disabled
HTTP TCP Port 80

[PASS]

Nipper determined that the HTTPS service specific timeout configured on router03.nipper.org was set to 3 minutes.

3.2.4.5 Fix

Set the idle timeout value to 10 minutes or less on all configured login classes as shown in the example below:

R1(config)#line vty 0 1
R1(config-line)#exec-timeout 10 0
R1(config-line)#exit
R1(config)#line con 0
R1(config-line)#exec-timeout 10 0
R1(config-line)#exit
R2(config)#ip http timeout-policy idle 600 life nnnn requests nn

3.2.4.6 CCI References

The information system terminates the network connection associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - SC-10;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - SC-10.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - SC-10.

3.2.4.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001133
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96089, SV-105227
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96089, SV-105227
  • Fix ID : F-16880r835042_fix
  • Check ID : C-16882r835041_chk

3.2.5 SRG-APP-000411-NDM-000330

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215699
  • Rule ID : SV-215699r835053_rule
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-001200
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.5.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to use FIPS-validated Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC) to protect the integrity of remote maintenance sessions.

3.2.5.2 Discussion

Unapproved mechanisms that are used for authentication to the cryptographic module are not verified and therefore cannot be relied upon to provide confidentiality or integrity, and DoD data may be compromised.

Nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic activities are those activities conducted by individuals communicating through a network, either an external network (e.g., the Internet) or an internal network.

Currently, HMAC is the only FIPS-approved algorithm for generating and verifying message/data authentication codes in accordance with FIPS 198-1. Products that are FIPS 140-2 validated will have an HMAC that meets specification; however, the option must be configured for use as the only message authentication code used for authentication to cryptographic modules.

3.2.5.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

NOTE: Although allowed by SP800-131Ar2 for some applications, SHA-1 is considered a compromised hashing standard and is being phased out of use by industry and Government standards. Unless required for legacy use, DoD systems should not be configured to use SHA-1 for integrity of remote access sessions.

SSH Example

ip ssh version 2
ip ssh server algorithm mac hmac-sha2-256

If the Cisco router is not configured to use FIPS-validated HMAC to protect the integrity of remote maintenance sessions, this is a finding.

3.2.5.4 Findings

This check is to confirm that only approved authentication mechanisms are used. The examples shown demonstate configuring the SSH and HTTPS services. However, if those services are not enabled then the authentication configuration of those services are extraneous and will show a N/A status.

Added information:

3.2.5.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on router03.nipper.org.

[FAIL]

Table 149: Non-FIPS compliant encryption ciphersuites
IANA Name Protocols Key Exchange Authentication Encryption Hash RFC
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA SSL v1
SSL v2
SSL v3
TLS v1
TLS v1.1
TLS v1.2		 RSA RSA RC4 128bit SHA-1 RFC 5246
RFC 6347
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 SSL v1
SSL v2
SSL v3
TLS v1
TLS v1.1
TLS v1.2		 RSA RSA RC4 128bit MD5 RFC 5246
RFC 6347
TLS_RSA_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA TLS v1
TLS v1.1		 RSA RSA DES 56bit CBC mode SHA-1 RFC 5469

3.2.5.5 Fix

Configure SSH to use FIPS-validated HMAC for remote maintenance sessions as shown in the following example:

SSH Example


R1(config)#ip ssh version 2
R1(config)#ip ssh server algorithm mac hmac-sha2-256

3.2.5.5.1 router03.nipper.org

The following will configure the SSH service to support only V2 of the protocol, removing access using the weaker SSH V1 protocol. (Risk Level - Low)

ip ssh version 2

The following will configure the HTTPS service to enable only the use of FIPS ciphersuites. (Risk Level - Low)

ip http secure-ciphersuite aes-128-cbc-sha
ip http secure-client-auth

3.2.5.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001941, CCI-002890
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001941, CCI-002890
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105283, V-96145
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105283, V-96145
  • Fix ID : F-16891r835052_fix
  • Check ID : C-16893r835051_chk

3.2.6 SRG-APP-000412-NDM-000331

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215700
  • Rule ID : SV-215700r835056_rule
  • CCI : CCI-003123
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-001210
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.6.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote maintenance sessions.

3.2.6.2 Discussion

This requires the use of secure protocols instead of their unsecured counterparts, such as SSH instead of telnet, SCP instead of FTP, and HTTPS instead of HTTP. If unsecured protocols (lacking cryptographic mechanisms) are used for sessions, the contents of those sessions will be susceptible to eavesdropping, potentially putting sensitive data (including administrator passwords) at risk of compromise and potentially allowing hijacking of maintenance sessions.

3.2.6.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement.

SSH Example

ip ssh version 2
ip ssh server algorithm encryption aes256-ctr aes192-ctr aes128-ctr

HTTPS Example

ip http secure-server
ip http secure-ciphersuite aes-128-cbc-sha
ip http secure-client-auth
ip http secure-trustpoint CA_XXX

If the router is not configured to implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote maintenance sessions using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm, this is a finding.

3.2.6.4 Findings

3.2.6.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[FAIL]

Nipper detemined that the SSH service was configured to support versions 1 and 2 of the protocol on router03.nipper.org.

[FAIL]

Table 150: Non-FIPS compliant encryption ciphersuites
IANA Name Protocols Key Exchange Authentication Encryption Hash RFC
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA SSL v1
SSL v2
SSL v3
TLS v1
TLS v1.1
TLS v1.2		 RSA RSA RC4 128bit SHA-1 RFC 5246
RFC 6347
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 SSL v1
SSL v2
SSL v3
TLS v1
TLS v1.1
TLS v1.2		 RSA RSA RC4 128bit MD5 RFC 5246
RFC 6347
TLS_RSA_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA TLS v1
TLS v1.1		 RSA RSA DES 56bit CBC mode SHA-1 RFC 5469

3.2.6.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco router to implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote maintenance sessions using a FIPS 140-2 approved algorithm as shown in the examples below.

SSH Example

R1(config)#ip ssh server algorithm encryption aes256-ctr aes192-ctr aes128-ctr

HTTPS Example

R2(config)#ip http secure-ciphersuite aes-128-cbc-sha

3.2.6.5.1 router03.nipper.org

The following will configure the SSH service to support only V2 of the protocol, removing access using the weaker SSH V1 protocol. (Risk Level - Low)

ip ssh version 2

The following will configure the HTTPS service to enable only the use of FIPS ciphersuites. (Risk Level - Low)

ip http secure-ciphersuite aes-128-cbc-sha
ip http secure-client-auth

3.2.6.6 CCI References

The information system implements cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - MA-4 (6).

3.2.6.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-003123
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105285, V-96147
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105285, V-96147
  • Fix ID : F-16892r835055_fix
  • Check ID : C-16894r835054_chk

3.2.7 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000336

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215709
  • Rule ID : SV-215709r835062_rule
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-001370
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.7.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to use an authentication server for the purpose of authenticating users prior to granting administrative access.

3.2.7.2 Discussion

Centralized management of user accounts and authentication increases the administrative access to the router. This control is particularly important protection against the insider threat. With robust centralized management, audit records for administrator account access to the organization's network devices can be more readily analyzed for trends and anomalies. The alternative method of defining administrator accounts on each device exposes the device configuration to remote access authentication attacks and system administrators with multiple authenticators for each network device.

3.2.7.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that the device is configured to use an authentication server as primary source for authentication as shown in the following example:

aaa new-model
!
aaa authentication login LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION group radius local
…
…
…
ip http authentication aaa login-authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION
ip http secure-server
…
…
…
radius-server host x.x.x.x auth-port 1645 acct-port 1646 key xxxxxxx
…
…
…
line con 0
 exec-timeout 10 0
 login authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION
line vty 0 1
 exec-timeout 10 0
 login authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION

If the Cisco router is not configured to use an authentication server for the purpose of authenticating users prior to granting administrative access, this is a finding.

3.2.7.4 Findings

3.2.7.4.1 router03.nipper.org
Table 151: Administrative lines on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Level Password Telnet SSH Filter In Filter Out
Console Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password N/A N/A N/A N/A
Auxiliary Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password N/A N/A N/A N/A
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 1 password Yes Yes 40  
Table 152: Authentication systems for LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION
Name Type For
LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION RADIUS Server
Local Users Database		 login
Table 153: RADIUS servers
Server Group Address Port Secret
  1.2.3.4 1645  
  10.10.10.10 1645 password

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to authenticate access to the web service using AAA. The named AAA authentication list was configured as "LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION".

3.2.7.5 Fix

Step 1: Configure the Cisco router to use an authentication server as shown in the following example:

R4(config)#radius host 10.1.48.2 key xxxxxx

Step 2: Configure the authentication order to use the authentication server as primary source for authentication as shown in the following example:

R4(config)#aaa authentication login LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION group radius local

Step 3: Configure all network connections associated with a device management to use an authentication server for the purpose of login authentication.

R4(config)#line vty 0 1
R4(config-line)#login authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION
R4(config-line)#exit
R4(config)#line con 0
R4(config-line)#login authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION
R4(config-line)#exit 
R4(config)#ip http authentication aaa login-authentication LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION

3.2.7.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000366, CCI-000370
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000366, CCI-000370
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105307, V-96169
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105307, V-96169
  • Fix ID : F-16901r835061_fix
  • Check ID : C-16903r835060_chk

3.2.8 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000350

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-220136
  • Rule ID : SV-220136r835065_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001851
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-001450
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.8.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to send log data to a syslog server for the purpose of forwarding alerts to the administrators and the ISSO.

3.2.8.2 Discussion

The aggregation of log data kept on a syslog server can be used to detect attacks and trigger an alert to the appropriate security personnel. The stored log data can used to detect weaknesses in security that enable the network IA team to find and address these weaknesses before breaches can occur. Reviewing these logs, whether before or after a security breach, are important in showing whether someone is an internal employee or an outside threat.

3.2.8.3 Check

Verify that the router is configured to send logs to a syslog server. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

logging x.x.x.x

If the router is not configured to send log data to the syslog server, this is a finding.

3.2.8.4 Findings

3.2.8.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that logging to a Syslog server was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

[FAIL]

Nipper determined that logging to a Syslog server was disabled on router03.nipper.org.

3.2.8.5 Fix

Configure the router to send log messages to the syslog server as shown in the example below.

R4(config)#logging host x.x.x.x

3.2.8.6 CCI References

The information system off-loads audit records per organization-defined frequency onto a different system or media than the system being audited.

  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-4 (1).

3.2.8.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001851
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96183, SV-105321
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96183, SV-105321
  • Fix ID : F-21844r835064_fix
  • Check ID : C-21850r835063_chk

3.2.9 SRG-APP-000516-NDM-000351

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-220137
  • Rule ID : SV-220137r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000366
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-001470
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-I

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Investigate)

3.2.9.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be running an IOS release that is currently supported by Cisco Systems.

3.2.9.2 Discussion

Network devices running an unsupported operating system lack current security fixes required to mitigate the risks associated with recent vulnerabilities. Running a supported release also enables operations to maintain a stable and reliable network provided by improved quality of service and security features.

3.2.9.3 Check

Verify that the router is in compliance with this requirement by having the router administrator enter the following command:

show version

Verify that the release is still supported by Cisco. All releases supported by Cisco can be found on the following URL:

www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/ios-nx-os-software

If the router is not running a supported release, this is a finding.

3.2.9.4 Fix

Upgrade the router to a supported release.

3.2.9.5 CCI References

The organization implements the security configuration settings.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - CM-6 b;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - CM-6.1 (iv);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - CM-6 b.

3.2.9.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000366
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96187, SV-105325
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96187, SV-105325
  • Fix ID : F-21845r388859_fix
  • Check ID : C-21851r388858_chk

3.2.10 SRG-APP-000001-NDM-000200

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215662
  • Rule ID : SV-215662r648760_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000054
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000010
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.10.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to limit the number of concurrent management sessions to an organization-defined number.

3.2.10.2 Discussion

Device management includes the ability to control the number of administrators and management sessions that manage a device. Limiting the number of allowed administrators and sessions per administrator based on account type, role, or access type is helpful in limiting risks related to DoS attacks.

This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for administrative accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by a single administrator via multiple administrative accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based upon mission needs and the operational environment for each system. At a minimum, limits must be set for SSH, HTTPS, account of last resort, and root account sessions.

3.2.10.3 Check

Note: This requirement is not applicable to file transfer actions such as FTP, SCP and SFTP.

Review the router configuration to determine if concurrent management sessions are limited as show in the example below:

ip http secure-server 
ip http max-connections 2 
… 
… 
… 
line vty 0 1 
transport input ssh 
line vty 2 4 
transport input none


If the router is not configured to limit the number of concurrent management sessions, this is a finding.

3.2.10.4 Findings

This check is to determine that the administrative services are configured to permit no more than 2 administrative sessions. The example shows configuring both the HTTPS service and line session limits (which will limit SSH sessions). However, it is worth noting that if those administrative services are disabled then no administrative connections can be made using them and the session limit check will be extraneous. These checks will return a N/A finding status.

Added information:

3.2.10.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[PASS]

Table 154: Administrative lines on router03.nipper.org
Line Access Login Exec Timeout Absolute Timeout Session Timeout Login Timeout Session Limit Filter In Filter Out Callback
VTY 0 - 4 Yes AAA [LOGIN_AUTHENTICATION] 10 minutes None None 30 seconds 2 40   N/A

[PASS]

Access to the web services restricted concurrent sessions to two sessions on router03.nipper.org.

3.2.10.5 Fix

Configure the router to limit the number of concurrent management sessions to an organization-defined number as shown in the example below.

R4(config)#ip http max-connections 2 
R4(config)#line vty 0 1 
R4(config-line)#transport input ssh
R4(config-line)#exit
R4(config)#line vty 2 4 
R4(config-line)# transport input none  
R4(config-line)#end

3.2.10.6 CCI References

The information system limits the number of concurrent sessions for each organization-defined account and/or account type to an organization-defined number of sessions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-10;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-10.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-10.

3.2.10.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000054
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96007, SV-105145
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96007, SV-105145
  • Fix ID : F-16854r648756_fix
  • Check ID : C-16856r648755_chk

3.2.11 SRG-APP-000026-NDM-000208

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215663
  • Rule ID : SV-215663r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000018
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000090
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.11.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to automatically audit account creation.

3.2.11.2 Discussion

Upon gaining access to a network device, an attacker will often first attempt to create a persistent method of reestablishing access. One way to accomplish this is to create a new account. Notification of account creation helps to mitigate this risk. Auditing account creation provides the necessary reconciliation that account management procedures are being followed. Without this audit trail, personnel without the proper authorization may gain access to critical network nodes.

3.2.11.3 Check

Review the router configuration to determine if it automatically audits account creation. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

archive
 log config
 logging enable

Note: Configuration changes can be viewed using the show archive log config all command.

If account creation is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.11.4 Findings

3.2.11.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log configuration changes.

3.2.11.5 Fix

Configure the router to log account creation using the following commands:

R4(config)#archive
R4(config-archive)#log config
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#end

3.2.11.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account creation actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.11.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000018
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105153, V-96015
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105153, V-96015
  • Fix ID : F-16855r285952_fix
  • Check ID : C-16857r285951_chk

3.2.12 SRG-APP-000027-NDM-000209

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215664
  • Rule ID : SV-215664r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001403
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000100
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.12.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to automatically audit account modification.

3.2.12.2 Discussion

Since the accounts in the network device are privileged or system-level accounts, account management is vital to the security of the network device. Account management by a designated authority ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel with the appropriate and necessary privileges. Auditing account modification along with an automatic notification to appropriate individuals will provide the necessary reconciliation that account management procedures are being followed. If modifications to management accounts are not audited, reconciliation of account management procedures cannot be tracked.

3.2.12.3 Check

Review the router configuration to determine if it automatically audits account modification. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

archive
 log config
 logging enable

Note: Configuration changes can be viewed using the show archive log config all command.

If account modification is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.12.4 Findings

3.2.12.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log configuration changes.

3.2.12.5 Fix

Configure the router to log account modification using the following commands:

R4(config)#archive
R4(config-archive)#log config
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#end

3.2.12.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account modification actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.12.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001403
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105155, V-96017
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105155, V-96017
  • Fix ID : F-16856r285955_fix
  • Check ID : C-16858r285954_chk

3.2.13 SRG-APP-000028-NDM-000210

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215665
  • Rule ID : SV-215665r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001404
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000110
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

Notes

Cheese

3.2.13.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to automatically audit account disabling actions.

3.2.13.2 Discussion

Account management, as a whole, ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel. Auditing account disabling actions will support account management procedures. When device management accounts are disabled, user or service accessibility may be affected. Auditing also ensures authorized active accounts remain enabled and available for use when required.

3.2.13.3 Check

Review the router configuration to determine if it automatically audits account disabling. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

archive
 log config
 logging enable

Note: Configuration changes can be viewed using the show archive log config all command.

If account disabling is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.13.4 Findings

3.2.13.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log configuration changes.

3.2.13.5 Fix

Configure the router to log account disabling using the following commands:

R4(config)#archive
R4(config-archive)#log config
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#end

3.2.13.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account disabling actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.13.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001404
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96019, SV-105157
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96019, SV-105157
  • Fix ID : F-16857r285958_fix
  • Check ID : C-16859r285957_chk

3.2.14 SRG-APP-000029-NDM-000211

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215666
  • Rule ID : SV-215666r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001405
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000120
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.14.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to automatically audit account removal actions.

3.2.14.2 Discussion

Account management, as a whole, ensures access to the network device is being controlled in a secure manner by granting access to only authorized personnel. Auditing account removal actions will support account management procedures. When device management accounts are terminated, user or service accessibility may be affected. Auditing also ensures authorized active accounts remain enabled and available for use when required.

3.2.14.3 Check

Review the router configuration to determine if it automatically audits account removal. The configuration should look similar to the example below:

archive
 log config
 logging enable

Note: Configuration changes can be viewed using the show archive log config all command.

If account removal is not automatically audited, this is a finding.

3.2.14.4 Findings

3.2.14.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log configuration changes.

3.2.14.5 Fix

Configure the router to log account removal using the following commands:

R4(config)#archive
R4(config-archive)#log config
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R4(config-archive-log-cfg)#end

3.2.14.6 CCI References

The information system automatically audits account removal actions.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-2 (4);
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-2 (4).1 (i and ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-2 (4).

3.2.14.7 Additional Information

  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM

  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105159, V-96021
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105159, V-96021
  • Fix ID : F-16858r285961_fix
  • Check ID : C-16860r285960_chk

3.2.15 SRG-APP-000038-NDM-000213

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215667
  • Rule ID : SV-215667r835035_rule
  • CCI : CCI-001368
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000140
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Investigate)

3.2.15.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the device based on control policies.

3.2.15.2 Discussion

A mechanism to detect and prevent unauthorized communication flow must be configured or provided as part of the system design. If management information flow is not enforced based on approved authorizations, the network device may become compromised. Information flow control regulates where management information is allowed to travel within a network device. The flow of all management information must be monitored and controlled so it does not introduce any unacceptable risk to the network device or data.

Application-specific examples of enforcement occur in systems that employ rule sets or establish configuration settings that restrict information system services or message-filtering capability based on message content (e.g., implementing key word searches or using document characteristics).

Applications providing information flow control must be able to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the system in accordance with applicable policy.

3.2.15.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement.

Step 1: Verify that the line vty has an ACL inbound applied as shown in the example below.

line vty 0 1
 access-class MANAGEMENT_NET in
 transport input ssh

Step 2: Verify that the ACL permits only hosts from the management network to access the router.

ip access-list extended MANAGEMENT_NET 
permit ip x.x.x.0 0.0.0.255 any
deny   ip any any log-input

If the Cisco router is not configured to enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of management information within the device based on control policies, this is a finding.

3.2.15.4 Fix

Configure the Cisco router to restrict management access to specific IP addresses via SSH as shown in the example below.

SW2(config)#ip access-list standard MANAGEMENT_NET 
SW2(config-std-nacl)#permit x.x.x.0 0.0.0.255 
SW2(config-std-nacl)#exit 
SW2(config)#line vty 0 1 
SW2(config-line)#transport input ssh 
SW2(config-line)#access-class MANAGEMENT_NET in 
SW2(config-line)#end

3.2.15.5 CCI References

The information system enforces approved authorizations for controlling the flow of information within the system based on organization-defined information flow control policies.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-4;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-4.1 (iii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-4.

3.2.15.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-001368
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96023, SV-105161
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96023, SV-105161
  • Fix ID : F-16859r835034_fix
  • Check ID : C-16861r835033_chk

3.2.16 SRG-APP-000065-NDM-000214

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215668
  • Rule ID : SV-215668r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000044
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000150
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Investigate)

3.2.16.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to enforce the limit of three consecutive invalid logon attempts, after which time it must lock out the user account from accessing the device for 15 minutes.

3.2.16.2 Discussion

By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-forcing, is reduced.

3.2.16.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it enforces the limit of three consecutive invalid logon attempts as shown in the example below.

login block-for 900 attempts 3 within 120

Note: The configuration example above will block any login attempt for 15 minutes after three consecutive invalid logon attempts within a two-minute period.

If the Cisco router is not configured to enforce the limit of three consecutive invalid logon attempts, this is a finding.

3.2.16.4 Findings

3.2.16.4.1 router03.nipper.org

[INVESTIGATE]

[INVESTIGATE]

3.2.16.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco router to enforce the limit of three consecutive invalid logon attempts as shown in the example below.

R2(config)#login block-for 900 attempts 3 within 120

3.2.16.6 CCI References

The information system enforces the organization-defined limit of consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during the organization-defined time period.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-7 a;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-7.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-7 a.

3.2.16.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000044
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105163, V-96025
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105163, V-96025
  • Fix ID : F-16860r285967_fix
  • Check ID : C-16862r285966_chk

3.2.17 SRG-APP-000068-NDM-000215

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215669
  • Rule ID : SV-215669r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000048
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000160
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.17.1 Summary

The Cisco router must be configured to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access to the device.

3.2.17.2 Discussion

Display of the DoD-approved use notification before granting access to the network device ensures privacy and security notification verbiage used is consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

System use notifications are required only for access via logon interfaces with human users.

3.2.17.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

banner login ^C
You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.
^C

If the Cisco router is not configured to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access to the device, this is a finding.

3.2.17.4 Findings

3.2.17.4.1 router03.nipper.org

The Login banner message on router03.nipper.org was:


This is a test banner. This also has a really long banner text line to see what happens when the banner text is wider than the report content display.

3.2.17.5 Fix

Configure the Cisco router to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access as shown in the following example:

R1(config)#banner login #
Enter TEXT message. End with the character '#'.
You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details. #
R1(config)#end

3.2.17.5.1 router03.nipper.org

The following will set a login banner message that contains the appropriate organization authorization and legal warning text. (Risk Level - Safe)

banner login ^
You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only. By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions: 
-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations. 
-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS. 
-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose. 
-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy. 
-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.
^

3.2.17.6 CCI References

The information system displays an organization-defined system use notification message or banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AC-8 a;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AC-8.1 (ii);
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AC-8 a.

  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM

  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96027, SV-105165
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96027, SV-105165
  • Fix ID : F-16861r285970_fix
  • Check ID : C-16863r285969_chk

3.2.18 SRG-APP-000080-NDM-000345

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215670
  • Rule ID : SV-215670r835036_rule
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000210
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.18.1 Summary

The Cisco device must be configured to audit all administrator activity.

3.2.18.2 Discussion

This requirement supports non-repudiation of actions taken by an administrator and is required in order to maintain the integrity of the configuration management process. All configuration changes to the network device are logged, and administrators authenticate with two-factor authentication before gaining administrative access. Together, these processes will ensure the administrators can be held accountable for the configuration changes they implement.

To meet this requirement, the network device must log administrator access and activity.

3.2.18.3 Check

Review the Cisco router configuration to verify that it is compliant with this requirement as shown in the example below.

hostname R1
!
logging userinfo
!
…
…
…
archive
log config
logging enable
!

Note: The logging userinfo global configuration command will generate a log when a user increases his or her privilege level.

If logging of administrator activity is not configured, this is a finding.

3.2.18.4 Findings

3.2.18.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log configuration changes.

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log user information.

3.2.18.5 Fix

Configure the router to log administrator activity as shown in the example below.

R1(config)#logging userinfo
R1(config)#archive
R1(config-archive)#log config
R1(config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R1(config-archive-log-cfg)#end

3.2.18.6 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000172, CCI-002234, CCI-000166
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000172, CCI-002234, CCI-000166
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000172, CCI-002234, CCI-000166
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96035, SV-105173
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : V-96035, SV-105173
  • Fix ID : F-16862r285973_fix
  • Check ID : C-16864r285972_chk

3.2.19 SRG-APP-000096-NDM-000226

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215672
  • Rule ID : SV-215672r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000131
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000280
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Pass)

3.2.19.1 Summary

The Cisco router must produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.

3.2.19.2 Discussion

It is essential for security personnel to know what is being done, what was attempted, where it was done, when it was done, and by whom it was done in order to compile an accurate risk assessment. Logging the date and time of each detected event provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured network device. In order to establish and correlate the series of events leading up to an outage or attack, it is imperative the date and time are recorded in all log records.

3.2.19.3 Check

Verify that the router is configured to include the date and time on all log records as shown in the configuration example below.

service timestamps log datetime localtime

If time stamps is not configured, this is a finding.

3.2.19.4 Findings

3.2.19.4.1 router03.nipper.org

Nipper determined that router03.nipper.org was configured to log messages with a timestamp.

3.2.19.5 Fix

Configure the router to include the date and time on all log records as shown in the example below.

R1(config)#service timestamps log datetime localtime

3.2.19.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes when an event occurred.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.

3.2.19.7 Additional Information

Information
  • Reference ID : 4014
  • Reference Title : DPMS Target Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • Reference Publisher : DISA
  • Reference Type : DPMS Target
  • Reference Subject : Cisco IOS Router NDM
  • http://cyber.mil/cci : CCI-000131
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105179, V-96041
  • http://cyber.mil/legacy : SV-105179, V-96041
  • Fix ID : F-16864r285979_fix
  • Check ID : C-16866r285978_chk

3.2.20 SRG-APP-000097-NDM-000227

Information
  • Vuln ID : V-215673
  • Rule ID : SV-215673r521266_rule
  • CCI : CCI-000132
  • STIG ID : CISC-ND-000290
DISA STIG Rating
  • Category: CAT-II

Affected Devices

Cisco Router 1841 router03.nipper.org (Fail)

3.2.20.1 Summary

The Cisco router must produce audit records containing information to establish where the events occurred.

3.2.20.2 Discussion

In order to compile an accurate risk assessment and provide forensic analysis, it is essential for security personnel to know where events occurred, such as device hardware components, device software modules, session identifiers, filenames, host names, and functionality.

Associating information about where the event occurred within the network device provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured device.

3.2.20.3 Check

Review the deny statements in all ACLs to determine if the log-input parameter has been configured as shown in the example below.

ip access-list extended BLOCK_INBOUND
 deny  icmp any any log-input

If the router is not configured with the log-input parameter after any deny statements to note where packets have been dropped via an ACL, this is a finding.

3.2.20.4 Findings

3.2.20.4.1 router03.nipper.org
Table 155: Extended IPv4 ACL: named-acl-1
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 172.168.2.3 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 10.8.10.11 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
Table 156: Extended IPv4 ACL: cp-critical-in
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
41 Any IPv4 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
Table 157: Extended IPv4 ACL: INBOUND_MSDP_SA_FILTER
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv4 224.0.1.3 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
2 Any IPv4 224.0.1.24 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
3 Any IPv4 224.0.1.22 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
4 Any IPv4 224.0.1.2 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
5 Any IPv4 224.0.1.35 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
6 Any IPv4 224.0.1.60 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
7 Any IPv4 224.0.1.39 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
8 Any IPv4 224.0.1.40 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
9 Any IPv4 232.0.0.0/8 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
10 Any IPv4 239.0.0.0/8 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
11 10.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
12 127.0.0.0/8 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
13 172.16.0.0/12 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
14 192.168.0.0/16 Any IPv4 Any IP from any port to any port Connection State: Any No
Table 158: Extended IPv4 ACL: 120
Rule Action Source Destination Service Log
8 Any IPv4 192.168.30.56 TCP from any port to port 9876 No
Table 159: IPv6 Access List: FILTER_IPV6
Rule Action Source Destination Service Properties Log
1 Any IPv6 32::48/80 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
2 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP [Option 138] from any port to any port   Yes
3 Any IPv6 1e7f:4d:1::32 IPv6-ICMP Fragments Yes
5 Any IPv6 Any IPv6 Any IP from any port to any port Routing Types No

3.2.20.5 Fix

Configure the log-input parameter after any deny statements to provide the location as to where packets have been dropped via an ACL.

R1(config)#ip access-list extended BLOCK_INBOUND
R1(config-ext-nacl)#deny icmp any any log-input

3.2.20.6 CCI References

The information system generates audit records containing information that establishes where the event occurred.

  • NIST SP 800-53 v3 - AU-3;
  • NIST SP 800-53A v1 - AU-3.1;
  • NIST SP 800-53 Revision 4 v4 - AU-3.
